    The city has developed and adopts by reference as though fully set forth in this division an identity theft prevention program for the purpose of complying with 16 CFR 681.2 and in order to detect, prevent and mitigate identity theft by identifying and detecting identity theft red flags and by responding to such red flags in a manner that will prevent identity theft. Pursuant to 16 CFR 681.1, the purpose of the adopted program is also to establish a process by which the city will be able to form a reasonable belief that a consumer report relates to the consumer about whom it has requested a consumer credit report when the city has received a notice of address discrepancy. 
Sec. 2-262. - Fee schedule. 
    The city has adopted a fee schedule setting forth city fees, charges and rates authorized throughout this Code. A copy of the fee schedule, as amended from time to time by the city council, is available in the office of the city secretary. The fee schedule is adopted and incorporated as fully as if set forth in full in this section. 
Sec. 2-263. - Dishonored check fees. 
    A fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule shall be charged for any check or electronic funds draft accepted by the city in payment of any fee, tax or other charge that is dishonored by the holder for insufficient funds or other cause. 
Sec. 2-264. - State law controls purchasing and contracting authority. 
    V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 252 provides regulations and procedure regarding the purchasing and contracting authority of state municipalities that applies to the city only to the extent that the statutory provisions do not conflict with the city's Charter. V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 252.002 allows the city to override its Charter, thereby making V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 252 applicable despite contrary charter provisions. The city elects, pursuant to V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 252.002, that in the event of conflict between V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 252 and the city's Charter, the statutory provisions shall control. 
(Ord. No. 1928, 10-10-2000) 
Secs. 2-265-2-291. - Reserved. 
Chapter 4 - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal and county authority to regulate sexually oriented businesses, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 243.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
    Adult arcade means any place to which public is permitted or invited wherein coin/slug-operated or electronically, electrically or mechanically controlled still or motion picture machines, projectors or other image-producing devices are maintained to show images to five or fewer persons per machine at any one time and where the images so displayed are distinguished or characterized by the depicting or describing "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas." 
    Adult cabaret means a nightclub, bar, restaurant or similar commercial establishment which regularly features: 
(1)  Persons who appear in a state of nudity; 
(2)  Live performances which are characterized by the exposure of specified anatomical areas or by specified sexual activities; or 
(3)  Films, motion pictures, videocassettes, slides or other photographic reproductions which are characterized by the depiction or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
    Adult motel means a hotel, motel or similar commercial establishment which: 
(1)  Offers accommodations to the public for any form of consideration; provides patrons with closed-circuit television transmissions, films, motion pictures, videocassettes, slides or other photographic reproductions which are characterized by the depiction or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas; and has a sign visible from the public right-of-way which advertises the availability of this adult type of photographic reproductions; 
(2)  Offers a sleeping room for rent for a period of time that is less than ten hours; or 
(3)  Allows a tenant or occupant of a sleeping room to sub-rent the room for a period of time that is less than ten hours. 
    Adult motion picture theater means a commercial establishment where, for any form of consideration, films, motion pictures, videocassettes, slides or similar photographic reproductions are regularly shown which are characterized by the depiction or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
    Adult novelty store or adult video store means a commercial establishment which, as its principal business purpose, offers for sale or rental for any form of consideration any one or more of the following: 
(1)  Books, magazines, periodicals or other printed matter, or photographs, films, motion pictures, video cassettes, audio cassettes, video reproductions, slides or other photographic reproductions which depict or describe specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas; or 
(2)  Instruments, devices or paraphernalia which are designed for use in connection with "specified sexual activities." 
    Adult theater means a theater, concert hall, auditorium or similar commercial establishment which regularly features persons who appear in a state of nudity, seminude or live performances which are characterized by the exposure of specified anatomical areas or by specified sexual activities. 
    Building inspector means the building and code compliance officer of the city. 
    City police chief means the city police chief of the city or his designated agent. 
    Escort means a person who, for consideration, agrees or offers to act as a companion, guide or date for another person, or who agrees or offers to privately model lingerie or to privately perform a striptease for another person. 
    Escort agency means a person or business association who furnishes, offers to furnish or advertises to furnish escorts as one of its primary business purposes, for a fee, tip or other consideration. 
    Establishment means and includes any of the following: 
(1)  The opening or commencement of any sexually oriented business as a new business; 
(2)  The conversion of an existing business, whether or not a sexually oriented business, to any sexually oriented business; 
(3)  The addition of any sexually oriented business to any other existing sexually oriented business; or 
(4)  The relocation of any sexually oriented business. 
    Licensee means a person in whose name a license to operate a sexually oriented business has been issued, as well as the individual listed as an applicant on the application for a license. 
    Nude model studio means any place where a person who appears in a state of nudity or displays specified anatomical areas is provided to be observed, sketched, drawn, painted, sculptured, photographed or similarly depicted by other persons who pay money or any form of consideration. 
    Nudity or state of nudity means the bare appearance of a human buttock, anus, male genitals, female genitals or female breast, regardless of whether uncovered or covered with translucent or transparent material. 
    Person means an individual, proprietorship, partnership, corporation, association or other legal entity. 
    Principal business or primary business means: 
(1)  35 percent or more of the gross floor area is devoted to the sale, display or inventory of items which depict or describe specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas or which are designed for use in connection with specified sexual activities; or 
(2)  35 percent or more of the gross receipts are derived from the sale or rental of items described in subsection (1) of this definition. 
    Residential use means any single-family, multifamily or mobile home dwelling, regardless of whether attached or detached and regardless of whether tenant or owner occupied. 
    Seminude means a state of dress in which clothing or other matter covers no more than the genitals, public region or areola of the female breast, as well as portions of the body covered by supporting straps or devices. 
    Sexual encounter center means a business or commercial enterprise that, is one of its primary business purposes, offers for any form of consideration: 
(1)  Physical contact in the form of wrestling or tumbling between persons of the opposite sex; or 
(2)  Activities between male and female persons and/or persons of the same sex when one or more of the persons is in a state of nudity or seminude. 
    Sexually oriented business means an adult arcade, adult bookstore or adult video store, adult cabaret, adult motel, adult motion picture theater, escort agency, nude model studio or sexual encounter center. 
    Signage means those sign definitions as contained in chapter 42. 
    Specified anatomical areas means human genitals in a state of sexual arousal. 
    Specified sexual activities means and includes any of the following: 
(1)  The fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttocks, anus or female breasts; 
(2)  Sex acts, normal or perverted, actual or simulated, including intercourse, oral copulation or sodomy; 
(3)  Masturbation, actual or simulated; or 
(4)  Excretory functions as part of or in connection with any of activities set forth in subsections (1) through (3) of this definition. 
    Substantial enlargement of a sexually oriented business means the increase in floor area occupied by the business by more than 25 percent, as the floor area exists after December 1, 2000. 
    Transfer of ownership or control of a sexually oriented business means and includes any of the following: 
(1)  The sale, lease or sublease of the business; 
(2)  The transfer of securities which constitute a controlling interest in the business, whether by sale, exchange or similar means; or 
(3)  The establishment of a trust, gift, or other similar legal device which transfers the ownership or control of the business, except for transfer by bequest or other operation of law upon the death of the person possessing the ownership or control. 
(Ord. No. 1932, § I, 12-12-2000) 
Sec. 4-2. - Purpose and intent. 
(a)  It is the purpose of this article to regulate sexually oriented businesses to promote the health, safety, morals and general welfare of the citizens of the city and to establish reasonable and uniform regulations to prevent the concentration of sexually oriented businesses within the city. The provisions of this article have neither the purpose nor effect of imposing a limitation or restriction on the content of any communicative materials, including sexually oriented materials. Similarly, it is not the intent nor effect of this article to restrict or deny access by adults to sexually oriented materials protected by the First Amendment, or to deny access by the distributors and exhibitors of sexually oriented entertainment to their intended market. 
(b)  It is the intent of the city council that the locational regulations of this section are promulgated pursuant to Texas Local Government Code Chapter 243 (V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 243.001 et seq.), as they apply to sexually oriented businesses. It is also the intent of the city council that all other provisions of this article are promulgated pursuant to the city charter and state law. The provisions of this article are not intended to regulate businesses within the city that are exempt pursuant to V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 243.004. 
(Ord. No. 1932, § II, 12-12-2000) 
Sec. 4-3. - Classification. 
    Sexually oriented businesses are classified as follows: 
(1)  Adult arcades; 
(2)  Adult bookstores or adult video stores; 
(3)  Adult cabarets; 
(4)  Adult motels; 
(5)  Adult motion picture theaters; 
(6)  Adult theaters; 
(7)  Escort agencies; 
(8)  Nude model studios; and 
(9)  Sexual encounter centers. 
(Ord. No. 1932, § III, 12-12-2000) 
Secs. 4-4-4-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 4-25. - Inspection. 
(a)  An applicant or licensee under this article shall permit representatives of the police department, health department, fire department and building inspection department to inspect the premises of a sexually oriented business for the purpose of ensuring compliance with the law, at any time it is occupied or open for business. 
(b)  A person who operates a sexually oriented business or his agent or employee commits an offense if he refuses to permit a lawful inspection of the premises by a representative from the above departments at any time it is occupied or open for business. 
(Ord. No. 1932, § IV, 12-12-2000) 
Sec. 4-26. - Penalties; defenses. 
(a)  Except as provided by subsection (b) of this section, any person violating section 4-90, upon conviction, is punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00. 
(b)  If the sexually oriented business involved is a nude model studio or sexual encounter center, then violation of section 4-58 or 4-90 is punishable as a Class A misdemeanor. 
(c)  It is a defense to prosecution under section 4-58 or 4-90 that a person appearing in a state of nudity did so in a modeling class operated: 
(1)  By a propriety school licensed by the state; or 
(2)  By a public or private accredited college or university which maintains and operates educational programs. 
(d)  It is a defense to prosecution under section 4-58 or 4-90 that each item of descriptive, printed, film or video material offered for sale or rental, taken as a whole, contains serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. 
(Ord. No. 1932, § XII, 12-12-2000) 
Secs. 4-27-4-57. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LICENSING 

Sec. 4-58. - License. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if he operates a sexually oriented business without a valid license issued by the city for the particular type of business. 
(b)  An application for a license under this article must be made on a form provided by the building inspector. The application must be accompanied by a diagram showing the configuration of the premises, including a statement of total floor space occupied by the business. The diagram need not be professionally prepared but must be drawn to a scale of no less than one inch equals ten feet or drawn with marked dimensions of the interior of the premises to an accuracy of plus or minus six inches. Applicants who must comply with section 4-94 shall submit a diagram meeting the requirements of that section. 
(c)  The applicant for a license under this article must be qualified according to the provisions of this article and the premises must be inspected and found to be in compliance with the law by the building inspection department. 
(d)  If a person who wishes to operate a sexually oriented business is an individual, he must sign the application for a license as applicant. If a person who wishes to operate a sexually oriented business is other than an individual, each individual who has a 20 percent or greater interest in the business must sign the application for a license as applicant. Each applicant must be qualified under section 4-59 and each applicant shall be considered a licensee if a license is granted. 
(Ord. No. 1932, § XIV, 12-12-2000) 
Sec. 4-59. - Issuance. 
(a)  The building inspector shall approve the issuance of a license under this article to an applicant within 30 days after receipt of an application unless he finds one or more of the following to be true: 
(1)  An applicant is under 18 years of age. 
(2)  An applicant or an applicant's spouse is overdue in his payment to the city of taxes, fees, fines or penalties assessed against him or imposed upon him in relation to a sexually oriented business. 
(3)  An applicant has failed to provide information reasonably necessary for issuance of the license or has falsely answered a question or request for information on the application form. 
(4)  An applicant or an applicant's spouse has been convicted of a violation of a provision of this article, other than the offense of operating a sexually oriented business without a license, within two years immediately preceding the application. The fact that a conviction is being appealed shall have no effect. 
(5)  An applicant is residing with a person who has been denied a license by the city to operate a sexually oriented business within the preceding 12 months or residing with a person whose license to operate a sexually oriented business has been revoked within the preceding 12 months. 
(6)  The premises to be used for the sexually oriented business has not been approved by the building inspection department as being in compliance with applicable laws and ordinances. 
(7)  The license fee required by this article has not been paid. 
(8)  An applicant or the proposed establishment is in violation of or is not in compliance with sections 4-25, 4-27, 4-90, 4-92, 4-93, 4-94 and 4-95. 
(9)  An applicant or an applicant's spouse has been convicted of a crime: 
a.  Involving: 
1.  Prostitution; 
2.  Promotion of prostitution; 
3.  Aggravated promotion of prostitution; 
4.  Compelling prostitution; 
5.  Obscenity; 
6.  Sale, distribution or display of harmful material to a minor; 
7.  Sexual performance by a child; 
8.  Possession or promotion of child pornography; 
9.  Public lewdness; 
10.  Indecent exposure; 
11.  Indecency with a child; 
12.  Sexual assault or aggravated sexual assault; 
13.  Prohibited sexual conduct, enticing a child or harboring a runaway child; 
14.  Criminal attempt, conspiracy or solicitation to commit any of the foregoing offenses; 
b.  For which: 
1.  Less than two years have elapsed since the date of conviction or the date of release from confinement imposed for the conviction, whichever is the later date, if the conviction is of a misdemeanor offense; 
2.  Less than five years have elapsed since the date of conviction or the date of release from confinement for the conviction, whichever is the later date, if the conviction is of a felony offense; or 
3.  Less than five years have elapsed since the date of the last conviction or the date of release from confinement for the last conviction, whichever is the later date, if the convictions are of two or more misdemeanor offenses or combination of offenses occurring within any 24-month period. 
c.  The fact that a conviction is being appealed shall have no effect on the disqualification of the applicant for a sexually oriented business license or the applicant's spouse. 
d.  The license, if granted, shall state on its face the name of the person to whom it is granted, the expiration date and the address of the sexually oriented business. The license shall be posted in a conspicuous place at or near the entrance to the sexually oriented business so that it may be easily read at any time. 
(Ord. No. 1932, § XV, 12-12-2000) 
Sec. 4-60. - Fees. 
    The annual fee for a sexually oriented business license shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Ord. No. 1932, § XVII, 12-12-2000) 
Sec. 4-61. - Transfer of license. 
    A licensee shall not transfer his sexually oriented business license to another nor shall a licensee operate a sexually oriented business under the authority of a license at any place other than the address designated in the application for such license. 
(Ord. No. 1932, § XXII, 12-12-2000) 
Sec. 4-62. - Expiration of license. 
(a)  Each license issued under this article shall expire one year from the date of issuance and may be renewed only by making application as provided in section 4-58. Application for renewal of such license must be made at least 30 days before the expiration date, and when made less than 30 days before the expiration date, the expiration of the license will not be affected and the renewal application will be treated as a new application. 
(b)  When the building inspector denies renewal of a license under this article, the applicant shall not be issued a license for one year from the date of denial. If, subsequent to denial, the building inspector finds that the basis for denial of the renewal license has been corrected or abated, the applicant may be granted a license if at least 90 days have elapsed since the date denial became final. 
(Ord. No. 1932, § XVIII, 12-12-2000) 
Sec. 4-63. - Suspension. 
    The building inspector shall suspend a sexually oriented business license for a period not to exceed 30 days if he determines that a licensee or an employee of a licensee has: 
(1)  Violated or is not in compliance with sections 4-25, 4-27, 4-90, 4-92, 4-93, 4-94 and 4-95; 
(2)  Engaged in excessive use of alcoholic beverages while on the sexually oriented business premises; 
(3)  Refused to allow an inspection of the sexually oriented business premises as authorized by this article; 
(4)  Knowingly permitted gambling by any person on the sexually oriented business premises; or 
(5)  Demonstrated inability to operate or manage a sexually oriented business in a peaceful and law abiding manner, thus necessitating action by law enforcement officers. 
(Ord. No. 1932, § XIX, 12-12-2000) 
Sec. 4-64. - Revocation. 
(a)  The building inspector shall revoke a sexually oriented business license if a cause of suspension under section 4-62 occurs and the license has been suspended within the preceding 12 months. 
(b)  The building inspector shall revoke a sexually oriented business license if he determines that: 
(1)  A licensee gave false or misleading information in the material submitted to the building inspector during the application process; 
(2)  A licensee or an employee has knowingly allowed possession, use or sale of controlled substances on the premises; 
(3)  A licensee or an employee has knowingly allowed prostitution on the premises; 
(4)  A licensee or an employee knowingly operated the sexually oriented business during a period of time when the licensee's license was suspended; 
(5)  A licensee has been convicted of an offense listed in section 4-59 for which the time period required has not elapsed; 
(6)  On two or more occasions within a 12-month period, a person committed an offense occurring in or on the licensed premises of a crime listed in section 4-59 for which a conviction has been obtained and the person was an employee of the sexually oriented business at the time the offenses were committed; 
(7)  A licensee or an employee has knowingly allowed any act of sexual intercourse, sodomy, oral copulation, masturbation or sexual contact to occur in or on the licensed premises. The term "sexual contact" shall have the same meaning as it is defined in the Texas Penal Code; or 
(8)  A licensee is delinquent in payment to the city for hotel-motel occupancy taxes, ad valorem taxes or sales taxes related to the sexually oriented business. 
(c)  The fact that a conviction is being appealed shall have no effect on the revocation of the sexually oriented business license. 
(d)  When the building inspector revokes a sexually oriented business license, the revocation shall continue for one year and the licensee shall not be issued a sexually oriented business license for one year from the date revocation becomes effective. If, subsequent to revocation, the building inspector finds that the basis for the revocation has been corrected or abated, the applicant may be granted a license if at least 90 days have elapsed since the date the revocation became effective. If the license was revoked under subsection (b) of this section, an applicant may not be granted another license until the appropriate number of years required has elapsed since the termination of any sentence, parole or probation. 
(Ord. No. 1932, § XX, 12-12-2000) 
Sec. 4-65. - Appeals. 
    If the building inspector denies the issuance of a sexually oriented business license, suspends or revokes a sexually oriented business license, he shall send to the applicant or licensee, by certified mail, return receipt requested, written notice of his action and the right to an appeal. The aggrieved party may appeal the decision of the building inspector to the city council. The filing of an appeal stays the action of the building inspector in suspending or revoking a license until the city council makes a final decision thereon. 
(Ord. No. 1932, § XXI, 12-12-2000) 
Secs. 4-66-4-88. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PREMISES AND OPERATION REGULATIONS 

Sec. 4-89. - Signage. 
(a)  All signs must comply with the provisions of chapter 42, and, additionally, any sexually oriented business sign must be no larger than 100 square feet. 
(b)  Any sign that is visible from the exterior of the structure will not have a pictorial display of a seminude or nude person or of any other person considered in a state of nudity. 
(Ord. No. 1932, § XVI, 12-12-2000) 
Sec. 4-90. - Location restrictions. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if he operates or causes to be operated a sexually oriented business within 1,000 feet of: 
(1)  A church; 
(2)  A public or private elementary or secondary school or a registered daycare center; 
(3)  A boundary of any district zoned R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4, R-5, MH, and B-1; 
(4)  Any public area used or owned by a governmental or educational entity; or 
(5)  The property line of a lot having any residential use as defined in section 4-1. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if he causes or permits the operation, establishment, substantial enlargement or transfer of ownership or control of a sexually oriented business within 1,000 feet of another sexually oriented business. 
(c)  A person commits an offense if he causes or permits the operation, establishment or maintenance of more than one sexually oriented business in the same building, structure or portion thereof, or the increase of floor area of any sexually oriented business in any building, structure or portion thereof containing another sexually oriented business. 
(d)  For the purposes of subsection (a) of this section, measurement shall be made in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures or objects, from the nearest portion of the building or structure used as a part of the premises where a sexually oriented business is conducted, to the nearest property line of the premises described in subsection (a) of this section. 
(e)  For the purposes of subsection (b) of this section, the distance between any two sexually oriented businesses shall be measured in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures or objects, from the closest exterior wall of the structure in which each business is located. 
(Ord. No. 1932, § V, 12-12-2000) 
Sec. 4-91. - Exemptions from location restrictions. 
(a)  If the building inspector denies the issuance of a license to an applicant because the location of the sexually oriented business establishment is in violation of section 4-90, then the applicant may, not later than ten calendar days after receiving notice of the denial, file with the city secretary a written request for an appeal from the locational restrictions of section 4-90. 
(b)  If the written request for an appeal from the locational restrictions of section 4-90 is filed with the city secretary within the ten-day limit, the city secretary shall set a date for appeal to the city council within 60 days from the written request is received. The appeal will be placed on the city council's agenda and the city secretary shall notify both the applicant and the building inspector of the meeting date. 
(c)  The city council may, at its discretion, grant an exemption from the locational restrictions of section 4-90 if it makes the following findings: 
(1)  That the location of the proposed sexually oriented business will not have a detrimental effect on nearby properties or be contrary to the public safety or welfare; 
(2)  That the granting of the exemption will not violate the spirit and intent of this article; 
(3)  That the location of the proposed sexually oriented business will not downgrade the property values or quality of life in the adjacent areas or encourage the development of urban blight; 
(4)  That the location of an additional sexually oriented business in the area will not be contrary to any program of neighborhood conservation nor will it interfere with any efforts of urban renewal or restoration; or 
(5)  That all other applicable provisions of this article will be observed. 
(d)  The city council shall grant or deny the exemption applied for under this section by a majority vote. Failure to reach a majority vote shall result in denial of the exemption. Disputes of fact shall be decided on the basis of preponderance of the evidence. The decision of the city council can be appealed to the district court. 
(e)  If the city council grants the exemption applied for under this section, the exemption is valid for one year from the date of the council action. Upon the expiration of an exemption, the sexually oriented business is in violation of the locational restrictions of section 4-90 until the applicant applies for and receives another exemption. 
(f)  If the city council denies the exemption applied for under this section, the applicant may not reapply for an exemption until at least 12 months have elapsed since the date of city council action. 
(g)  The grant of an exemption under this section does not exempt the applicant from any other provisions of this article other than the locational restrictions of section 4-90. 
(Ord. No. 1932, § VI, 12-12-2000) 
Sec. 4-92. - Employment of persons under the age of 18 years. 
    A person commits an offense if he employs a person under the age of 18 years in any sexually oriented business. 
(Ord. No. 1932, § VIII, 12-12-2000) 
Sec. 4-93. - Additional regulations; adult motels. 
(a)  Evidence that a sleeping room in a hotel, motel or similar commercial establishment has been rented and vacated two or more times in a period of ten hours creates a rebuttable presumption that the establishment is an adult motel as that term is defined in this article. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if, as the person in control of a sleeping room in a hotel, motel or similar commercial establishment that does not have sexually oriented business license, he rents or sub-rents a sleeping room to a person, and, within ten hours from the time the room is rented, he rents or sub-rents the same sleeping room again. 
(c)  For the purposes of this section, the term "rent" or "sub-rent" means the act of permitting a room to be occupied for any form of consideration. 
(Ord. No. 1932, § IX, 12-12-2000) 
Sec. 4-94. - Exhibition of sexually explicit films or videos. 
(a)  A person who operates or causes to be operated a sexually oriented business, other than an adult motel, which exhibits on the premises a film, videocassette or other video reproduction, which depicts specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  Upon application for a sexually oriented business license, the application shall be accompanied by a diagram of the premises showing a plan thereof specifying the location of one or more manager's stations and the location of all overhead lighting fixtures and designating any portion of the premises in which patrons will not be permitted. The diagram shall also designate the place at which the permit shall be conspicuously posted, if granted. A professionally prepared diagram, in the nature of an engineer's or architect's blueprint shall not be required; however, each diagram should be oriented to the north or to some designated street or object and should be drawn to a designated scale (of no less than one inch equals ten feet) or with marked dimensions sufficient to show the various internal dimensions of all areas of the interior of the premises to an accuracy of plus or minus six inches. The building inspector may waive the foregoing diagram for renewal applications if the applicant adopts a diagram that was previously submitted and certifies that the configuration of the premises has not been altered since it was prepared. 
(2)  The application shall be sworn to be true and correct by the applicant. 
(3)  No alteration in the configuration or location of a manager's station may be made without the prior approval of the building inspector or his designee. 
(4)  It is the duty of the owner and operators of the premises to ensure that at least one employee is on duty and situated in each manager's station whenever a patron is present inside the premises. 
(5)  The interior of the premises shall be configured in such a manner that there is an unobstructed view from a manager's station of every area of the premises to which any patron is permitted access for any purpose, excluding restrooms. Restrooms may not contain video reproduction equipment. If the premises have two or more manager's stations designated, then the interior of the premises shall be configured in such a manner that there is an unobstructed and straight view of each area of the premises to which any patron is permitted access for any purpose from at least one of the manager's stations. 
(6)  It shall be the duty of the owner and operators and it shall also be the duty of any agents and employees present in the premises, to ensure that the view area specified in subsection (a)(5) of this section remains unobstructed by any doors, walls, merchandise, display racks or other materials at all times that any patron is present in the premises and to ensure that no patron is permitted access to any area of the premises which has been designated as an area in which patrons will not be permitted in the application filed pursuant to subsection (a)(1) of this section. 
(7)  The premises shall be equipped with overhead lighting fixtures of sufficient intensity to illuminate every place to which patrons are permitted access at an illumination of not less than one foot-candle as measured at the floor level. 
(8)  It shall be the duty of the owner and operators and it shall also be the duty of any agents and employees present in the premises to ensure that the illumination described in subsection (a)(7) of this section is maintained at all times that any patron is present in the premises. 
(b)  A person having a duty under subsections (a)(1) through (a)(8) of this section commits an offense if he knowingly fails to fulfill that duty. 
(Ord. No. 1932, § X, 12-12-2000) 
Sec. 4-95. - Display of sexually explicit material to minors. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if, in any business establishment open to persons under the age of 17 years, he displays a book, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, videocassette or film, the cover of which depicts, in a manner calculated to arouse sexual lust or passion for commercial gain or to exploit sexual lust or passion for commercial gain, any of the following: 
(1)  Human sexual intercourse, masturbation or sodomy. 
(2)  Fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttocks or female breasts. 
(3)  Less than completely opaquely covered human genitals, buttocks or that portion of the female breast below the top of the areola. 
(4)  Human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, whether covered or uncovered. 
(5)  A person also commits an offense if he displays or allows to be displayed any video or game, or any live, mechanical or electronically displayed entertainment depicting or exhibiting subsections (a)(1) through (a)(4) of this section. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if, in any business establishment open to persons under the age of 17 years, he displays any instruments, devices or paraphernalia which are designed for uses in connection with specified sexual activities. 
(c)  In this section, the term "display" means to locate an item in such a manner that, without obtaining assistance from an employee of the business establishment: 
(1)  It is available to the general public for handling and inspection; or 
(2)  The cover or outside packaging on the item is visible to members of the general public; and 
(3)  The game or entertainment is accessible or visible to persons under the age of 17 years. 
(Ord. No. 1932, § XI, 12-12-2000) 
Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Alcoholic beverages, V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code § 1.01 et seq.; alcoholic beverage permit and license fees authorized, V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code §§ 11.38, 61.36; location restrictions for sale of beer and wine authorized, V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code § 109.31 et seq.; local option provisions, V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code § 251.71 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 6-1-6-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PREMISES AND OPERATION REGULATIONS 

Sec. 6-16. - State and city licenses required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or establishment to sell alcoholic beverages, beer or wine for consumption by the general public unless they have first obtained the state alcoholic beverage commission licenses for retail on-premises sale of said alcoholic beverages and the city occupational licenses for all licenses issued by the state. 
(Ord. No. 1637, § III, 9-26-1989) 
Chapter 8 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Local Public Health Reorganization Act, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 121.001 et seq.; treatment of animals, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 821.001 et seq.; dangerous dogs, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 822.001 et seq.; Rabies Control Act of 1981, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.001 et seq.; animal health, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 801.001 et seq.; cruelty to livestock animals, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 42.09; livestock, V.T.C.A., Agriculture Code § 141.001 et seq.; registration of dogs and cats, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.031; protection of birds, nests, and eggs, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 64.002 et seq.; vaccination of dogs and cats, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.021; restraint of dogs and cats; impoundment, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.033; quarantine of animals, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.042 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal means any vertebrate animal other than human beings. 
    Animal control officer means any person designated by the city who is qualified to perform the duties required by this chapter or state law regarding animal control. 
    Animal control shelter means any shelter operated by a humane society, or a municipal agency, for the purpose of impounding animals under authority of this chapter or state law for care, confinement, return to owner, adoption, or euthanasia. 
    Animal nuisance means the public nuisance created by an animal within the city limits that affect the quality of life of persons of normal nervous sensibilities, including, but not limited to, one or more of the following acts of any animal: 
(1)  Molests or chases pedestrians or passing vehicles, including bicycles; 
(2)  Makes an unprovoked attack on a human or other animal of any kind; 
(3)  Is repeatedly at large, specifically three or more times within a 12 month period; 
(4)  Destruction of public or private property belonging to any person other than the owner; 
(5)  Allowing the animals to urinate or defecate on any public or private property other than that of the owner unless such waste is removed and properly disposed by the custodian of the animal; 
(6)  Excessive noise produced by barking, whining, digging, or any other noise activity; 
(7)  Any foul or noxious odor produced by the offending animal. 
    At large means not physically restrained to the premises of the owner or not under the direct control of the owner, handler, or trainer. The term "direct control" means securely confined by leash, chain, or other device not more than six feet in length held by a person or affixed to the owner's premises in a manner capable of controlling the animal. 
    Cat means any domestic feline of either sex, including one neutered or sterilized. 
    Cat kennel means any place in which more than three feline animals over three months of age are confined. This definition excludes animal hospitals. 
    Dog means any domestic canine of either sex, including one neutered or sterilized. 
    Dog kennel means any building, structure or enclosure, wherein more than three canine animals over the age of three months of age are confined except animal hospitals. 
    Domestic animals means all species of animals commonly accepted as being domesticated. This definition specifically includes household pets such as dogs and cats. 
    Harboring means sheltering, feeding, or caring for an animal. 
    Household means those who dwell in the same residence and compose a family. 
    Hybrid animal means any offspring of two animals of different species. 
    Owner means any person or legal entity owning an animal or who harbors, cares for, feeds or who allows an animal to remain about the owner's premises for period of a ten days. This includes any third person who visits the owner's premises when the owner is not present while the dog is inside the premises. 
    Provocation means any purposeful act that causes an animal to bite, scratch or otherwise attack in protection of self, owner, or owner's property. 
    Public nuisance means the violation of the restrictions and rules regarding the ownership, harboring or caring for animals set forth in this chapter subject to penalties as provided in this chapter and to nuisance abatement pursuant to state law. 
    Restraint or restrained means any physical means of controlling an animal, to include, but not limited to, cage, fence, leash, or chain; or automobile, in the cab or tied. 
    Street line means the nearest edge of any sidewalk, or if there is none, then the nearest edge of any curb, or if there is none, then the nearest edge of the improved portion of the public right-of-way. 
    Vicious/dangerous animal means: 
(1)  Any animal with the propensity, tendency, or disposition to make unprovoked attacks on humans or domestic animals; 
(2)  Any animal that has attacked or attempted to attack humans or domestic animals except when the person or animal being attacked is unlawfully on the premises of the owner. 
    Wild animal means an undomesticated animal with the propensity, tendency, or disposition for unprovoked attacks on humans or domestic animals. 
    Working day means any day of the week, excluding weekends and city observed holidays. 
(Code 1973, § 4-1; Ord. No. 1135, § 1, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § I, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1998, § I, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § I(A), 8-22-2006; Ord. No. 2081-A, § I(A), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § I(A), 9-11-2012) 
Secs. 8-2-8-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CARE AND CONTROL REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-23. - Violation deemed public nuisance. 
    Violations of this article shall constitute public nuisances. 
Sec. 8-24. - Keeping diseased animals prohibited; exception. 
    No person except a licensed veterinarian shall keep any animal which is known or believed by him to be infected with any dangerous or communicable disease, or which is afflicted with any painful disease believed by him to be incurable, without written permission to do so from an animal control officer of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 4-6(F); Ord. No. 1135, § 6(J), 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § VI(F), 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1998, § VI(F), 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § VI(F), 8-22-2006; Ord. No. 2081-A, § VI(F), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § VI(F), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-25. - Keeping wild animals prohibited; exception. 
(a)  Certain animals prohibited. It is prohibited and a public nuisance for any person or business to keep or maintain in the city any wild or vicious animal or reptile of any nature whatsoever, including hybrid animals. 
(b)  Carnivals or circuses. Nothing in this section shall be construed to apply to the temporary display of wild or vicious animals or reptiles in carnivals, zoos, museums, exhibitions, or circuses provided that: 
(1)  Prior city council approval has been obtained for such a display; 
(2)  The display has been inspected by the animal control officer; 
(3)  The animals or reptiles are so restricted so as to pose no threat to the public safety; and 
(4)  The animals are well cared for, free from disease and kept in sanitary conditions. 
(c)  Exception for transportation of animals through city. The requirements of this section shall not be applicable to persons transporting wild or vicious animals through the city providing that the transporter has taken adequate safeguards to protect the public and does not park the transporting vehicle within the city limits. 
(Code 1973, § 4-5; Ord. No. 1135, § 5, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § V, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1998, § V, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § V, 8-22-2006; Ord. No. 2081-A, § V, 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § V, 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-26. - Keeping of monkeys and certain livestock prohibited. 
    It is prohibited and a public nuisance for any person to keep or maintain at his residence within the city any of the following animals: 
(1)  Horse, colt, jack or mule; 
(2)  Goats or sheep; 
(3)  Cattle including ox, steer, bull, cow or calf; 
(4)  Pigs or hogs; 
(5)  Monkeys. 
(Code 1973, § 4-4(A); Ord. No. 1135, § 4, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § IV, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1946, § I(E), (F), 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 1998, § IV, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § IV(A), 8-22-2006; Ord. No. 2081-A, § IV(A), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § IV(A), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-27. - Keeping of rabbits and fowl restricted. 
(a)  Maximum number allowed. It is prohibited and a nuisance for any person to keep or maintain at his residence in the city a cumulative total exceeding ten chickens, geese, ducks, turkeys, pheasants, doves, pigeons, squabs, roosters, similar fowl, or rabbits. An adult rooster of crowing age may be substituted for one of the ten fowl allowed under this section. 
(b)  Running at large; enclosure setback requirements. It is prohibited and a nuisance for any person to allow fowl or rabbits to run or fly at large or to go upon the premises of any other person, or upon a public way in the city. The animals shall be kept in a confined area situated no closer than 30 feet to the nearest street line or 20 feet to the nearest property line. 
(c)  Exception for animals raised for food purposes. This section does not prohibit the display or sale of any rabbit or fowl by any dealer, hatchery, or store engaged in the business of selling the same to be raised for food purposes whenever such dealer, hatchery, or store has proper facilities for the display and care of such animals or fowl and is in compliance with city zoning regulations. 
(Code 1973, § 4-4(B)-(D); Ord. No. 1135, § 4, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § IV, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1946, § I(F), (G), 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 1998, § IV, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § IV(B)-(D), 8-22-2006; Ord. No. 2081-A, § IV(B)-(D), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § IV(B)-(D), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-28. - Trapping prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  Chemicals/traps prohibited. The use of cyanic pallet traps or any other kind of trap containing a substance noxious to man is prohibited within the city limits unless deemed necessary by the state department of health for the control of communicable disease. 
(b)  Inhumane traps prohibited. Except by order of the animal control officer, no person shall set up or allow to be set up on his property within the city limits any kind of trap that tears, cuts or in any way mutilates the prey, except traps used to catch common rodents, i.e., rats, mice, gophers, and ground squirrels. Traps prohibited by this section may be used on the order of the animal control officer for the control of communicable diseases. 
(c)  Tin traps prohibited. The use of tin traps is not to be allowed in the city limits unless ordered by the animal control officer. 
(Code 1973, § 4-6(L)-(N); Ord. No. 1135, § 6, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § VI, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1998, § VI, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § VI(L)-(N), 8-22-2006; Ord. No. 2081-A, § VI(L)-(N), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § VI(L)-(N), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-29. - Animals prohibited in commercial food preparation areas; exception. 
    No person shall allow an animal into an area where food is prepared for commercial purposes with the exception of dogs aiding the seeing or hearing impaired. 
(Code 1973, § 4-6(D); Ord. No. 1135, § 6, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § VI, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1998, § VI, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § VI(D), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § VI(D), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § VI(D), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-30. - Disposal of animal carcasses. 
    No person shall cause, suffer or permit the carcass of any animal to remain upon any lot, premises or place owned, controlled or occupied by him or it for a period of more than 24 hours. Violation of this section is deemed a public nuisance. 
(Code 1973, § 4-6(A); Ord. No. 1135, § 6, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § VI, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1998, § VI, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § VI(A), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § VI(A), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § VI(A), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-31. - Manure accumulations. 
(a)  Every person owning or occupying premises where manure from any pigeon, fowl, rabbit or other animal accumulates shall provide for the removal of such manure daily. 
(b)  Boxes, bins or receptacles of a design and construction acceptable to the animal control officer shall be provided by the owner or occupant of such premises, and such boxes, bins or receptacles shall be used only for the purpose of containing the accumulation of manure. In no instance shall manure be placed in such boxes or receptacles in such manner as to prevent the tight closing of the lid. The boxes, bins or receptacles shall be constructed of brick, stone, concrete, metal or wood lined with metal or other sound material, and shall prevent access to the contents thereof by flies. The contents of the boxes, bins or receptacles shall be removed once a week. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to apply to manure that is spread as fertilizer over or around cultivated plants, vines, vegetables, lawns, bushes or trees, or manure kept by any nursery for commercial fertilizer purposes, unless such manure creates a nuisance either from fly breeding or excessive obnoxious odors. 
(Code 1973, § 4-6(B); Ord. No. 1135, § 6, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § VI, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1998, § VI, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § VI(B), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § VI(B), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § VI(B), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-32. - Cleaning of animal and manure enclosures required on order of animal control officer. 
    The animal control officer may order the cleaning and disinfection of any stable, barn, corral, stall, pen, coop, building or place in which any fowl, bird or other animal is kept, and any box, bin or receptacle used for the accumulation of manure. Such order shall be complied with in the time specified by the animal control officer. 
(Code 1973, § 4-6(C); Ord. No. 1135, § 6, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § VI, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1998, § VI, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § VI(C), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § VI(C), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § VI(C), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-33. - Boarding kennels prohibited; exception. 
    No boarding kennel shall be allowed within the city except exempted animal hospitals. 
(Code 1973, § 4-3; Ord. No. 1135, § 3, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § III, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1946, § I(B)-(D), 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 1998, § III, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § III(P)(2), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § III(P)(2), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § III(P)(2), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-34. - Dogs causing death of or serious bodily injury to a person. 
    The city adopts the provisions of V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code §§ 822.002 through 822.006. 
(Code 1973, § 4-2(Q); Ord. No. 1135, § 2, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § II, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1946, § I(A), 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 1998, § II, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § II(H), (Q), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § II(H), (Q), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § II(H), (Q), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-35. - Destruction of wild, old, crippled, injured or diseased animals. 
    It is the duty of animal control officers to order the destruction of any animal lawfully taken into custody that is, in the opinion of the animal control officer, by reason of old age, unfit for use, or which is infected with a dangerous or communicable disease, or which is in an incurably crippled condition, or which is adjudged by a report of a licensed veterinarian to be afflicted with any painful, incurable disease. A reasonable attempt shall be made to notify the owner, if known, prior to taking action; however, the humane destruction of a sick or injured animal may necessitate immediate action. 
(Code 1973, § 4-2(P); Ord. No. 1135, § 2, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § II, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1946, § I(A), 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 1998, § II, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § II(P), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § II(P), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § II(P), 9-11-2012) 
Secs. 8-36-8-54. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DOGS AND CATS 

Sec. 8-55. - Dogs at large prohibited; impound. 
(a)  No person owning, harboring, or caring for a dog shall allow the animal to be off the premises of its owner unless securely confined by a strong leash not to exceed six feet in length continuously held by a person capable of controlling the dog or confined to an automobile. 
(b)  It is the duty of the animal control officer and of any police officer of the city to take up all dogs found in violation of this section. When such dog is taken up by a police officer, it shall be delivered by him to the animal control officer. All such dogs shall be impounded in the city's animal control shelter. 
(Code 1973, § 4-3; Ord. No. 1135, § 3, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § III, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1946, § I, 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 1998, § III, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § III(D), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § III(D), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § III(D), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-56. - Maximum number of dogs and cats per household. 
    No person shall own or harbor more than four dogs or four cats or a combination of dogs and cats exceeding eight animals in any one location in the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 4-3; Ord. No. 1135, § 3, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § III, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1946, § I(B)-(D), 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 1998, § III, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § III(P)(1), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § III(P)(1), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § III(P)(1), 9-11-2012) 
Secs. 8-57-8-77. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RABIES MANAGEMENT 

Sec. 8-78. - Vaccination required. 
(a)  Every person owning or harboring a dog or cat in the city shall cause such dog or cat to be vaccinated for rabies with an approved rabies vaccine immediately upon procurement if the animal is over four months old and has not been vaccinated within a period of one year prior to procurement or as soon as possible after the dog or cat has attained the age of three months; provided, however, that such vaccination has been accomplished by the time it attains the age of four months. 
(b)  Every person owning or harboring in the city a dog or cat which has been vaccinated with an approved vaccine shall cause the dog or cat to be vaccinated again within a period not to exceed one year or three years, depending on the type of vaccination given to the animal. 
(Code 1973, § 4-3; Ord. No. 1135, § 3, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § III, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1946, § I, 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 1998, § III, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § III(F), (G), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § III(F), (G), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § III(F), (G), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-79. - Tags. 
(a)  Required. At the time a dog or cat is vaccinated, a vaccination tag shall be stamped with the date of vaccination and the type of vaccine used. It is the pet owner's responsibility to keep in his possession the certificate issued to him at the time of the animal's vaccination and to produce the certificate if requested by the animal control officer or police officer. 
(b)  Must be shown on demand. No person shall fail or refuse to show the animal control officer or any police officer the rabies vaccination tag for any duly vaccinated dog or cat kept or remaining within any home or upon any enclosed premises under his immediate control. The vaccination tag shall be attached to a neck collar and be worn by the animal at all times. If a tag is lost it shall be the responsibility of the owner to replace the tag as soon as possible in order to return to compliance with this section. 
(c)  Removal prohibited. No unauthorized person shall remove from any dog or cat any collar, harness or other device to which is attached a vaccination tag for the current year, or to remove such tag therefrom. 
(d)  Counterfeiting prohibited. No person shall imitate or counterfeit the tags in this chapter provided for, or shall use any imitation or counterfeit of such tag. 
(Code 1973, § 4-3; Ord. No. 1135, § 3, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § III, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1946, § I, 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 1998, § III, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § III(A), (B), (I), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § III(A), (B), (I), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § III(A), (B), (I), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-80. - Certificates. 
    Every person owning or harboring in the city any dog or cat required by this article to be vaccinated shall, at all times while such dog or cat is thus kept, harbored or had, have in his possession a certificate issued by a person licensed by the state or any other state or nation to practice veterinary medicine, which certificate shall specify that such dog or cat has been vaccinated in accordance with provisions of this chapter. At the time a dog or cat is vaccinated, a vaccination tag shall be stamped with the date of vaccination and the type of vaccine used. 
(Code 1973, § 4-3; Ord. No. 1135, § 3, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § III, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1946, § I, 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 1998, § III, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § III(H), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § III(H), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § III(H), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-81. - Report and confinement of dogs or cats suspected of rabies infection. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person having knowledge of the whereabouts of a dog or cat known to have or suspected of having rabies or has shown symptoms of rabies to fail, refuse or neglect to allow the city's police department or animal control officer, to make an inspection or examination that the animal has or does not have rabies. 
(b)  Officers or persons capturing dogs or cats suspected of having rabies shall separately confine such dog or cat, shall report the capture to a licensed veterinarian, and shall submit the animal to the examination of a veterinarian. It shall be the duty of the veterinarian to ascertain whether the dog or cat is infected with rabies. 
(c)  Such dog or cat shall not be killed, but shall be kept in confinement until further observation of such dog or cat claimed by its owner is not necessary for the determination of the presence or the absence of rabies. 
(d)  Stray or unclaimed animals quarantined under this section shall be processed as allowed by state health regulations incurring the least expense upon the residents of the city. 
(e)  Violation of the observation quarantine of a biting animal required by this section shall be grounds for seizure and confinement of the animal at a licensed veterinary facility. 
(Code 1973, § 4-3; Ord. No. 1135, § 3, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § III, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1946, § I, 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 1998, § III, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § III(J), (K), (L)(3), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § III(J), (K), (L)(3), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § III(J), (K), (L)(3), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-82. - Quarantine or destruction of other animals suspected of rabies infection. 
    If an animal is believed to have rabies or has been bitten by an animal suspected of having rabies, such animal shall, upon order of the animal control officer either be quarantined by a licensed veterinarian for the appropriate period of time or humanely euthanized. If human exposure to such an animal has occurred, the head of such animal shall be removed and submitted to the state department of health lab for rabies diagnosis. 
(Code 1973, § 4-3; Ord. No. 1135, § 3, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § III, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1946, § I, 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 1998, § III, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § III(L)(2), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § III(L)(2), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § III(L)(2), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-83. - Report and quarantine of animals who have bitten or scratched persons. 
(a)  If any animal within the corporate limits of the city shall bite or scratch any person or so injure any person so as to cause a skin abrasion, and such facts are known to the owner of such animal, such owner shall immediately give his name and address together with the animal's license tag number to the person bitten or injured; provided, however that the person so bitten or injured is over 18 years of age. If the person bitten or injured is under the age of 18 years, then such required information shall be given to a parent or guardian. In addition thereto, the owner of such animal shall immediately thereafter, and in no event later than 24 hours thereafter, notify the police department or animal control officer giving his name, animal's vaccination tag number, the name of the victim, and any other information that the police department or animal control officer may require. 
(b)  The city's police department or animal control officer shall be notified of any person bitten by an animal of a species subject to rabies, whether or not the animal is suspected of having rabies. 
(c)  If it is shown that any dog, cat, or other animal without proof of current rabies vaccination has bitten any person, no person owning or harboring the animal, upon order of the animal control officer or any police officer, shall fail, refuse, neglect to take or cause to be promptly taken, such animal to a veterinarian to be held in quarantine for a period of ten days. Such animal may not be released from quarantine without the authorization of the veterinarian in charge. The total cost of the confinement for a ten-day period shall be borne by the owner. 
(Code 1973, § 4-3; Ord. No. 1135, § 3, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § III, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1946, § I, 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 1998, § III, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § IV, 8-22-2006; Ord. No. 2081, §§ III(M), (K), (L)(1), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, §§ III(M), (K), (L)(1), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, §§ III(M), (K), (L)(1), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-84. - Wild animals not subject to quarantine; destruction authorized. 
    No wild animals will be placed in quarantine. All wild animals involved in biting incidents will be humanely euthanized in such a manner that the brain is not mutilated. The brain shall be submitted to a state department of health lab for rabies diagnosis. 
(Code 1973, § 4-3; Ord. No. 1135, § 3, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § III, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1946, § I, 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 1998, § III, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § III(L)(4), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § III(L)(4), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § III(L)(4), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-85. - Costs of confinement. 
    The total cost of the confinement period for animals that have bitten or scratched persons shall be borne by the owner of the animal unless the bite or scratch was caused by a provocation. The person responsible for the provocation or, if a minor, his parents or guardian, shall bear the expense of any quarantine, provided that the animal or its owner was not in violation of any provision of this article at the time of the attack. 
(Code 1973, § 4-3; Ord. No. 1135, § 3, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § III, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1946, § I, 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 1998, § III, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § III(L)(5), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § III(L)(5), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § III(L)(5), 9-11-2012) 
Secs. 8-86-8-113. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-114. - Animal control department and officers. 
(a)  Positions and department established. The positions of the chief animal control officer and deputy animal control officers and an animal control department have been established by the city. 
(b)  Department function; duties of officers. The animal control department shall function as a department of the city subject to guidelines and procedures adopted by the city council for its operations. Animal control officers shall enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  Compensation. The chief animal control officer and deputy animal control officer shall receive such compensation as shall be established by the city's annual fiscal budget. 
(d)  Police power of officers. The animal control officers shall be vested with the necessary police powers for the exclusive purpose of enforcing the provisions of this article, and it shall be their duty to issue citations for violations of any of the provisions of this article. They shall enforce all of the laws of the city, county, and state relating to the care, treatment and impounding of animals and to the prevention of cruelty to animals. This exercise of the police powers is under the direct supervision of the city police chief or designated representative. 
(e)  Authority to collect fees. The animal control officer shall be vested with the powers to collect fees established in this chapter, in the amounts provided in the city fee schedule. 
(f)  Interference with duty. No person shall release or attempt to release any animal mentioned herein from the possession of any animal control officer nor interfere with the chief animal control officer, or his deputies, in the performance of their official duties. 
(Code 1973, § 4-2(A)-(F); Ord. No. 1135, § 2, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § II, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1946, § I(A), 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 1998, § II, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § II(A)-(G), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § II(A)-(G), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § II(A)-(G), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-115. - Delegation of authority. 
    Whenever a power is granted to, or a duty imposed upon, the animal control officer and other public officers, the power may be exercised or the duty may be performed by a deputy of the officers or by a person authorized, pursuant to law, by the officer, unless this chapter expressly provides otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 2081, § VI, 8-22-2006; Ord. No. 2081-B, § VI, 9-8-2012; Ord. No. 2081, § VI(I), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § VI(I), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § VI(I), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-116. - Animal control shelter. 
    The city shall provide a suitable building or enclosure to keep and safely hold all animals herein enumerated which are subject to be impounded, which shall be known and designated as the animal control shelter. 
(Code 1973, § 4-2(I); Ord. No. 1135, § II(J), 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § II(I), 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1946, § I(A), 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 1998, § II, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § II(I), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § II(I), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § II(I), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-117. - Accounting for sums collected. 
    The animal control officer shall pay over to the finance director all sums collected by him pursuant to the terms of this chapter promptly as directed. All sums received by the city pursuant to the terms of this article shall be deposited into the city's general fund. 
(Code 1973, § 4-2(O); Ord. No. 1135, § 2(O), (P), 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § II(N), (O), 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1946, § I(A), 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 1998, § II(N), (O), 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § II(N), (O), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § II(N), (O), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § II(N), (O), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-118. - Penalties. 
    Any person who shall be found guilty of violating this article may be assessed a fine of not more than $1,000.00. Each day the violation occurs may be deemed a separate offense. Repeat offenses may be punished by no less than $200.00 nor more than $1,000.00. 
(Ord. No. 2081, § VI, 8-22-2006; Ord. No. 2081-B, § VI, 9-8-2012; Ord. No. 2081, § VI(H), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § VI(H), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § VI(H), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-119. - Fees and penalties constitute debt to city; civil suit for collection. 
(a)  The amount of any fee or penalty imposed by this chapter shall be defined a debt to the city and any person keeping any animal without having complied with the provisions of this chapter shall be liable to an action in the name of the city in any court of competent jurisdiction for the amount of the fees or penalties imposed and required by this article to be paid for the privilege of keeping such animal. 
(b)  It is the duty of the animal control officer to cause a civil complaint to be filed against any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter, and the city police chief shall cause an action to be brought against any person failing to pay a fee or penalty required by the provisions of this article for the recovery of the same. 
(Code 1973, § 4-6(E); Ord. No. 1135, § VI(I), 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § VI(E), 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1998, § VI(E), 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § VI(E), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § VI(E), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § VI(E), 9-11-2012) 
Secs. 8-120-8-179. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - IMPOUNDMENT 

Sec. 8-180. - Duty and authority to impound. 
    It is the duty of the animal control officer or any peace officer to take up, impound, or safely keep any animal found to be in violation of this chapter. 
(1)  Nuisance animals. Animal control officers or other law enforcement officers shall have the power to impound animals which create an animal nuisance for the purpose of abating the nuisance as follows: 
a.  On public property in all cases. 
b.  On private property, if: 
1.  The consent of the property owner or resident is obtained; 
2.  The officer reasonably believes there is immediate or imminent danger or peril to the public if the animal in question is not impounded; 
3.  Authorized by appropriate courts of law; 
4.  If property is vacant of buildings and residents to serve as a custodian for the animal; or 
5.  The animal is in violation of rabies vaccination and marking requirements. 
(2)  Unrestrained animals. Animal control officers or other law enforcement officer shall have the power to impound unrestrained animals for the purpose of abating the nuisance as follows: 
a.  On public property in all cases. 
b.  On private property with the consent of the property owner or resident. 
c.  On private property when in pursuit of an animal which he believes is subject to impoundment under the provisions of this chapter. 
d.  When authorized by an appropriate court of law. 
e.  On private property, if property is vacant of buildings and residents to serve as a custodian for the animal. 
(Code 1973, § 4-2(J); Ord. No. 1135, § 2(H), (K), 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § II(H), (J), 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1946, § I(A), 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 1998, § II(H), (J), 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § II, 8-22-2006; Ord. No. 2081-B, § II, 9-8-2012; Ord. No. 2081, § II(J), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § II(J), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § II(J), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-181. - Care of impounded animals. 
    It shall be the duty of the animal control officer to provide impounded animals with adequate food, water, and shelter for the period of their impoundment. 
(Code 1973, § 4-2(K); Ord. No. 1135, § 2(L), 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § II(K), 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1946, § I(A), 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 1998, § II(K), 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § II(K), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § II(K), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § II(K), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-182. - Redemption and other disposition of impounded animals. 
(a)  Livestock. After giving five days' notice in the newspaper, the animal control officer may sell at public stockyards any impounded livestock. At any time prior to sale, the owner or his agent may redeem the animal by paying an impounding fee and a per day boarding fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule, together with all advertising and other costs, if any incurred by the city. All money received by virtue of sale of such animals under this section shall be delivered to the city finance director for deposit to the city's general fund. Livestock not sold or redeemed pursuant to this subsection may be disposed of by the animal control officer or police chief in whatever manner is in the best interest of the city. 
(b)  Other animals. Redemption of animals other than livestock shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  The animal owner may redeem an impounded dog or cat within three working days of impoundment. If not redeemed in that period, the animal shall be held for an additional two working days for possible sale to the public or transfer to a pet adoption program. 
(2)  The animal control officer shall make every attempt within reason to notify the owner of an animal immediately after impounding at his last known residence, either by mail, telephone, or personal contact. 
(3)  The owner of an impounded animal may reclaim the animal at any time prior to final disposition of the animal in advance of payment of all impound and boarding fees, in the amount provided in the city fee schedule, and any applicable veterinary fees. 
(4)  If the animal is required to be vaccinated for rabies, proof of rabies vaccination shall also be required. If an animal is impounded and is not current for rabies vaccination, the animal control officer may take the animal to a licensed veterinarian for rabies vaccination prior to release to its owner. 
(Code 1973, §§ 4-2(L), 4-4(F); Ord. No. 1135, §§ 2(L), 4(Q), 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, §§ II(L), IV(P), 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1946, § I(A), (F), (G), 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 1998, §§ II(L), IV(P), 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § IV, 8-22-2006; Ord. No. 2081, §§ II(L), III(O), IV(E), (F), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, §§ II(L), III(O), IV(E), (F), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, §§ II(L), III(O), IV(E), (F), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-183. - Owner subject to penalties for chapter violation. 
    The owner of any animal impounded remains subject to prosecution for violation of this chapter regardless of whether the animal is reclaimed. 
(Code 1973, § 4-6(K); Ord. No. 1135, § 6, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § VI, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1998, § VI, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § VI(K), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § VI(K), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § VI(K), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-184. - Unauthorized released of impounded animals prohibited. 
    It is unlawful to release by any method, without proper authorization, any animal impounded by the city. 
(Code 1973, § 4-6(J); Ord. No. 1135, § 6, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § VI, 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1998, § VI, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § VI(I), (J), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § VI(I), (J), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § VI(I), (J), 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 8-185. - Pet adoption programs. 
    The city encourages and supports development of pet adoption programs by organizations within the community, and will cooperatively work with such organizations to encourage responsible pet adoption. 
(Code 1973, § 4-3; Ord. No. 1135, § 3, 9-11-1973; Ord. No. 1621, § III(J), 2-14-1989; Ord. No. 1946, § I, 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 1998, § III(O), 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 2081, § III(O), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-A, § III(O), 7-24-2012; Ord. No. 2081-B, § III(O), 9-11-2012) 
Chapter 10 - BUILDINGS AND CONSTRUCTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- For provisions regarding vehicle storage facilities, see section 52-241. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Building and technical codes adopted. 
(a)  The following codes are hereby adopted by reference as though they were copied herein fully: 
(1)  2015 International Building Code. 
(2)  2015 International Residential Code for One- and Two-Family Dwellings. 
(3)  2015 International Plumbing Code. 
(4)  2015 International Mechanical Code. 
(5)  2015 International Energy Conservation Code. 
(6)  2015 International Existing Building Code. 
(7)  2015 International Property Maintenance Code. 
(8)  2015 International Fuel Gas Code. 
(9)  2014 National Electrical Code. 
(10)  2014 Life Safety Code, 101. 
(b)  Wherever the term "municipality" is used in any building or technical code adopted by reference in this chapter, it shall be held to mean this city. Wherever the term "corporation counsel" is used in any building or technical code adopted by reference in this chapter, it shall be held to mean the attorney for the city. 
(c)  The building official or his designated representative is responsible for the enforcement of this chapter, including the adopted codes. 
(Code 1973, §§ 5-21, 5-22; Ord. No. 886, §§ I, VI, 3-12-1968; Ord. No. 2025, § 1, 3-9-2004; Ord. No. 2181, 1-11-2011) 
Editor's note- See section 20-50 for fire code adopted by the city. 
Sec. 10-2. - Permit fees. 
(a)  No permit as required by the building code adopted in section 10-1 shall be issued until a fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule has been paid, nor shall an amendment to a permit be approved until the additional fee, if any, due to an increase in the estimated cost of the building or structure, is paid. 
(b)  In case of abandonment or discontinuance, the cost of work performed under a permit may be estimated, an adjustment of the fee made and the portion of the fee for uncompleted work returned to the permit holder; provided, no refund of a prescribed minimum fee shall be made. If such discontinuance is due to revocation of permit, a similar adjustment and return may be made; provided, no refund shall be made until all penalties incurred or imposed by due authority have been collected. After such a refund has been made, no work shall be resumed until a new application has been made and a new permit has been issued. 
(c)  The term "estimated cost," as used in this section, means the reasonable value of all services, labor, materials and use of scaffolding and other appliances or devices entering into and necessary to the prosecution and completion of the work ready for occupancy; provided, the cost of excavation or grading, and of painting, decorating or other work that is merely for embellishment or not necessary for the safe and lawful use of the building or structure, is not deemed a part of such estimated cost. 
(Code 1973, § 5-23; Ord. No. 886, § VII, 3-12-1968) 
Sec. 10-3. - Building inspector. 
(a)  Office created; appointment and removal; acting officer. The office of building inspector is hereby created, and the executive inspector in charge shall be known as the building inspector. The building inspector shall be appointed by the city manager. His appointment shall continue during good behavior and satisfactory service. He shall not be removed from office except for cause. During temporary absence or disability of the building inspector, the appointing authority shall designate an acting building inspector.
