(b)  Duties generally. The building inspector shall devote his whole time to the duties of his office. He shall receive applications required by the building code, issue permits and furnish the prescribed certificates. He shall examine premises for which permits have been issued and shall make necessary inspections to see that the provisions of law are complied with and that construction is prosecuted safely. He shall enforce all provisions of the building code. He shall, when requested by proper authority, or when the public interest so requires, make investigations in connection with matters referred to in the building code and render written reports on the same. To enforce compliance with law, to remove illegal or unsafe conditions, to secure the necessary safeguards during construction, or to require adequate exit facilities in buildings and structures, he shall issue such notices or orders as may be necessary. 
(c)  Inspections. Inspections required under the provisions of the building code shall be made by the building inspector or his duly appointed assistant. The building inspector may accept reports of inspectors of recognized inspection services, after investigation of their qualifications and reliability. No certificate called for by a provision of the building code shall be issued on such reports unless the same are in writing and certified by a responsible officer of such service. 
(d)  Recordkeeping. The building inspector shall keep comprehensive records of applications, permits issued, certificates issued, inspections made, reports rendered and notices or orders issued. He shall retain on file copies of required plans and all documents relating to building work so long as any part of the building or structure to which they relate may be in existence. All such records shall be open to public inspection for good and sufficient reasons at the stated office hours, but shall not be removed from the office of the building inspector without his written consent. 
(e)  Periodic reports. The building inspector shall make written reports to his immediate superior once each month, or more often if requested, including statements of permits and certificates issued and orders promulgated. 
(f)  Cooperation with other officials. The building inspector may request and shall receive insofar as may be necessary, in the discharge of his duties, the assistance and cooperation of other officials of the city. 
(g)  Right of entry. The building inspector in the discharge of his official duties, and upon proper identification, shall have authority to enter any building, structure or premises at any reasonable hour. 
(Code 1973, §§ 5-1-5-4; Ord. No. 886, §§ II-V, 3-12-1968) 
Secs. 10-4-10-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADDITIONAL ELECTRICAL STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-25. - General. 
    Due to the extreme climatic conditions prevailing in and about the city, certain special rules covering electrical wiring and equipment installations are set forth herein, and certain exceptions are taken to the rules and regulations of the National Electrical Code to raise the safety level of electrical installations and prevent the rapid deterioration of electrical materials and equipment from severe atmospheric and underground corrosive action. 
(Code 1973, § 5-99; Ord. No. 1118, art. IX, § 1, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-26. - Branch circuits. 
(a)  In residences with more than 500 square feet of floor space, receptacles will be required as outlined in the National Electrical Code. 
(b)  In determining outlets per circuit, the National Electrical Code shall be complied with, except that no circuits shall be permitted with more than seven outlets in residential wiring. In commercial wiring, not more than four receptacles shall be permitted on one circuit or six incandescent fixtures. Fixed lighting on a circuit shall be determined according to the load. Receptacles, incandescent fixtures and fixed lighting on individual circuits as herein regulated shall not exceed 80 percent of the circuit load. No wire less than No. 12 shall be used, except on low voltage circuits and No. 14 wire may be used on switch legs up to five amps. If aluminum wire is used it must be one size larger than copper. A separate circuit is to be used for each of the following: Attic fan, dishwasher, automatic washing machine, clothes dryer and room air conditioning units. In the working area of the kitchen there shall be one duplex receptacle only, on each circuit. 
(c)  All service and branch circuit overcurrent protective devices rated at 30 amperes or less, are to be equipped with nontamperable overcurrent protective devices which are definite and cannot be changed from one rating to another. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to bridge, tamper with, or change from its original installation, except upon the approval of the chief electrical inspector, and then only after proper permit for alteration has been issued, any fuse of the plug, cartridge type or link type, installed in panel boards, main switches or switchboards, or to alter or change circuit breakers so that the original calibration will be affected, or to tie down or secure any circuit breaker so that it will not function properly. 
(e)  The minimum size service switch shall not be less than 60 amperes for buildings having more than two circuits. Buildings with less than three circuits may use a 30 ampere disconnect. Residences over 500 square feet shall have 100 amperes service or larger. All disconnects or service switches shall be of the weatherproof type. 
(f)  All mobile homes shall have a main service of not less than 100 amperes. 
(Code 1973, § 5-101; Ord. No. 1118, art. IX, § 3, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-27. - Extension cords. 
    Extension cords shall be no longer than eight feet except those used for portable tools and trouble lights. 
(Code 1973, § 5-102; Ord. No. 1118, art. IX, § 4, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-28. - Electric fences prohibited. 
    The installation and use of any type of electric fence is prohibited within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 5-103; Ord. No. 1118, art. IX, § 5, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-29. - Motor and starters. 
(a)  All motors of more than five horsepower rating shall be three-phase. 
(b)  All motors with a rated capacity of ten horsepower or more shall be equipped for reduced voltage starting and shall have low voltage release attachment, the details of the controlling equipment to be approved by the electrical inspector before such motors are connected. 
(Code 1973, § 5-104; Ord. No. 1118, art. IX, § 6, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-30. - Utility company rules. 
    Rules and regulations of the central power and light company regarding service and meter installations for the kind and character of service to be rendered as passed and approved by the city council from time to time, in accordance with franchise provisions, are hereby referred to, incorporated herein, and made a part hereof. 
(Code 1973, § 5-105; Ord. No. 1118, art. IX, § 7, 5-8-1973) 
Secs. 10-31-10-48. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 10-49. - General. 
    The administration and enforcement of this article is hereby assigned to and shall be the responsibility of the city electrical inspector under the supervision of the building official. 
(Code 1973, § 5-38; Ord. No. 1118, art. III, § 1, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-50. - Duties of electrical inspector. 
    The electrical inspector shall have the following duties: 
(1)  He shall enforce the provisions of this chapter; he shall delegate any powers of inspection to his subordinates which he deems advisable; 
(2)  He shall collect, or have collected, all fees as provided herein and transmit the same to the proper city officials; 
(3)  He shall, upon application, grant permits for the installation, extension, or alteration of electrical work as provided in this chapter; 
(4)  He shall make inspections of all work as provided in this chapter; 
(5)  He shall keep complete records of all permits issued, inspections and reinspections made, and other official work performed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 5-39; Ord. No. 1118, art. III, § 2, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-51. - Authority of the electrical inspector. 
(a)  Whenever an electrical inspector shall call upon the police department for aid and assistance in making an arrest or stopping work, it shall be the duty of the police department to act immediately in giving the required assistance. 
(b)  Electrical inspectors shall have the right, with the property owner's consent, to enter any building or premises in the discharge of their official duties, or for the purpose of making any inspection, reinspection, or test of electrical wiring, devices and equipment. 
(c)  Each electrical inspector shall have the power to inspect and reinspect electrical wiring, devices, and equipment, to prevent the connection of same from a source of electrical energy where such electrical wiring, devices, equipment and electrical energy source have not been approved, to issue notices or affix them to structures, and to condemn electrical wiring, and shall have such other powers as are provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 5-40; Ord. No. 1118, art. III, § 3, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-52. - Service of notice. 
    When any order or notice is issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter to any person who cannot be found after reasonable search, then such order or notice may be served by posting it in a conspicuous place upon the premises occupied by him, or upon the premises where the defects are alleged to exist. Such posting of the order or notice shall be considered equivalent to personal service of such order or notice. An order or notice sent by mail in a sealed envelope with postage prepaid, and directed to the address of the electrical contractor, owner, lessee, or occupant of the premises shall be equivalent to personal service of such order or notice. 
(Code 1973, § 5-41; Ord. No. 1118, art. III, § 4, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-53. - Suspension or revocation of rights. 
    The building official shall have the power to suspend or revoke the annual certificate of registration issued by the city of any electrician who is found guilty of: 
(1)  Practice of any fraud or deceit in obtaining such annual certificate of registration. 
(2)  Taking out electrical permits in the name of some person authorized by law to do electrical work and thereafter permitting a person without a proper certificate to do the work. 
(3)  Any gross negligence, incompetence, or misconduct in the performance of electrical work within the jurisdiction of the city under this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 5-53; Ord. No. 1118, art. IV, § 11, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-54. - Appeal. 
(a)  Any applicant that is refused a certificate of registration, or whose certificate of registration may have been revoked, may appeal to the board of appeals from examinations for a review of his case. If an applicant is dissatisfied with the decision of the board of appeals he shall have the right of final appeal to the city council whose judgment as to all matters involved shall be final. 
(b)  Every electrical contractor must submit to the city electrical department an address or telephone number where the electrical department may leave messages for the electrical contractor. 
(Code 1973, § 5-54; Ord. No. 1118, art. IV, § 12, 5-8-1973) 
Secs. 10-55-10-81. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - QUALIFICATIONS AND REGISTRATION OF ELECTRICIANS 

Sec. 10-82. - Registration required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of installing, maintaining, altering or repairing any wiring, fixture, or equipment used for the conducting of electricity for which a permit is required by this chapter, nor shall any person in any manner undertake to execute such work unless such person is licensed by the state department of licensing and registration as an electrical contractor. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely represent himself as a registered electrician of any class set forth in this chapter or to use the words "electrical contractor," or words of similar import or meaning, on signs, cards, stationery, or by any other manner whatsoever, unless the person is properly registered within the meaning of this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 5-56; Ord. No. 1118, art. V, § 1, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-83. - Fees for examination or registration. 
(a)  The fees covering the examination for a certificate of registration to qualified electricians of all classes shall be in the amount provided in the city fee schedule and payable to the city at the office of the electrical inspector. The examination fee shall accompany the application for registration. 
(b)  The registration fee shall be paid to the electrical inspector before the issuance of a certificate of registration and only after the person has been approved by the examining board dealing with the registrant's classification. 
(c)  Annual renewal of a certificate of registration shall be accomplished by issuance of a certified receipt signed by the electrical inspector issued upon payment each year extending the validity of correspondingly numbered certificates for that year only. The holder of the certificate shall affix and display each yearly receipt upon the face of his certificate in the designated space. He shall remove and destroy any previously issued receipt. 
(d)  Annual renewal of a registration card shall be required as herein. 
(e)  Fees for this section shall be as provided by the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1973, § 5-66; Ord. No. 1118, art. V, § 11, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-84. - Insurance for electrical contractor and electricians. 
    All electrical contractors and electricians certified under this chapter shall be required to furnish and to keep in force each year during the life of his certificate of registration a certificate of insurance as required by the applicable state department of licensing and regulations. The insurance policy shall be conditioned that the holder thereof will indemnify and hold the city harmless against all cost, expenses, damages, and injuries sustained by the city by reason of the carelessness or neglect of the person in operating under this chapter. All such insurance policies shall be approved by the city attorney as to form and shall be filed with the city secretary. 
(Code 1973, § 5-67; Ord. No. 1118, art. V, § 12, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-85. - Display or evidence of registration. 
    Every holder of a registration card shall carry his registration card on his person at all times while doing electrical work and shall produce and exhibit it when requested by any electrical inspector or proper official of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 5-74; Ord. No. 1118, art. V, § 19, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-86. - Revocation. 
    Conviction under the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed just cause for the revocation of any certificate which the person may have or hold under the provisions of this chapter, and examination for reissue of such certificate shall be at the discretion of the examining board of qualified electricians, but in no event shall be delayed longer than a period of one year. 
(Code 1973, § 5-107; Ord. No. 1118, art. X, § 2, 5-8-1973) 
Secs. 10-87-10-115. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PERMITS AND FEES 

Sec. 10-116. - Permits required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install or cause to be installed, or to permit any person to install, any electrical wiring, fixture, or equipment or to make any alteration, addition, change, or repair within the scope of this chapter, without first having procured a permit therefor issued by the electrical inspector, except as provided herein. There shall be one permit for each building for which rough work for electrical conductors, or electrical equipment is installed. Accessory buildings, tourist cottages, or group houses shall not be considered separate buildings when the work is to be installed as one complete project, and at one time, except where separate switches or meter loops are installed thereon. 
(Code 1973, § 5-75; Ord. No. 1118, art. VI, § 1, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-117. - Permit fees. 
(a)  Before proceeding with the installation, alteration of, or the addition to any electrical wiring or equipment within or on any building, structure, or premises, publicly or privately owned, within the city limits, the electrical contractor in charge of such proposed work shall first file with the electrical inspector an application requesting permit and pay fees to the city in accordance with the city fee schedule, to secure a permit to carry on such work. 
(b)  Permit applications covering the installation of motors on any job shall specify each motor individually and no grouping of motors per machine, or other such grouping of horsepower, shall be permitted, except package machines may be wired as one group. 
(c)  Permit fees. Fees for inspection of all electrical work and appliances shall be made and collected upon and in accordance with the amounts provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1973, § 5-76; Ord. No. 1118, art. VI, § 2, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-118. - Application for permit. 
(a)  Application for permits shall be made in writing upon forms provided by the electrical inspector for that purpose. With such application there shall be filed a diagram or plan showing clearly the character and kind of wiring or installation of fixtures or equipment work to be done. The plan or diagram shall show the manner in which the electrical installation is to be made, or the character of any repairs to any existing electrical installation. The application shall include the street and house number, name of owner, kind of building and a list of electrical fixtures and appliances to be installed. 
(b)  The diagram or plans and application shall be referred to the electrical inspector, who shall have the authority to issue or refuse to issue a permit. No electrical permit on new construction shall be granted prior to the granting of a building permit. Issuance of an electrical permit in error shall not waive compliance with this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 5-77; Ord. No. 1118, art. VI, § 3, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-119. - Permits for part jobs. 
    When one electrical contractor completes the rough work, in whole or in part, on any electrical wiring or installation of fixtures or equipment, and a second electrical contractor is called upon to complete the work, in whole or in part, then, in that event, a separate permit is required, for which minimum fees shall be paid for the work to be done. Each electrical contractor shall be held responsible only for the work installed by him. Before the second electrical contractor is issued a permit for the completion of an electrical wiring or installation of fixtures or equipment job, the electrical inspector shall first notify the electrical contractor holding the original or first permit, if he can be found, that the second permit is to be issued. The issuance of the second permit shall cancel the first permit and no refund of fees shall be made. 
(Code 1973, § 5-78; Ord. No. 1118, art. VI, § 4, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-120. - To whom permits issued. 
    Permits shall be issued to electrical contractors qualified to secure permits as set forth in this chapter, or to their duly authorized agent. Qualified electrical contractors shall certify their duly authorized agent to the electrical inspector in the form of an affidavit stating that the electrical contractor assumes all and full responsibility for any permit taken out or applied for by the agent. This certification shall be kept in the electrical inspector's file after it has been approved by the city attorney. Permits for the construction or erection and connecting of gaseous tubing or electric signs may be issued to qualified electrical sign contractors. 
(Code 1973, § 5-79; Ord. No. 1118, art. VI, § 5, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-121. - Time limitation of permits. 
    If electrical wiring or installation of fixtures or equipment work authorized under a permit is not started within 60 days after issuance of such permit, or if the work is started and then discontinued and the work remains discontinued without justifiable cause for a period of 60 days, the permit becomes void, and no work shall be done on the premises until a new permit is issued and all necessary fees paid. No refunds shall be made for permits that may become void. 
(Code 1973, § 5-80; Ord. No. 1118, art. VI, § 6, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-122. - Revocation of permits. 
    The electrical inspector shall have the right to declare a permit null and void if there has been misrepresentation of facts or any violation of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 5-81; Ord. No. 1118, art. VI, § 7, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-123. - Personal home wiring permits. 
(a)  Any person shall be permitted to do electrical work on such property owned by him and used by him as a home and shall not be required to obtain a permit through an electrical contractor, but shall have the right to apply in person for such permit without being qualified as an electrician. 
(b)  The exception mentioned in subsection (a) of this section shall not relieve any person attempting to perform work or do certain acts described above from applying in person for a permit prior to the beginning of work; and further, all work described above shall at all times be subject to the inspection and approval by the electrical inspector in accordance with the terms of all valid city ordinances, laws, rules, and regulations; and further, such persons shall comply with the ordinances, laws, rules, and regulations as to the types of material, quantity, and quality thereof as required by all inspections. 
(c)  Any person mentioned above shall be required to pay the same permit and inspection fees as shall be required of any other person under the electrical code and building code of the city; provided, however, that no person may exercise the exception mentioned above save and except on his own premises as was mentioned above. 
(Code 1973, § 5-82; Ord. No. 1118, art. VI, § 8, 5-8-1973) 
Secs. 10-124-10-144. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - INSPECTIONS 

Sec. 10-145. - Inspections required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make connections from a source of electrical energy to any electrical wiring, device, or equipment on an installation for which a permit is required, as set forth in this chapter, until a certificate of approval has been issued by the electrical inspector authorizing such connection and the use of such wiring, device, or equipment. 
(Code 1973, § 5-83; Ord. No. 1118, art. VII, § 1, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-146. - Rough inspection. 
(a)  When the rough wiring or installation work is completed on any premises, the person responsible therefor shall notify the electrical inspector that the job is ready for inspection, giving proper identification of the work, address, and permit number. The electrical inspector shall then make an inspection of the electrical installation within 48 hours from the time of notification (exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays). 
(b)  If the wiring or installation work has been installed in accordance with the terms and provisions of this chapter, the electrical inspector shall sign the inspection card, noting thereon the date of approval of the work. More than one rough inspection may be made without charge when the progress of construction requires such inspection. 
(c)  Faulty work. If the electric wiring or installation of fixtures or equipment is found to be faulty or incorrectly or defectively installed, the electrical inspector shall notify the responsible person who installed such work of the changes necessary to be made in order that the work may conform to this chapter. 
(d)  Rectification of faulty work. The electrical contractor shall make or start to make the changes ordered immediately and shall proceed with the work until the same is completed. Upon completion thereof and payment of the reinspection fee, he shall notify the electrical inspector that such faulty work has been corrected. The latter shall then cause the reinspection to be made, and if the work has been found to comply with this chapter he shall sign the inspection card, noting thereon the date of approval of the work. If the electrical inspector shall again find the work incorrectly installed, he shall notify the responsible electrical contractor of the necessary changes, and shall collect an additional reinspection fee. If the responsible electrical contractor does not make the required change within a reasonable time, the electrical inspector shall refuse to issue to any such person any further permits until the work in question is corrected and approved. 
(Code 1973, § 5-84; Ord. No. 1118, art. VII, § 2, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-147. - Final inspection. 
    Upon the completion of all electrical wiring or installation of fixtures or equipment in any building or on any premises, the electrician in charge shall notify the electrical inspector that the work is ready for final inspection, giving the electrical permit number and street address, and the electrical inspector shall then cause inspection to be made within 48 hours from the time of receipt of notification (exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays), and if any faulty or defective wiring or equipment is found, the electrician in charge shall be notified of the changes to be made in order that such work shall conform to this chapter. If such work is found to be correctly installed, replaced or repaired, the electrical inspector shall endorse his approval upon the inspection certificate stating that the wiring or installation work has been installed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. For each and every final inspection requested by the electrical contractor s in charge of a job, after the first has been made, the final inspection fee shall be paid as hereinbefore provided. 
(Code 1973, § 5-85; Ord. No. 1118, art. VII, § 3, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-148. - Work left open. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cover or cause to be covered any part of a wiring installation with flooring, lath, wallboard, or other material, until the electrical inspector shall have approved the wiring installation, in part or as a whole, except as herein set forth. 
(Code 1973, § 5-86; Ord. No. 1118, art. VII, § 4, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-149. - Inspector's removal request. 
    It shall be the duty of the electrical inspector to cause all abandoned dead wire or equipment inside or on the outside of a building, unused poles, or electrical apparatus on the outside of the buildings or in streets or alleys to be removed at the expense of the owners thereof, by giving the owners written notice. 
(Code 1973, § 5-87; Ord. No. 1118, art. VII, § 5, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-150. - Interference. 
    It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to, in any manner, change or alter electrical conductors or equipment in or on any building. If, in the course of the erection of a building or structure, electrical conductors or equipment have previously been installed in such position as to interfere with the erection or completion of the structure, notice shall be immediately given to the authorized person using the electrical conductors or equipment, and he shall be required to accomplish this needed change in accordance with this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 5-88; Ord. No. 1118, art. VII, § 6, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-151. - Periodic general inspection. 
    The electrical inspector shall inaugurate thorough periodic reinspection of installation of all electric wiring, electric devices, electric equipment, including radio towers, antennas, transmission towers, and electrical roof signs, now installed or that may hereafter be installed within the city, and within the scope of this chapter, and when the installation of any such wiring, device, or equipment is found to be defective, dangerous, or in an unsafe condition, the person owning, using or operating the wiring, device, or equipment shall make the necessary repairs or changes required to place such wiring, device, or equipment in a safe condition, within five days or any longer period specified by the electrical inspector in the notice. The electrical inspector shall immediately order the disconnection or discontinuance of electrical service to such wiring, device, or equipment until it has been made safe, as directed. When old buildings are remodeled, all wiring shall be in conformity with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 5-89; Ord. No. 1118, art. VII, § 7, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-152. - Proper supervision. 
(a)  In the actual work of installing, maintaining, altering, or repairing any electrical wiring device or equipment for which a permit is required by this chapter, there shall be present and in direct supervision a qualified electrician of the proper classification or registration. 
(b)  In erecting a sign for which a building permit and an electrical permit have been issued, the registered electrical sign contractor shall direct supervision until such time as the sign is ready to be connected to a source of power. Connecting the sign to a source of power will be done by an electrical contractor, or a journeyman electrician operating under a licensed electrical contractor. 
(Code 1973, § 5-90; Ord. No. 1118, art. VII, § 8, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-153. - Electrical service connection. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make connections from a source of electric energy to any electrical wiring, device, or equipment which has been disconnected by order of the electrical inspector, or the use of which has been prohibited for reasons herein set forth, until a certificate of approval has been issued by him authorizing the reconnection and use of such wiring, device, or equipment. Whenever the service wires are once disconnected in any commercial building in the city limits or any building in the fire limits, the service shall not again be connected until the same has been wired so as to conform to this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 5-91; Ord. No. 1118, art. VII, § 9, 5-8-1973) 
Secs. 10-154-10-174. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - TELEVISION ANTENNA REGULATIONS 

Sec. 10-175. - Lightning protection. 
(a)  An approved lightning arrestor should be placed in each conductor of a ribbon-type lead-in. 
(b)  An antenna system using coaxial cable is suitably protected against lightning by effectively grounding the outside metal shield. 
(c)  Metal masts must be effectively grounded. 
(d)  Ground wires used in lightning protection systems should be No. 6 Copper A.W.G. 
(e)  Ground clamps must be of the "approved" type. 
(f)  Lightning arrestors must be located outside the building at the point of entrance of the downlead into the building and away from highly combustible materials. 
(Code 1973, § 5-93; Ord. No. 1118, art. VIII, § 2, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-176. - Clearance. 
(a)  An antenna system must have a full clearance of eight feet from other antennas on flat roofs. An antenna system must be eight feet above all points on a flat roof. 
(b)  An antenna system must not cross a public way or above or below light, power, and communication lines. 
(c)  Downleads must be separated by at least two feet from power lines with potential up to 250 volts, ten feet from lines with potentials higher than 250 volts, and six feet from lightning rod systems. 
(d)  Location of the antenna system must be such that sagging, swinging, or collapse of the antenna will not result in contact with light, power, or communication lines. 
(Code 1973, § 5-94; Ord. No. 1118, art. VIII, § 3, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-177. - Strength of structures. 
(a)  Anchor screws or lead expansion shields must be used in masonry at anchor points of mast and guy wire supports. 
(b)  Support insulators for downleads must be spaced at least every ten feet, or the leads may be securely taped to the mast. 
(c)  Guy wires must be at least 3/32 inch, five strand cable, galvanized steel. 
(d)  Antenna systems must be adequately supported to withstand extreme conditions of wind. 
(e)  Chimneys must be in good condition and have at least a two square foot cross section to be suitable as a mast support. 
(f)  Masts should not extend above eight feet from the top of a chimney unless properly guyed. 
(g)  All antennas, except those of the self-supporting type, with masts ten feet or higher shall be guyed at one level of the mast. Masts from 20 to 50 feet high should be guyed at two levels. 
(h)  Antenna supports on frame structures must be fastened to rafters or beams. 
(Code 1973, § 5-95; Ord. No. 1118, art. VIII, § 4, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-178. - Resistance to corrosion. 
    Mast and miscellaneous hardware should be noncorrosive. 
(Code 1973, § 5-96; Ord. No. 1118, art. VIII, § 5, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-179. - Quality of materials. 
    The materials entering into the construction of the antenna system shall be of a quality that meets the standards of recognized testing laboratories such as Underwriters Laboratories. 
(Code 1973, § 5-97; Ord. No. 1118, art. VIII, § 6, 5-8-1973) 
Sec. 10-180. - Prohibited areas and supports. 
(a)  Attachment of any part of the antenna system to light, power, or communication structures or poles is prohibited. 
(b)  No antenna shall be mounted on fire escapes or fire towers. 
(Code 1973, § 5-98; Ord. No. 1118, art. VIII, § 7, 5-8-1973) 
Secs. 10-181-10-198. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FENCES 

Sec. 10-199. - Issuance of permit. 
    No fence shall be constructed in the city without first obtaining a building permit in the manner provided in this chapter. The application for permit shall include a description of the proposed location, height and construction materials and the anticipated time for project completion and shall be accompanied by a permit fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Ord. No. 2090, § 2, 2-13-2007) 
Sec. 10-200. - Regulations. 
(a)  With the exceptions only approved by the city's board of adjustment following due process, the only materials acceptable for fencing in all neighborhoods shall be limited to: 
Chain link Woven wire fence Split rail Rough posts split to form horizontal fence Board on board Wood frame fence Picket Narrow vertical wooden fence Decorative iron Ornamental iron sections PVC panels Ornamental man-made material fence Stucco Cement plaster Block tile Concrete block Shrub Vegetation Brick (Self-explanatory)  
(b)  Fences in neighborhoods shall not exceed eight feet in height, in rear and side yards as established by a structure in compliance with the set building code setbacks or only beyond the zoning ordinance building lines pursuant to the individual zones on a vacant parcel 
(c)  Fences in neighborhoods shall not exceed 48 inches in height in front yards or beyond the setback building lines for the particular property zone with the exception of corner lots addressed in section 46-1 to prevent obscured traffic intersections. 
(d)  Fences for front yards as permitted hereto shall be at least 75 percent open space for passage of light and air. 
(e)  Fences extending across the back and side yards shall be at least five percent open space of light and air. 
(f)  Gate access will be required for egress and ingress. 
(g)  Fences surrounding swimming pools within the city must adhere to fencing regulations established by article V of this chapter. 
(h)  Fences required whenever a zone change is granted for a business, commercial use, or for multiple dwelling in a residential zone shall adhere to specific fencing regulations established by section 56-122. 
(i)  Double fencing means two or more fences constructed more or less parallel to each other, and where there is less than a 30-inch clear and accessible separation between the fences at any point. The term "clear and accessible" refers to the area between two or more fences which must be accessible to lawn mowers up to 24 inches wide in order to keep the area free and clear of grass, weeds, and unsightly debris. 
(j)  The fence permit is good for a 60-day period and may be extended for an additional 30 days only if the building inspector finds circumstances warranting such extension. 
(k)  Fences prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or cause to be constructed electrified fences or fences containing barbed wire within the city. Exception: Property within the city still undeveloped and used for agricultural purposes or qualified for agricultural tax exceptions may retain barbed wire fencing until that time that development for single-family, multiple-family or light commercial use takes place on the property or adjacent to the property at which time perimeter fencing for the developed area shall comply with the regulations herein established. 
(Ord. No. 2090, § 3, 2-13-2007; Ord. No. 2101, § 1, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 10-201. - Appeal procedure. 
    Applicants aggrieved by the decision of the building inspector to deny a fence permit, by his application of the regulations herein adopted, may file an appropriate appeal procedure of the denial within 30 days from the date the fencing permit is denied to the city's board of adjustment for final determination, during which time all fence construction shall cease. 
(Ord. No. 2090, § 4, 2-13-2007) 
Secs. 10-202-10-225. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MOVING BUILDINGS 

Sec. 10-226. - Permit required. 
    No person shall move or transport any house or building from one location to another within the city, or move a house or building from without the city to a location within the city, or to move a house or building within the city to a point outside the city, or to move a house or building through the city, without first securing a permit therefor as required by this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 5-6; Ord. No. 764, § 1, 9-14-1965) 
Sec. 10-227. - Permit application, bond. 
(a)  Written application for a permit to move a house or building shall be signed by the applicant, and shall state the location of the house or building to be moved and the lot and block where it is to be placed after it is moved if it is to be placed in the city, and the destination if it is to be moved to a place outside the city, and the streets over which same is proposed to be moved and the time desired within which to move it. The application shall be submitted to the building inspector. 
(b)  If the building inspector or someone under his direction shall determine that such house or building may be moved in safety and in full compliance with applicable provisions of this chapter, he shall issue a permit to the applicant upon the payment by the applicant of a fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule to cover the costs of investigating the application and of issuing the permit, which fee shall be deposited in the general funds of the city. 
(c)  The building inspector shall also require the applicant to deposit a bond in the sum of $5,000.00 before he issues any permit to move the house or building over the streets of the city. This bond shall be signed by the applicant and two or more good and sufficient sureties or by the applicant and a surety company authorized to make surety bonds in this state, the bond being conditioned to indemnify all persons and the city for any damage, loss or reasonable and necessary expenses caused to or incurred by any persons or the city as a result of the moving of any house or building, and such bond shall be for the use and benefit of all persons, including the city, who suffer any damage or loss to property or person, or incur any reasonable and necessary expenses by reason of the moving of such house or building; provided, if any person making application for such permit desires to deposit a cash bond in the above mentioned amount instead of a surety bond, he may do so. In the event the applicant is in the house moving business and contemplates moving more than one house or building in the period of one year, he may make a blanket bond in the sum of $5,000.00, conditioned as stated but covering all buildings and houses for which he may obtain permits during the year, and such bond shall be in force for a period of one year and it shall apply to all houses and buildings that may be moved by the applicant during such year. All such bonds shall be approved by the city attorney and shall be filed with the building inspector. 
(Code 1973, § 5-7; Ord. No. 764, § 2, 9-14-1965) 
Sec. 10-228. - Route, notice to utility companies. 
(a)  The chief of police, or someone under his control, shall at the time a permit to move a house or building is issued by the building inspector indicate the route to be followed by the applicant in moving the house or building, which route must be followed by the applicant. 
(b)  When such route has been indicated, and the permit issued, it shall be the duty of the person moving the house or building to give immediate notice of the move to all companies maintaining overhead wires across or along any street or alley included in the designated route along which such house or building is to be moved. The companies shall be told the time the move is to be undertaken and when it will be necessary to raise or cut such wires. The house mover shall arrange with the companies for the payment of all charges for moving, cutting or repairing wires, cables or poles or for other services rendered. 
(c)  After receiving such notice, it shall be the duty of the companies maintaining the wires to furnish one or more employees to cut, raise or move such wires in order to permit the house or building to be moved along the designated route. 
(d)  The house movers shall under no conditions nor under any consideration cut, raise or move any wire found across or along any street or alley and shall not remove the same from any post or support or damage the same in moving such house or building, but shall stop all operations in the moving of the house or building until such wire is raised, cut or moved by an employee of the company owning or maintaining the same. 
(Code 1973, § 5-8; Ord. No. 764, § 3, 9-14-1965) 
Sec. 10-229. - Lights at night. 
    No house or building shall be moved at night, nor be stopped or left on any street or alley of the city at night, unless there shall be attached to each end of such house or building a red light or lantern visible for at least 300 feet along such street or alley. 
(Code 1973, § 5-9; Ord. No. 764, § 4, 9-14-1965) 
Secs. 10-230-10-251. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SWIMMING POOLS 

Sec. 10-252. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Swimming pool means any structure, above-ground or at ground level, indoors or outdoors, having a depth of 18 inches or more, used or suitable to be used for bathing or swimming purposes, whether in use, temporarily not in use, filled with water or drained of all water. 
(Ord. No. 1836, § 2, 11-12-1996) 
Sec. 10-253. - Enclosure required. 
(a)  Swimming pools in the city shall be completely enclosed by a fence, wall or screen enclosure not less than four feet in height. 
(b)  A building may be used as a part of such enclosure. The city building inspector may make determinations with regard to whether natural barriers or obstructions are sufficient to be used as part of a pool enclosure. 
(c)  All doors or gates in such enclosure that are accessible to the general public shall be equipped with self-closing and self-latching devices that operate to keep the gate or door securely closed at all times when not in actual use. 
(d)  Fences and walls of such enclosure shall be so designed as to eliminate any openings, holes or gaps in such enclosure that would permit the passage of a sphere six inches in diameter. 
(e)  Pools completely enclosed within buildings to which access by the general public is controlled, pools constructed above the ground floor of buildings to which access by the general public is controlled, or pools maintained within completely fenced or enclosed apartment complexes equipped with self-closing and self-latching devices on all gates or doors accessible to the general public and leading directly to the pool area, shall be considered to be in compliance with the requirements of this section. 
(f)  No final inspection shall be approved for any swimming pool constructed or erected unless, upon final inspection, the building inspector is satisfied that the enclosure requirements of this section have been met. 
(Ord. No. 1836, § 3, 11-12-1996) 
Sec. 10-254. - Right of entry for inspection; violation declared nuisance; penalties. 
(a)  The city code enforcement official, building inspector, or any authorized city official may enter upon any and all parts of the premises of such swimming places to make examinations and investigations of their compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Any person who violates this article is guilty of a Class C misdemeanor and upon conviction subject to a fine of up to $1,000.00. Each day such violation exists shall constitute a separate offense. In addition, violation of this article constitutes a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 1836, §§ 4, 5, 11-12-1996) 
Secs. 10-255-10-271. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - BUILDING AND STANDARDS COMMISSION 

Sec. 10-272. - Created; purpose. 
    Pursuant to V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.033, the city has created a building and standard commission to hear and determine cases concerning violations defined in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.032. 
(Ord. No. 2259, 5-12-2015) 
Sec. 10-273. - Members; terms; removal. 
    The building and standards commission shall consist of five members who are also members of the planning and zoning commission. Members of the building and standards commission shall serve two-year terms to run consecutively with their planning and zoning commission terms. The city council may remove a commission member for cause on a written charge. 
(Ord. No. 2259, 5-12-2015) 
Sec. 10-274. - Alternate members; appointment, terms, vacancies. 
    The mayor shall appoint, with the approval of the city council, eight or more alternate members who shall serve in the absence of regular members when requested to do so by the mayor or the city manager. Alternate members shall serve the same period and are subject to removal in the same manner as regular members. A vacancy of an alternate member is filled in the same manner as regular members. 
(Ord. No. 2259, 5-12-2015) 
Sec. 10-275. - Chairman; election and authority to administer oaths and compel witness attendance. 
    The building and standards commission shall elect a chairman from among its members. The chairman may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. 
(Ord. No. 2259, 5-12-2015) 
Sec. 10-276. - Procedural rules to be established. 
    The majority of the commission shall adopt rules in accordance with this article and V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.034 et seq. The rules shall establish procedures for use in hearings, providing ample opportunity for presentation of evidence and testimony by respondents or persons opposing charges brought by the city or its building officials relating to alleged violations of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2259, 5-12-2015) 
Sec. 10-277. - Meetings; minutes and other records. 
    Meetings of the commission shall be held at the call of the chairman and shall be open to the public. The commission shall keep minutes of its proceedings showing the vote of each member on each question or the fact that a member is absent or abstains from voting. The commission shall keep records of its examinations and other official actions. The minutes and records shall be filed in the office of the commission as public records. 
(Ord. No. 2259, 5-12-2015) 
Sec. 10-278. - Building official's statement of violation. 
    If the building official or his representative shall be of the opinion that a dangerous or unhealthy dwelling, building, improvement or condition exists within the city, he shall file a written statement with the chairman of the commission detailing the specific conditions rendering the dwelling, building or improvement or condition dangerous or unhealthy. 
(Ord. No. 2259, 5-12-2015) 
Sec. 10-279. - Notice of violation and hearing to interested parties. 
(a)  Upon receipt of the building official's statement of violation, the chairman shall cause written notice of the violation to be given: 
(1)  By personal service, certified mail, return receipt requested, or by delivery by United States Postal Service using signature confirmation service, to the record owners of the affected property, and each holder of a recorded lien against the affected property, as shown by the records in the office of the county clerk in which the affected property is located if the address of the lienholder can be ascertained from the deed of trust establishing the lien or other applicable instruments on file in the office of the county clerk; and 
(2)  To all unknown owners by posting a copy of the notice on the front door of the improvements structure on the affected property or as close to the front door as practicable. 
(b)  The notice shall identify the dangerous or unhealthy conditions that exist and require that such conditions be removed or remedied within ten days. The notice shall also set a date and time for a hearing before the building and standards commission, not less than ten days after that the notice is mailed and posted. 
(c)  The notice shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city on one occasion before the tenth day before the date fixed for the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 2259, 5-12-2015) 
Sec. 10-280. - Hearing. 
    All cases heard before the commission shall be heard by a majority of the commission. At the hearing, the building official or his representative shall present all available information and facts as to the condition of the premises. In addition, any person having an interest in the property shall have the opportunity to appear at the hearing to present relevant facts and hear the reports of city personnel or other witnesses. 
(Ord. No. 2259, 5-12-2015) 
Sec. 10-281. - Findings and final order; enforcement of penalties. 
(a)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the commission shall make written findings of fact as to whether the premises constitutes a dangerous or unhealthy condition. Such findings of fact shall be made by majority vote of the commission. The commission may, in accordance with its findings and V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.036: 
(1)  Order repair of the violating conditions within a fixed period of time; 
(2)  Declare a building substandard in accordance with V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 54; 
(3)  Order, in appropriate cases, the immediate removal of persons or property found on private property, enter on private property to secure the removal if it is determined that conditions exist on the property that constitute a violation of this Code, and order action to be taken as necessary to remedy, alleviate, or remove any substandard building found to exist; 
(4)  Issue orders or directives to any peace office of the state, including a sheriff or constable or the city police chief to enforce and carry out the lawful orders or directives of the commission; and 
(5)  Determine the amount and duration of a civil penalty, if assessed by the commission, as provided by V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.017. 
(b)  An abbreviated copy of the order shall be published one time in a newspaper of general circulation in the city within ten calendar days after date of delivery or mailing of the copy as provided in this article, including the street address or legal description of the property; the date of the hearing; a brief statement indicating the results of the order; and instructions stating where a copy of the order may be obtained and a copy shall be filed in the office of the city secretary. 
(c)  Pursuant to V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.037, a determination of a civil penalty shall be final and binding and constitutes prima facie evidence of the penalty in any court of jurisdiction in a civil suit brought by the city for final judgment in accordance with the established penalty. To enforce a civil penalty hereunder, the city secretary shall file with the county district clerk a certified copy of the order of the commission establishing the amount and duration of the penalty. No other proof is required for the district clerk to enter final judgment on the penalty. 
(Ord. No. 2259, 5-12-2015) 
Sec. 10-282. - Emergency intervention by city; recovery of costs. 
    A condition subject to this article is an emergency if it reasonably appears that there is immediate danger to the life and safety of any person, or an unhealthy condition exists for any person, unless an uninhabitable or dangerous dwelling, building or improvement is immediately repaired, vacated, demolished, or immediate remedy of such building or condition takes place. The city may, at its option, take steps to remedy an emergency condition. The cost of emergency repair, vacation, demolition or remedy by the city or its designees shall be assessed against the owner and such assessment shall become a lien upon the property which shall be filed in county lien records. 
(Ord. No. 2259, 5-12-2015) 
Sec. 10-283. - Judicial review. 
(a)  Any owner, lienholder, or mortgage of record jointly or severally aggrieved by a decision of the commission may present a petition to a district court, duly verified, setting forth that the decision is illegal in whole or in part, and specifying the grounds for the illegality. 
(b)  The petition must be presented to the court within 30 calendar days after the date a copy of the final decision of the commission is delivered, mailed by first class mail with certified return receipt requested, or delivered by the United States Postal Service using signature confirmation service, to all persons whom notice is required under V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.035. The commission shall deliver or mail that copy promptly after the decision becomes final. 
(c)  The judicial review procedures set forth in the V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.039 are adopted to the extent applicable and made a part of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2259, 5-12-2015) 
Sec. 10-284. - Conflict with state law. 
    If a provision of this article conflicts with V.T.C.A., Local Government Code §§ 54.031 through 54.042, state law shall supersede the conflicting provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2259, 5-12-2015) 
Chapter 12 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation of miscellaneous businesses, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 215.002 et seq.; home rule municipal authority to license any lawful business or occupation that is subject to its police powers, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 215.075; municipal authority to regulate sexually oriented business, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 243.001 et seq.; uniformity required in the issuance of local permits, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 245.001 et seq.; occupations generally, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 1.001 et seq.; Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 431.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Tent shows restricted to county fairgrounds. 
    It is unlawful for any open or tent show to exhibit on any grounds, lots or blocks in the city, except on the location so designated by the city, and the show grounds or district so designated shall be the county fairgrounds. In addition, it is unlawful for any person, including employees, agents and persons in charge, to exhibit any open or tent show except only on the county fairgrounds. 
(Code 1973, §§ 10-1, 10-2; Ord. No. 167A, §§ 1, 3, 7-29-1929) 
Secs. 12-2-12-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ITINERANT MERCHANTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to license, tax, prevent or otherwise regulate hawkers and pawnbrokers, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 215.031; cancellation of certain home solicited consumer transactions, V.T.C.A., Business and Commerce Code § 601.001 et seq.; certain peddlers regarded as retailers for purposes of sales and use taxes, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 151.024. 

Sec. 12-21. - Definitions; applicability. 
(a)  As used in this article, the terms "itinerant merchant," "itinerant vendor" and "itinerant peddler" are synonymous and mean any person who shall not maintain an office or business establishment within an area of the city zoned for business uses under the provisions of the city zoning ordinance, wherein there are kept, used and maintained either office or business equipment or business supplies of a kind and type reasonably commensurate with the requirements of the business activity engaged in by such person or an inventory of such goods, wares, merchandise, services (including tools of trade or parts), products, photographs, newspapers, magazines, books, pamphlets, periodicals or other reading matter, equipment for the taking, printing and reproduction of photographs and related supplies, or any other item, product or thing offered by such person for sale, rent or lease to the public, and which are subject to rendition and assessment for ad valorem taxes by the tax assessor-collector. The terms "itinerant merchant," "itinerant vendor" and "itinerant peddler" also mean any person who does not maintain such business establishment or office or such inventory and who goes about calling upon the inhabitants of the city from door to door, at any house, place or building, or who communicates with the inhabitants thereof by means of the telephone from within or without the city, for the purpose of soliciting, selling, renting, leasing, taking orders for or offering to solicit, sell, rent, lease or take orders for any such goods, wares, merchandise, services, products or reading matter. 
(b)  It is the intention of this article that any such person who is in fact an itinerant merchant, vendor or peddler, as herein defined, shall apply for and be issued such license before engaging in any of the above described activities within the city, irrespective of the manner, method or means of communication employed by such person in contacting prospects, clientele, customers, ultimate users, purchasers, recipients, subscribers and consumers of the product, item, thing or service, which is the subject matter of the business activity and endeavor pursued by such person; but shall not apply to the resident citizens of the county who actually raise, grow, harvest and produce the items mentioned in section 12-23(b) on land situated within the county, or to persons residing outside the county who actually raise, grow, harvest and produce the items on land situated within the county; nor shall the provisions of this article apply to sales made to dealers by commercial travelers or sales agents in the usual course of business, nor to sales made under the authority of any ordinance or franchise heretofore promulgated and issued by the city, nor shall the provisions of this article apply to commercial dealers operating within the city under licenses granted by the city. 
(Code 1973, § 10-14; Ord. No. 441, §§ 2, 8, 7-8-1958; Ord. No. 633, §§ 1, 3, 1-8-1963; Ord. No. 666, § II(a), (c), (e), 8-13-1963) 
Sec. 12-22. - Purpose. 
    This article is and shall be deemed an exercise of the police power of the state and of the city for the public safety, comfort, convenience and protection of the city and citizens of the city, and all of the provisions of this article shall be construed for the accomplishment of that purpose. 
(Code 1973, § 10-15; Ord. No. 441, § 1, 7-8-1958) 
Sec. 12-23. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person acting as an itinerant merchant, itinerant vendor, itinerant peddler or in any other similar capacity, to solicit, sell, rent, lease, take orders for, or to offer to solicit, to offer to sell, to offer to rent, to offer to lease or to offer to take orders for any such goods, wares, merchandise, products, photographs, services, newspapers, magazines, books, pamphlets, periodicals or other reading matter of whatever kind or character, by personal calls or contacts upon and with the inhabitants of the city, or by telephone communication emanating either from within or without the city, without first having applied for and obtained a license to do so from the city secretary, and without having such license upon his person when actually engaged in the business or activity for which the license is issued. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful, except as exempted herein, for any person acting as an itinerant merchant, itinerant vendor or itinerant peddler to sell or offer to sell, or to take orders for any fruit, vegetable, produce, truck crop or any other food, poultry or dairy product or other merchandise for human consumption, whether in solid or liquid form, and whether in open or sealed containers, from any cart, car, truck, wagon or other vehicle upon the public streets, alleys and ways, or from any temporary stand, structure, shack, tent or other enclosure situated upon any public or private property within the city, or going about the city from house to house or from building to building for such purposes as set out in this article, without having first applied for and obtained a license to do so as provided in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1973, § 10-16; Ord. No. 441, § 2, 7-8-1958; Ord. No. 633, § 1, 1-8-1963; Ord. No. 666, §§ I, II(b), 8-13-1963) 
Sec. 12-24. - Application. 
    Any person desiring a license required by this article shall make written application to the city secretary at least seven days prior to the date on which such person intends to sell or solicit in the city, for a license to do so, which application shall show: 
(1)  Name and address of the company, if any. 
(2)  Full and complete description of the goods, wares and merchandise or other articles, which description shall give in detail the grade, make, character or property to be sold. 
(3)  Whether the applicant upon any sale or order shall demand, accept or receive payment or deposit of money in advance of final delivery. 
(4)  The period of time the applicant wishes to sell or solicit in the city. 
(5)  The full name and post office address of the applicant. 
(6)  The state, county, town or city in which the applicant permanently resides. 
(7)  The age, height, weight, complexion, color of hair, color of eyes and fingerprints of the applicant. 
(8)  If the applicant has ever been convicted of a felony or sex crime, it shall be so stated in the application, giving the name of the offense, name of the court and date of each conviction and the time served under each conviction. 
(9)  Names and post office addresses of three persons as references to which the city secretary shall write, within two days of the date of filing of the application, with reference to the character and moral integrity of the applicant. 
(10)  Attached to the application there shall be a photographic likeness of the applicant. 
(11)  The state registration numbers of the vehicles to be used by the applicant and his driver's license number shall also be indicated on the application. 
(Code 1973, § 10-17; Ord. No. 441, § 3, 7-8-1958) 
Sec. 12-25. - Bond. 
    The application for the license required by this article shall be accompanied by a bond in the penal sum of $1,000.00, signed by the applicant and signed, as surety, by some surety company authorized to do business in the state, conditioned for the final delivery of goods, wares, merchandise, services, photographs, magazines, newspapers and other articles in accordance with the terms of any order obtained prior to delivery and also conditioned to indemnify all purchasers or customers for all defects in material or workmanship that may exist in the article sold by the principal of the bond, at the delivery, and that may be discovered by such purchaser or customer within 30 days after delivery, and which bond shall be for the use and benefit of all persons who may make any purchase or give any order to the principal on the bond, or to an agent or employee of the principal; provided, in case the applicant is engaging in such activity through one or more agents or employees, such persons shall be required to enter into only one bond, in the sum of $1,000.00 as above required, which bond shall be made to cover the activities of all its agents or employees. 
(Code 1973, § 10-18; Ord. No. 441, § 4, 7-8-1958) 
Sec. 12-26. - Fees; term. 
    The license fee for an itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor shall be as reflected in the city fee schedule; provided, however, when any person engages in any activity mentioned in section 12-23 through one or more agents or employees, such person shall in addition to the fee, pay a license fee as reflected in the city fee schedule for such agent or employee so engaged, all of which licenses shall be valid for one year from the date of their issuance. The fees herein provided for shall be used for the purpose of defraying expenses incident to the issuing of the licenses. 
(Code 1973, § 10-19; Ord. No. 441, § 6, 7-8-1958; Ord. No. 1503, § I, 10-1-1984) 
Sec. 12-27. - Denial for false statement. 
    Any false statement on the application shall cause the request for license to be denied by the city secretary. 
(Code 1973, § 10-20; Ord. No. 441, § 7, 7-8-1958) 
Sec. 12-28. - Personal; nontransferable; notice of time of operation; cancellation. 
    The license required by this article shall in all things be personal to the applicant and issued showing his name as well as the company he represents, and it shall not be transferable. The license may be canceled by the chief of police for good cause shown. Any time the licensee works in the city other than the period of time reported on the application for license, it shall be his duty to report that fact to the chief of police. It shall be the duty of each licensee to have in his possession at all times his license which shall be exhibited by him when requested. 
(Code 1973, § 10-21; Ord. No. 441, § 9, 7-8-1958) 
Secs. 12-29-12-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STREET AND SIDEWALK VENDORS 

Sec. 12-40. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Goods means any item offered for sale including, without limitation, wares, merchandise, services, food (including frozen and perishable food) and domestic or farm animals. 
    Perishable food item means both frozen and non-frozen items regardless of whether or how packaged. 
    Street vendor or sidewalk vendor means a person, acting on his own behalf or on behalf of an entity, engaging in sale of retail or wholesale goods on public owned right-of-way or on private property duly zoned for such enterprise. 
Sec. 12-41. - Enhanced penalties applicable. 
    This article is an exercise of the police power of the city for the public safety, comfort, convenience and protection of city citizens, and violations of this article shall be subject to the enhanced penalties applicable to such regulations under state law. 
Sec. 12-42. - License required except for sales to dealers by commercial travelers and sales agents. 
    It is unlawful for any person acting as a street or sidewalk vendor retailing or wholesaling goods within the city, whether on public owned right-of-way or on private property, when properly zoned, without having first applied for and obtained a license to do so from the city secretary; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to sales made to dealers by commercial travelers or sales agents in the usual course of business. 
Sec. 12-43. - Application. 
(a)  Applications for licensure under this article shall be made in writing to the city secretary prior to set for or conduct of any sales. The application shall include, at a minimum, the following information: 
(1)  Applicant's full name and permanent mailing address. 
(2)  Complete description of goods, wares and merchandise or other article, to be sold including, when applicable, the grade, make, and character of the merchandise. 
(3)  Whether applicant upon sale or order shall demand, accept or receive payment or deposit of money in advance of final delivery. 
(4)  The period of time applicant wishes to sell or solicit sales in the city, not to exceed 31 consecutive days. 
(5)  A copy of the applicant's current sales tax license issued by the state comptroller's office. 
(6)  A signed and dated statement from the property owner giving permission for use of his property for the proposed sale during the time specified in the application. 
(7)  Whether applicant has ever been convicted of a felony or sex crime and, if so, details with regard to each such conviction. 
(8)  A passport size photograph of the applicant; and 
(9)  The number of the license to be issued (to be supplied by the city secretary). 
(b)  Any false statement on an application submitted under this article shall be grounds for denial of licensure. 
Sec. 12-44. - Fee. 
    The fee for licenses issued under this article shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
Sec. 12-45. - Display of license. 
    It is the duty of each license holder to the license in his possession at the time items are being offered for sale. Licenses shall be prominently displayed, visible from the main street providing access to the sale, at all times during which sales are solicited or conducted. 
Sec. 12-46. - Licenses not transferrable; term of license; cancellation by police chief. 
    License issued under this article are personal to the applicant and, if applicable, the company he represents and are not transferable. Licenses shall expire 31 calendar days from the date of issue, and may be cancelled by the police chief at any time for good cause shown. 
Sec. 12-47. - Nonprofit organizations exemption and registration requirement. 
(a)  Local organization. Local nonprofit organizations based in the city or county shall be exempt from the license and fee requirements of this article but must pre-register with the city secretary's office prior to conducting any street or sidewalk sales. The exemption granted in this section is limit to sales on one weekend per month and such sales shall comply with all other requirements of this article. 
(b)  Non-local non-profit organizations. An exemption under this section for Texas based nonprofit organizations that are not based in the city or county must be first approved by the city council. Non-local non-profit organizations granted exemption under this section shall comply with all other requirements of this article. 
Sec. 12-48. - Zoning restrictions applicable. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to authorize sale of goods in any area where such sale is forbidden by city zoning regulations. 
Sec. 12-49. - Perishable foods to be maintained in approved containers. 
    Perishable food items, both frozen and non-frozen, shall be maintained in containers and conditions acceptable by the county community affairs office. 
Secs. 12-50-12-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TAXICABS 

Sec. 12-60. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Applicant means any individual, firm or corporation in the process of attaining either a license to operate or a city taxi driver permit. 
    Conduct a taxicab business means the use of one or more taxicabs within the city, by the owner thereof, for the purpose of carrying passengers for hire, either by driving the same himself or having the same driven by some other person, provided that this definition shall not apply to any licensed chauffeur hired as a driver by any person holding a license to conduct a taxicab business in the city. 
    Driver means an individual who drives or operates a taxicab. 
    Holder means a person who is granted an annual operating permit to operate a taxicab service under the provisions of this article. 
    Manifest means a daily record prepared by a taxicab driver of all trips made by the driver, showing time and place of origin, destination, number of passengers and the amount of fare of each trip. 
    Operating permit means the permission granted by the city to operate a taxicab service inside the city for a period of one year, renewable under the provisions of this article. 
    Rate card means a card for display in each taxicab which contains the rates of fare in force. 
    Taxicab means a motor vehicle regularly engaged in the business of carrying passengers for hire and not operated on a fixed route, other than a limousine. 
    Taxicab business means a service consisting of the provisions and operation of motor vehicles for hire which carry passengers and are not operated on a fixed route, and does not include limousine services. 
(Code 1973, § 16-1; Ord. No. 253, § 1, 7-11-1946; Ord. No. 2222, § 1, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-61. - Vehicle inspection. 
(a)  Before being allowed to operate upon the streets of the city, each taxicab shall be inspected and approved annually by the chief of police or his representative. 
(b)  No taxicab shall be driven or operated upon the streets of the city unless the same is in safe condition and free from mechanical defects, and it must further meet the following requirements: 
(1)  Have a current valid state inspection sticker and be in compliance with the safety requirements of the state motor vehicle code as amended; 
(2)  Have a seat belt for each passenger; 
(3)  Have an operating heater and air conditioner; 
(4)  Have a fire extinguisher that is in good operating order; and 
(5)  Have a taxi-top light. 
(c)  The vehicle identification number and license number of each taxicab must match the numbers listed for that taxicab on the permit application. 
(d)  Insignia of taxicab must be the same as that indicated on the permit application. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 2, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-62. - Condition of the vehicle. 
    Every vehicle operating under this article shall be kept clean and in sanitary condition. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 3, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-63. - Designation of taxi. 
(a)  Each taxicab shall have painted on both sides the trade name of the organization under whose operating permit such taxicab is being operated, the taxicab unit number, and the business telephone number of the holder of the operating permit. Such letters and numbers shall be not less than three inches high with one-half inch stroke, painted on each taxicab with permanent, non-washable paint of a color sharply contrasting to the color of the taxicab so that the same will be readily apparent. 
(b)  No design shall be approved that, in the opinion of the city, conflicts with or imitates that of any vehicle already operating under an operating permit granted under this article. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 4, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-64. - Taximeter required. 
(a)  A person may not drive or allow another person to drive a taxicab unless the taxicab is equipped with an operational taximeter that displays an accuracy seal, certifying its accuracy in accordance with procedures determined by the chief of police. 
(b)  For purposes of determining a fare for taxicab service, a person may not use a device other than a taximeter for measuring distance or time. 
(c)  Except as provided by section 12-65(e), a person may not drive or allow another person to drive a taxicab unless an accurate taximeter is used to determine the fare to be charged. 
(d)  When using a taximeter to compute a fare, a driver shall place the taximeter in the revenue-earning position when a passenger enters a taxicab, or at the pre-arranged time, if any, after the customer is informed of the taxicab's presence. 
(e)  When using a taximeter to compute a fare, a driver shall call the attention of passengers to the amount registered on the taximeter before resetting the taximeter. The taximeter may not be reset to the "vacant" position until after the fare is paid. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 5, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-65. - Rates of fare; rate card required. 
(a)  This section establishes maximum fares that the owner or operator of a taxicab can charge. Rates are annually set by city council and are subject to change. 
(b)  For four or fewer passengers, the owner or operator of a taxicab may charge a pickup fee of not to exceed $5.00. For five or more passengers, the owner or operator of a taxicab may charge $1.00 for each additional passenger. 
(c)  For trips wholly within the city, the fare shall be a maximum of $2.00 per mile, regardless of the number of passengers. The taximeter shall be calibrated to charge no more than $0.50 per one-fourth of a mile. 
(d)  For trips that originate in the city, the fare shall be a maximum of $2.00 per mile, regardless of the number of passengers. The taximeter shall be calibrated to charge no more than $0.50 per one-fourth of a mile. 
(e)  A taximeter is not necessary to determine the maximum fare for a trip under a contract with a governmental agency, a nonprofit organization, or as otherwise reasonably necessary to provide a public service. 
(f)  The maximum fare for wait time will be $15.00 for each hour the driver must wait for a passenger. The taximeter shall be calibrated to charge a maximum of $0.25 per minute of wait time. 
(g)  A cab driver may charge a cleaning fee if a passenger soils a taxicab to the extent that the taxicab must be pulled from service for cleaning. The cleaning fee shall not exceed $250.00. 
(h)  Every taxicab operated under this article shall have a rate card setting forth the rates of fare established by this section displayed in a place in view of all passengers. The rate card shall instruct customers to call the city police department at (361)358-8100 or any successor non-emergency telephone number if they have questions or concerns about the rates. 
(i)  In January of each year, the chief of police shall review the rates of fare to determine whether the fares need to be reconsidered. The chief of police shall base such the determination on the consumer price index, the costs of gasoline, and other reasonable costs of operating a taxicab service. The chief of police shall report his findings each year to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 6, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-66. - Attempt to defraud passenger. 
    A person who operates a taxicab commits an offense if the person intentionally extends the distance or time for a trip beyond the distance and time necessary for the trip for the purpose of increasing the fare for the trip. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 7, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-67. - Solicitation of business.
