    It shall be unlawful for any driver of any taxicab or for any other person acting for the driver to seek or solicit patrons or passengers for any such taxicab by word or sign while driving any such taxicab over, through, or on any public street or public place of the city. Drivers may solicit business when the taxicab is legally parked. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 8, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-68. - Additional passengers. 
(a)  No driver shall permit any other person to occupy or ride in the taxicab, unless the person first employing the taxicab shall consent to the acceptance of the additional passenger. 
(b)  No driver shall permit more people to occupy a taxicab than the number of seatbelts installed and operational in that taxicab. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 9, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-69. - Refusal to carry orderly passengers prohibited. 
    No taxicab driver shall refuse or neglect to convey any orderly person, upon request, unless: 
(1)  The taxicab is previously engaged; 
(2)  The person is disorderly; 
(3)  The driver is engaged in answering a previous request for service; 
(4)  The driver is in fear of his personal safety; or 
(5)  The driver reasonably believes, based on a person's behavior, that transporting the person would damage the taxicab. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 10, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-70. - Service. 
    The permit holder shall determine the operating hours for cab service and shall provide information of operating hours to the chief of police. All calls for services inside the city during these hours shall be answered as soon as reasonably possible. If the services cannot be rendered within a reasonable time, the holder shall notify the prospective passenger how long it will be before the call can be answered and the reason for the delay. Any holder who refuses to accept a call anywhere in the city during these hours when the holder has available cabs, or who fails or refuses to provide high quality service, shall be deemed to violate this article and the violation shall be grounds for revocation of the operating permit. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 11, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-71. - Manifest. 
    Every driver of a vehicle operated pursuant to this article shall maintain a daily manifest upon which are recorded all trips made each day, showing time and place of origin and destination of each tap and the amount of fare. All completed manifests shall be returned to the designated agent of the holder of an operating permit at the conclusion of each tour of duty. The forms for each manifest shall be furnished to the driver by the holder. The holder shall retain and preserve all drivers' manifests in a safe place for at least the calendar year next preceding the current calendar year, and the manifests shall be available to the city at all times. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 12, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-72. - Holder's records and reports. 
    Every operating permit holder shall keep accurate records of receipts from operations, operating and other expenses, capital expenditures and any other operating information required by the city. Every holder shall maintain the records containing this information and other data required by this article at a place readily accessible for examination by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 13, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-73. - Operating permit. 
    No person shall engage, directly or indirectly, in the taxicab business upon the city streets without having first obtained an operating permit from the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 14, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-74. - Permit application. 
(a)  An application for an operating permit required in section 12-73 shall be filed with the city secretary's office upon forms provided by the city. The application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  If the applicant is a partnership, the information in subsection (a)(1) of this section shall be provided for each partner. 
(3)  If the applicant is a corporation, the name and place of residence of all of the officers of the corporation, a duly certified copy of its charter and bylaws, the amount of capital stock, the character and value of its assets, its liabilities and the security therefor and, if a corporation, a duly certified copy of its certificate of authority to transact business in the state. 
(4)  The experience of the applicant in the transportation of passengers. 
(5)  Any facts the applicant believes tend to prove that public convenience and necessity require the granting of an operating permit. 
(6)  The name, usual trade description, seating capacity, equipment, motor number, state license number, rated horsepower and factory number of each motor vehicle to be operated or controlled by applicant, and the year in which each automobile was manufactured. 
(7)  The location of any stand at which the taxicabs will remain when not in actual service. 
(8)  The name and address of the person who will be in active charge and control of the taxicab business. 
(9)  The proposed fares. 
(10)  The color scheme or insignia to be used to designate the vehicles of the applicant. 
(b)  No operating permit required under this article shall be issued or continued in operation unless the holder thereof has paid an annual license fee as provided in the city fee schedule for each year for each vehicle operated under an operating permit. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 15, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-75. - Public hearing. 
(a)  Upon the filing of an application for a certificate under this article, a time and place shall be set for a public hearing thereon. Notice of the hearing shall be given to the applicant and to all persons to whom operating permits have been previously issued. Due notice shall also be given to the general public by publication of the notice, at least ten days prior to the date set for the hearing, in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
(b)  Any interested person may file with the city council a statement in support of or opposition to the issuance of an operating permit. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 16, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-76. - Issuance. 
    If the city council, after the public hearing required by section 12-75, finds that further taxicab service in the city is required by the public convenience and necessity and that the applicant is fit, willing and able to provide the public transportation and to conform to this article, the city council shall issue an operating permit stating the name and address of the applicant, the number of vehicles authorized under the certificate and the date of issuance; otherwise the application shall be denied. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 17, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-77. - Insurance required. 
    Each holder of an operating permit for the operation of a taxicab business shall at all times during the term of the operating permit maintain a policy of liability insurance issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the state on each and every motor vehicle operated under the terms of the operating permit in the amount of $100,000.00 for bodily injury to any one person; in the amount of $300,000.00 for injuries to more than one person which are sustained in the same accident; and in the amount of $100,000.00 for property damage resulting from any one accident. The policy shall list the city as an additional insured. The policies shall be approved by the city attorney and filed with the city secretary. The policies of insurance shall not be cancelled or surrendered except after ten days' written notice to the city secretary. Failure of the operating permit holder to procure and file the policies of insurance as required by the section or failure to keep the policies in force shall immediately forfeit and make the operating permit null and void, and all rights there under shall at once cease. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 18, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-78. - Transferability. 
    No operating permit required under this article may be sold, assigned, mortgaged or otherwise transferred without the consent of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 19, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-79. - Suspension and revocation. 
(a)  Upon complaint alleging violation of any of the provisions of this article filed by any person with the chief of police, or upon the person's motion, the chief of police, after five days' notice of the grounds of such complaint to the owner or operators of the taxicab service against whom complaint is made, shall hear evidence with reference to such complaint, and after such hearing, the chief of police may revoke or suspend the operating permit of such holder with good cause shown. 
(b)  Due cause for the suspension or revocation of an operating permit will include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Failure of the operating permit holder to maintain any and all of the general qualifications applicable to the initial issuance of the permit as set forth in this article; 
(2)  Obtaining an operating permit by providing false information; 
(3)  Discontinuing operations for more than ten days; 
(4)  Violating any ordinance of the city, the laws of the United States or of the state, the violation of which adversely affects the ability of holder to offer public transportation; or 
(5)  Violation of any part of this article. 
(c)  The holder shall have the right to appeal the suspension or revocation to the city manager within ten business days of the notice of suspension or revocation. Such appeal will be submitted by a letter addressed to the city manager stating that an appeal from the decision of the chief of police is desired to the city manager. Upon receiving such notice of appeal, the city manager, as soon as practical thereafter, shall conduct a hearing at which the appealing party will be given an opportunity to present evidence and make arguments in the person's behalf. The formal rules of evidence do not apply to an appeal hearing under this section. The city manager shall make its ruling on the basis of a preponderance of the evidence at the hearing. 
(d)  The city manager will affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the chief of police. The decision of the city manager is final. 
(e)  If no appeal is taken from the ruling of the chief of police in the time and manner provided in this article, the ruling of the chief of police shall be final. 
(f)  Any person who continues to operate a taxicab under a permit that has been suspended or revoked for any reason while the suspension or revocation is in effect shall be considered guilty of misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be assessed a penalty accordingly. Every day's violation shall be considered to be a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 20, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-80. - Driver's permit. 
    No person shall operate a taxicab for hire upon the city streets and no person who owns or controls a taxicab shall permit it to be so driven, unless the driver of the taxicab shall have in force a taxicab driver's permit issued under this article. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 20, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-81. - Driver's permit application. 
(a)  The holder of an operating permit shall file with the city secretary's office an application for a taxicab driver's permit for each driver employed by the holder. On the application the holder shall certify that there is currently in effect an insurance policy covering the driver while the driver is engaged in providing taxi service. 
(b)  It is the responsibility of the holder to immediately notify the city secretary's office if the insurance required by subsection (a) of this section is no longer in effect for a driver holding a driver's permit and employed by the holder. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 21, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-82. - Driver's permit issuance; duration. 
(a)  Upon submission of the application for a taxicab driver's permit, a permit shall be issued which shall bear the name, address, signature and photograph of the driver. 
(b)  The driver's permit shall be in effect for one calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 22, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-83. - Driver's permit display. 
    Every driver operating pursuant to this article shall post the driver's permit in full view of all passengers while the driver is operating a taxicab. The permit shall be in sufficiently large type that a person with normal eyesight can read the permit from the back seat of the taxicab. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 23, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-84. - Failure to comply with laws. 
    Every driver receiving a driver's permit under this article shall comply with all city, state and federal laws. Failure to do so will justify the suspension or revocation of the permit. The police chief shall initiate the revocation or suspension. No permit shall be suspended or revoked unless notice and an opportunity to be heard have been provided the holder of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 24, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-85. - Suspension and revocation of driver's permit. 
(a)  Upon complaint alleging violation of any of the provisions of this article filed by any person with the chief of police, or upon the person's motion, the chief of police, after five days' notice of the grounds of such complaint to the driver and to the owner or operators of the taxicab service against whom complaint is made, shall hear evidence with reference to such complaint, and after such hearing the chief of police may revoke or suspend the driver's permit of such driver with good cause shown. 
(b)  Due cause for the suspension or revocation of a driver's permit will include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Failure of the driver's permit holder to maintain any and all of the general qualifications applicable to the initial issuance of the permit as set forth in this article; 
(2)  Obtaining a driver's permit by providing false information; 
(3)  Violating any ordinance of the city, the laws of the United States or of the state, the violation of which adversely affects the ability of the holder to offer public transportation; or 
(4)  Violation of any part of this section. 
(c)  The holder shall have the right to appeal the suspension or revocation to the city manager within ten business days of the notice of suspension or revocation. Such appeal will be submitted by a letter addressed to the city manager stating that an appeal from the decision of the chief of police is desired to the city manager. Upon receiving such notice of appeal, the city manager, as soon as practical thereafter, shall conduct a hearing at which the appealing party will be given an opportunity to present evidence and make argument in the person's behalf. The formal rules of evidence do not apply to an appeal hearing under this section. The city manager shall make its ruling on the basis of a preponderance of the evidence at the hearing. 
(d)  The city manager will affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the chief of police. The decision of the city manager is final. 
(e)  If no appeal is taken from the ruling of the chief of police in the time and manner as provided in this article, the ruling of the chief of police shall be final. 
(f)  Any person who continues to drive a taxicab under a driver's permit that has been suspended or revoked for any reason while the suspension or revocation is in effect shall be considered guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be assessed a penalty accordingly. Every day's violation shall be considered to be a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 25, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-86. - Driver's conduct. 
(a)  While on duty, a driver shall: 
(1)  Act in a professional and courteous manner; and 
(2)  Maintain a well-groomed appearance. 
(b)  While on duty, a driver may not: 
(1)  Consume an alcoholic beverage, controlled substance, or other substance that could adversely affect the driver's ability to drive a motor vehicle, and may not drive a vehicle while under the influence of an alcoholic beverage, controlled substance, or other substance that could adversely affect the driver's ability to drive a motor vehicle; 
(2)  Sell or otherwise provide an alcoholic beverage or a controlled substance to a passenger in a ground transportation service vehicle; 
(3)  Monitor the communication frequency of a ground transportation service other than the driver's own frequency or respond to a service call assigned to another driver; or 
(4)  Possess communication equipment, including scanners, capable of receiving the frequency of a service other than the driver's own. 
(c)  If a person is convicted of an offense prescribed in subsection (b)(2) of this section, the conviction results in the automatic revocation, without further notice, of all chauffeur's permits held by the person. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 26, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-87. - Soliciting for other business prohibited. 
    A driver may not solicit business for a hotel, motel, or similar business or attempt to divert patronage from one lodging business to another. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 27, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-88. - Unlawful acts. 
    A driver may not knowingly permit an unlawful act to be conducted in the taxicab. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 28, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-89. - Distracting driver. 
(a)  A person may not distract or attempt to distract the driver of a taxicab by physical contact or disorderly behavior while the driver is operating the taxicab. 
(b)  Violation of this section is a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 29, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-90. - Training required. 
(a)  Before applying for a driver's permit, each applicant must attend and complete training on recognizing the symptoms of alcohol poisoning and what to do when they observe someone with the symptoms. 
(b)  Before applying for a driver's permit, each applicant must attend hospitality training. 
(Ord. No. 2222, § 30, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 12-90.1. - Investigation; license issuance or denial. 
(a)  The city secretary or a duly authorized representative shall conduct an investigation into the background of all applicants for a taxicab license. The investigation shall include making a permanent record of the identity of all applicants, and shall not exceed 15 working days to conduct. As authorized by state law, a license issued pursuant to this article must be denied, suspended or revoked if the applicant has been convicted of, pled guilty or no contest to, any of the following offenses within the five-year period immediately preceding the date of the filing of an application: 
(1)  Unauthorized use of motor vehicle; 
(2)  Violation of state or federal laws regulating firearms; 
(3)  Violence to any person (except for conduct classified as a Class C misdemeanor); 
(4)  Indecency with a child; rape, sexual abuse, sexual assault; 
(5)  Sale or use of illegal drugs; or 
(6)  Driving while under the influence (drugs or alcohol); 
(7)  The application contains a false statement by the applicant. 
(b)  The city secretary shall deny issuance of a license of the application or investigation shows the applicant has had a taxicab business license revoked within the two years preceding the date of application. 
(c)  Criminal background check fee will consist of a $5.00 payment to the City of Beeville. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 31, 8-23-2016) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2303, § 31, adopted Aug. 23, 2016, enacted new provisions but did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, codification as § 12-90.1 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 12-91. - Operation without licenses prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or drive a taxicab on any of the streets of the city without the owner and driver thereof having licenses to so operate as is required by this article. 
(Code 1973, § 16-2; Ord. No. 327, § 1, 5-11-1953) 
Sec. 12-92. - Certificate of public convenience and necessity or license required; application; investigation; issuance. 
(a)  Before the city secretary shall issue an operator's license under the provisions of this article, a certificate or permit declaring that the public convenience and necessity require the issuance of such license shall first be obtained from the city council. 
(b)  Every person who may desire a license as owner to operate a taxicab shall file with the city secretary a written application signed by such applicant and stating: 
(1)  His name and place of residence, sex, age, customary occupation, the character and value of the assets of his taxicab business and whether any other persons own any interest in the business and what persons own any title or interest in any vehicle for which such license is requested. 
(2)  The name, usual trade description, equipment, rated horsepower and factory number of such vehicle and, as nearly as practicable, the year in which the automobile was manufactured or first used. 
(3)  The stand or stands at which the automobile will remain while not in actual service. 
(4)  The kind of written insurance which the applicant desires to furnish the city. 
(5)  The rated seating capacity of such automobile. 
(6)  If the applicant is a corporation, the name and place of residence of the officers of such corporation; the amount of its capital stock and the amount thereof fully paid up; the character and value of its assets, its liabilities and the security therefor, and when required by the city council, such corporation shall file as an addition to its application a duly certified copy of its charter and bylaws, and if it be a foreign corporation, a duly certified copy of its permit to do business in the state. 
(c)  Whenever application for a certificate required by this article is made to the city secretary under the provisions of this article, it shall be the duty of the city secretary to submit such application to the city council at its next regular meeting and such application shall be considered an application for a certificate of public convenience and necessity, as well as an application for a license to operate such vehicles. The city council shall make or cause to be made investigations, including any hearing deemed desirable as to any applications for such certificates, and shall determine whether the public convenience and necessity require the operation of such taxicabs and whether the applicant is fit to conduct such business and may investigate the fitness of the officers and stockholders of any corporation making such application, and in determining whether a certificate should be issued, the city council shall give weight and due regard to, among other things: 
(1)  Probable permanence and quality of the service offered by the applicant; 
(2)  The financial ability and responsibility of the applicant and its organization and personnel; 
(3)  The character of vehicles; 
(4)  The character and location of depots and terminals proposed to be used; and 
(5)  The experience of the applicant in the transportation of passengers. 
(d)  If the city council finds that the public convenience and necessity require the operation of a greater or lesser number of vehicles than that for which the certificate has been applied for, and that the applicant or owner is fit to conduct the business, and that the other requirements of this article have been complied with, it shall notify the applicant of its findings. If it finds that public convenience and necessity do not require the operation of any such vehicles or that the applicant is not fit to conduct such business, it shall forthwith refuse such application and no certificate or license shall be issued to such applicant. If it shall be determined that the public convenience and necessity require the operation of such vehicles, and that the applicant is fit to conduct such business, the applicant shall within 60 days thereafter furnish to the city council or such person as it may designate, information as to the particular vehicles for which certificates are granted, such information to include the make, the state license number, the length of time the vehicle has been in use, the motor power thereof, the names and addresses of the persons from whom the vehicles were purchased and any other information required by the city council. If the city council finds that the applicant is the owner of such vehicles and the same are fit and safe for the transportation of passengers and conform to the requirements of this article and other ordinances of the city applicable thereto, and to such other requirements as the city council may make under the authority of this article, it shall issue or cause to be issued to the applicant the certificate required by this article. 
(Code 1973, § 16-3; Ord. No. 327, §§ 3(f), 4(b), (c), 5-11-1953) 
Sec. 12-93. - Transfer; substitution of vehicles. 
    The certificate required by this article shall not be transferable without the consent and approval of the city council, and, after application, notice and hearing, as provided on original application; but the person to whom the certificate is issued may by appropriate endorsement made thereon, under the direction of the city council, substitute another vehicle in the place of that for which the certificate was granted. 
(Code 1973, § 16-4; Ord. No. 327, § 4(d), 5-11-1953) 
Sec. 12-94. - License fee. 
(a)  At the time of issuance of a license to an owner of a taxicab, the owner shall pay to the city secretary the sum provided in the city fee schedule for each taxicab to be operated in the city, for a 12-month period ending December 31, provided, if such license is granted for less than the full year, the owner shall pay to the city an amount prorated according to the number of months for which the license is issued. Each owner shall file with the city secretary a statement in writing under oath signed by him showing the make, model, motor number and state license number and the city cab number of each taxicab. If at any time the holder of a taxicab license shall desire to use any additional vehicles under the license, he may do so only after he has made application to the city council for a license to operate such additional vehicles and had his application for such license granted, and he shall furnish to the city secretary the same information regarding such additional vehicles as is required in this section regarding those covered by the original license, and shall pay to the city secretary the fee as provided by this section. 
(b)  The annual fee provided for in subsection (a) of this section shall be due and payable to the city no later than January 31 for the year for which the license is taken out, it being the intention to grant to such licensees a one-month grace period in the payment of such annual fee. 
(Code 1973, § 16-5; Ord. No. 327, § 2(c), 5-11-1953; Ord. No. 425, § I, 3-25-1958) 
Sec. 12-95. - License issuance. 
    Upon presentation of the certificate within 30 days of its date to the city secretary, the city shall issue licenses for the operation of such vehicles as provided in this article after the payment of all fees and compliance with other provisions of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 16-6; Ord. No. 327, § 4(f), 5-11-1953) 
Sec. 12-96. - Determination of number of vehicles. 
    The number of vehicles for hire authorized to operate in the city and for which certificates of public convenience and necessity may be issued under the terms of this article shall be at any time determined by the city council upon proper hearing. 
(Code 1973, § 16-7; Ord. No. 327, § 4(e), 5-11-1953) 
Sec. 12-97. - Insurance or bond. 
(a)  Before a license shall be issued, the applicant shall pay the license fee required by law and furnish to the city, for each such vehicle to be licensed, evidence of the issuance of an insurance policy, or a good and sufficient surety bond, approved by the city attorney as to form, and approved by the city council as to sufficiency, and in the amount hereinafter required, and conditioned that the insurance company or bond surety, shall well and truly pay to the mayor of the city, and to his successors in office, for the benefit of any persons injured by reason of the negligent operation of such vehicle, any amounts which may be awarded by the final judgment of any court of competent jurisdiction against the owner or operator, not exceeding however, for any injury to any person while traveling in a vehicle not exceeding seven passenger capacity, the amount required by state law. 
(b)  The insurance policy or surety bond shall be filed in the office of the city secretary. 
(c)  Such insurance policy or surety bond shall be executed by a solvent insurance company or surety company. An action shall survive in case of the death of the person injured for the benefit of the legal beneficiaries of such person. Such insurance policy or surety bond shall not be exhausted by the first recovery, but shall be subject to successive recoveries. Such insurance shall not be affected by any alterations for the route or termini of such vehicle during the time the policy continues in effect. The insurance policy, or surety bond, shall further provide and operate to the benefit of any person suffering damage to his property through the negligent operation of such vehicle in a sum not exceeding $2,000.00. 
(d)  No insurance company or surety on a surety bond shall cancel any policy or surety bond, unless such insurance company or surety has satisfactorily settled all claims arising under the policy or bond. 
(e)  The city shall not be deemed to have assumed any pecuniary responsibility for the solvency of any insurance company or surety company, or in any manner to have become liable for any sum on account of any such claim, or on account of any act or omission of any officers of the city in connection with any matter relating to such vehicle, nor shall the lawful liability of the owner or operator be in any manner either limited or enlarged, by anything in connection with this article or such insurance policy or bond, but persons having any cause of action secured thereby, shall be authorized to sue upon such insurance policy or surety bond without impleading the city. 
(Code 1973, § 16-8; Ord. No. 327, § 5, 5-11-1953; Ord. No. 488, § 1, 5-12-1959) 
Sec. 12-98. - Cessation of operation. 
(a)  The validity and existence of any license, permit or franchise granted by the city council for the operation of any taxicabs or other vehicles for hire in the city shall be contingent upon the continuous operation under the terms of the license, permit or franchise without interruption or cessation for any period of more than 120 consecutive days, it being the intention hereof that if after the granting of any such license, permit or franchise, service under such license, permit or franchise shall lapse or not be provided by the holder of the license, permit or franchise for 120 consecutive days, the license, permit or franchise shall automatically be cancelled and become null and void and of no force and effect for all purposes. 
(b)  If, after cessation or other interruption of operation under such a license, permit or franchise granted hereunder, the operator thereof resumes providing taxicab or vehicles-for-hire service, such resumption of service must be general in all respects and in good faith, it being the intention hereof that no token or bad faith resumption of service shall toll the running of such 120-day period of suspension of service before automatic cancellation of the license, permit or franchise. The city council, from the evidence it may have before it, shall have full power and authority to determine the question of whether any such resumption of service is in good faith or is provided merely for the purpose of tolling the 120-day period. 
(Code 1973, § 16-9; Ord. No. 327, § 4(f), 5-11-1953; Ord. No. 362, § 1, 9-13-1955) 
Sec. 12-99. - Gross receipts tax. 
    Each owner of a taxicab business holding a license shall make and file an affidavit on the tenth day of each month stating under oath the gross receipts received during the preceding month from the operation of such taxicabs. On or before December 31 next following the date of issuance of each license, all such affidavits will be reviewed and an adjustment will be made between the city and the owner of such taxicabs so that such owner shall pay to the city a total sum, exclusive of the license fee required by section 12-94, equal to one percent of the gross receipts from the operation of his taxicabs in the city, for the period for which a permit was granted. 
(Code 1973, § 16-10; Ord. No. 327, § 2(b), 5-11-1953) 
Sec. 12-100. - Chauffeur's license required. 
    No person shall drive a taxicab upon the streets of the city unless such person operating such taxicab shall first obtain a taxicab chauffeur's license issued by the chief of police. 
(Code 1973, § 16-11; Ord. No. 327, § 6, 5-11-1953; Ord. No. 624, § II, 10-23-1962) 
Sec. 12-101. - Application. 
    It shall be the duty of each driver of a taxicab to apply to the chief of police for a taxicab chauffeur's license upon forms to be furnished giving the name, age, present address, address and place of employment during the past two years, with the reasons for leaving, whether the applicant has been convicted of a felony, or if he has a police record. Such applicant shall likewise attach to his application for a taxicab chauffeur's license affidavits from two reputable citizens attesting to the character of the applicant. He shall also attach to such application a report to his physical condition based upon a complete physical examination made by a licensed physician within 30 days of the date of filing such application, and such report shall contain a statement as to the applicant's visual acuity. Such report must be signed by a licensed physician practicing within the city. 
(Code 1973, § 16-12; Ord. No. 327, § 6(a), 5-11-1953; Ord. No. 624, § II, 10-23-1962) 
Sec. 12-102. - Issuance, term, transferability; denial, appeal. 
(a)  After the application for a taxicab chauffeur's license has been made in accordance with this article, it shall be the duty of the chief of police to determine whether a taxicab chauffeur's license shall be issued to such applicant, which license, if issued, shall run for a period of two years from date of issuance. The license, when issued, shall not be transferable; however, it shall be lawful for the holder of such license to use the same license should he change employment from one operator or owner of taxicabs to another. 
(b)  In the event the chief of police determines that no such license should be issued to such applicant, written notice of such denial by certified U.S. mail shall be given to the applicant who shall have the right of appeal of such denial to the city council by giving written notice of such appeal to the city secretary within 30 days of his receipt of such written denial, which appeal shall be heard by the city council at a regular meeting, within 30 days from receipt of notice of such appeal. 
(Code 1973, § 16-13; Ord. No. 327, § 6(c), 5-11-1953) 
Sec. 12-103. - Fingerprints, photographs. 
    No taxicab chauffeur's license shall be issued to any driver of any taxicab until the police department shall have taken fingerprints and been provided with two photographs of the applicant for such license. 
(Code 1973, § 16-14; Ord. No. 327, § 6(b), 5-11-1953; Ord. No. 624, § II, 10-23-1962) 
Sec. 12-104. - Hiring unlicensed driver; filing drivers' names. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner of a taxicab to employ a driver who has not been licensed as a taxicab chauffeur under the provisions of this article. The names of all drivers shall be filed with the city secretary by the owner or operator. 
(Code 1973, § 16-15; Ord. No. 327, § 6(e), 5-11-1953) 
Sec. 12-105. - Display of license and photograph. 
    It shall be the duty of the driver of a taxicab to have his license, together with his photograph, the size to be prescribed by the city council affixed and displayed in the driving compartment of the taxicab. 
(Code 1973, § 16-16; Ord. No. 327, § 6(d), 5-11-1953) 
Sec. 12-106. - Vehicle lettering. 
    Each owner or operator of a taxicab shall have plainly printed on each such vehicle operated by him a sign giving the name, trade name or firm name under which he operates such vehicle. 
(Code 1973, § 16-17; Ord. No. 327, § 7, 5-11-1953) 
Sec. 12-107. - Vehicle air conditioning and radios. 
    All taxicabs used for hire shall be equipped with operable air conditioning and two-way radios. 
(Code 1973, § 16-18; Ord. No. 327, § 7, 5-11-1953; Ord. No. 827, § 1, 12-23-1966) 
Sec. 12-108. - Ownership information. 
    Each taxicab operator shall file with the city secretary an affidavit disclosing the names and addresses of all owners or persons interested in the business being operated by him, such initial affidavit to be filed when license is granted and an affidavit to be filed immediately upon any change in the ownership of the business. 
(Code 1973, § 16-19; Ord. No. 327, § 8, 5-11-1953) 
Sec. 12-109. - Transporting persons for immoral or unlawful purposes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any taxicab owner or driver to transport or offer to transport or to aid or assist in transporting, directly or indirectly, any person in, on, over or through the streets, alleys or public highways of the city by means of taxicabs for the purpose of lewdness, assignation or prostitution, or for any other unlawful or immoral purpose. 
(Code 1973, § 16-20; Ord. No. 327, § 10, 5-11-1953) 
Sec. 12-110. - Vehicle inspection. 
    It shall be the duty of every person owning a taxicab to have such vehicle inspected every 60 days by the parties to be designated by the city council to determine if such vehicle is in good mechanical condition and safe for use as a taxicab. If such vehicle is found to be in good mechanical condition and safe for use as a taxicab, a certificate of inspection will be issued as evidence thereof. No vehicle shall be operated as a taxicab without the certificate of inspection; and further, such certificate of inspection shall be on display at all times in the taxicab for which the certificate of inspection was issued and a copy of same shall be delivered to the city secretary. 
(Code 1973, § 16-21; Ord. No. 327, § 12, 5-11-1953) 
Sec. 12-111. - Passenger fares; meters; schedule. 
(a)  Each service automobile, taxicab and other motor vehicle used for transportation of passengers for hire within and from the corporate limits of the city, other than busses operated upon regular and fixed schedules, shall be equipped with a mileage and rate meter of a standard and uniform make, manufacture and model approved by the city manager, which meter shall be installed on the right side of the dashboard or at such other place in the vehicle as may be approved by the city manager and shall be clearly visible to the passengers. The meter shall be maintained at all times in good repair, capable of displaying the correct mileage of and charge from each point of departure, throughout and to the termination of each trip. 
(b)  The following schedule of rates shall apply and be charged for transportation of persons and property in such vehicles effective immediately: 
(1)  For the first one-fourth mile (1,320 feet) or fraction thereof, for not more than two persons, the charge shall be $1.25. For each additional one-fourth mile or fraction thereof there shall be an additional charge of $0.25. For more than two persons in one cab, there shall be an additional charge of $0.12. If the trip exceeds ten miles there shall be charged an additional 20 percent of the total metered trip fare. 
(2)  There shall be charged a waiting time fee of $4.80 per hour. The waiting time period to begin when the speed of the taxicab drops below 12 miles per hour thus engaging the waiting time clock. 
(Code 1973, § 16-22; Ord. No. 327, § 13, 5-11-1953; Ord. No. 947, § 1, 2-25-1969; Ord. No. 1121, § 1, 5-22-1973; Ord. No. 1179, § 1, 8-13-1974; Ord. No. 1383, § I, 6-9-1981) 
Sec. 12-112. - Violation; suspension of license of person charged. 
    Any licensed taxicab owner or driver who is charged with the violation of any city ordinance or state law may, in the discretion of the judge of the municipal court, have his license suspended, provided that such suspended owner or driver shall have the right to appeal from the suspension to the city council at its next regular meeting, and the action of the city council upon the suspension shall in all things be final. 
(Code 1973, § 16-23; Ord. No. 327, § 11, 5-11-1953) 
Sec. 12-113. - Punishment; injunction. 
(a)  Any person violating or failing or refusing to comply with any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section 1-14. Each act constituting a violation and each failure or refusal to comply with any provision of this article shall be a separate offense and shall be punished as such. Each charge made and each trip made upon the streets of the city answering a call or carrying a passenger by any person who does not have a written license in full force and effect at the time shall constitute a separate offense under this article. 
(b)  In addition to the remedies provided in subsection (a) of this section, the city may file in the proper court a suit for injunction and may enjoin the use of the streets of the city by any person operating a taxicab when such person at such time does not have a written license in full force and effect procured under the terms and provisions of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 16-24; Ord. No. 327, § 17, 5-11-1953) 
Secs. 12-114-12-139. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - AMUSEMENT DEVICES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of home rule municipalities to regulate the location and conduct of theaters, movie theaters, bowling alleys and other places of public amusement, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 215.074; sports, amusements and entertainment generally, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 2001.001 et seq. 

Sec. 12-140. - Requirement. 
    No person shall operate amusement devices defined in this article within the city without first obtaining a permit and paying the required permit fee. 
(Ord. No. 2000, § 1, 1-28-2003; Ord. No. 2184-B, § 1, 8-14-2012) 
Sec. 12-141. - Definitions. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Amusement redemption machine means a skill or pleasure coin-operated machine that is designed, made, and adapted solely for bona fide amusement purposes, and that by operation of chance or a combination of skill and chance affords the user, in addition to any right of replay, an opportunity to receive exclusively non-cash merchandise prizes, toys, or novelties, or a representation of a value redeemable for those items. 
    Coin-operated machine means and includes a machine or devise operated by the payment or insertion of paper currency or any other consideration. 
    Machine placed in the establishment means a machine physically located in the establishment regardless of whether operational. 
    Representation of value means and includes cash paid under authority of sweepstakes contests as provided in V.T.C.A., Business and Commerce Code ch. 43, or a gift certificate of gift card that is presented to a merchant in exchange for merchandise. 
(b)  Excluded machines. An amusement redemption machine does not include: 
(1)  A machine that awards the user non-cash merchandise prizes, toys, or novelties solely and directly from the machine, including claw, crane, or similar machines; nor 
(2)  A machine from which the opportunity to receive non-cash merchandise prizes, toys, or novelties, or a representation of value redeemable for those items, varies depending upon the user's ability to throw, roll, flip, toss, hit, or drop a ball or other physical object into the machine or a part thereof, including basketball, skeeball, golf, bowling, pusher, or similar machines. 
(Ord. No. 1901, § 1, 11-9-1999; Ord. No. 2000, § 2, 1-28-2003; Ord. No. 2004, § 1, 2-25-2003; Ord. No. 2184-B, §§ 2, 3, 8-14-2012) 
Sec. 12-142. - Local permit fee. 
(a)  Fee. An owner, operator, or lessee of premises on which an amusement redemption machine is made available to others shall be required to secure a permit by paying to the city an annual amusement redemption machine premises permit fee for each machine registered with the county tax assessor/collector's department in the amount provided in the city fee schedule. 
(b)  Expiration and renewal. Permits issued under this article shall automatically expire on the last working day of February of the year next following its issuance, except as otherwise stated herein. Such permit shall also automatically expire if the holder thereof sells, transfers equity, or otherwise disposes of such devises. 
(c)  Refunds and proration. The city shall not refund any portion of an amusement redemption machine premises permit fee after the permit is issued, nor shall it prorate or reduce in amount any fee due to the city except those businesses that begin operation during the middle of the operating year. 
(d)  Machines placed in the establishment after annual permit is obtained. The total fee applicable for the number of machines located on premises with the addition of new machines after the annual permit is obtained or renewed shall be the total fee due upon addition of added machines in one establishment and thereafter the fee due on the last working day of February of the year. Fees will not be prorated. 
(e)  Late penalty. Upon the expiration of a permit, and within 30 days thereafter, the person making the device available to others shall obtain a renewal thereof in the same manner as an original permit if he wishes to continue operating premises on which an amusement redemption machine is made available to others. Failure to pay this fee within 30 days will require such person to pay an additional late fee as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(f)  Sealing. The city shall have the authority to seal any coin-operated machine located at an establishment for which an amusement redemption machine premises permit fee has not been secured. A fee as provided in the city fee schedule will be charged for the release of any machine sealed for non-payment of the amusement redemption machine premises permit fee and assessed late penalties. 
(g)  Posting of permit. The permit shall be conspicuously posted inside the building at the address registered with the county tax assessor/collector's office. 
(h)  Revocation of permit. The city council may revoke any permit to maintain and operate premises on which an amusement redemption machine is made available to others when the licensee has been found guilty by a court of competent jurisdiction of violating any provisions of this article or any applicable state statute. After such conviction, the license may be reissued if the circumstances leading to conviction have been remedied and the premises are being maintained and operated in full compliance with law and this article; provided, however, that an owner, operator, or lessee of premises on which an amusement redemption machine is made available to others, who is found to be in violation of this article based on a finding that the number of amusement redemption machines exceeds the number for which the premises is permitted, shall be required to pay an amount equal to twice the difference of the original permit fee and the permit fee required for the number of machines actually on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 2000, § 3, 1-28-2003; Ord. No. 2004, § 2, 2-25-2003; Ord. No. 2184-B, § 3, 8-14-2012) 
Sec. 12-143. - Occupation tax. 
    Every owner or operator who owns, controls, possesses, exhibits, or who permits to be exhibited in the corporate limits of this city any coin-operated machine which is not exempt from payment by under state law shall pay an annual occupation tax for each machine. 
(Ord. No. 1901, § 2, 11-9-1999) 
Sec. 12-144. - Amount of tax. 
(a)  For each coin-operated machine, the tax shall be $15.00, one-fourth of the amount imposed by state statutes per applicable coin-operated machine, and which, under the statutes of the state, may be imposed by the city. Such tax shall be due and payable annually to the city's tax assessor-collector, or duly designated party, on the first regular day of business following January 1 of each year. 
(b)  Prorated amounts based on the $15.00 tax herewith imposed shall be applied and collected between the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived and January 2000. Upon payment of the tax required by this section, the tax assessor-collector or duly designated person shall issue a receipt showing payment of the tax levy for the coming year which receipt shall be affixed to the duly permitted coin-operated machine. 
(Ord. No. 1901, § 3, 11-9-1999) 
Sec. 12-145. - Untaxed machines prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess or exhibit, within this city, any coin-operated machine subject to the provision of this article without having attached thereto a valid occupational tax receipt showing payment of the tax for the current year. 
(b)  The city police chief, or a duly appointed representative of the city police chief, acting under the request of the tax assessor-collector or duly designated party, shall have the power to seal any coin-operated machine on which the city occupational tax has not been paid. The city police chief, or a duly appointed representative of the city police chief, is authorized to release any machine so sealed upon payment to the tax assessor-collector of all occupational taxes due and payment of a fee as provided in the city fee schedule for each machine so sealed. Whosoever shall break the seal affixed for nonpayment of the occupational tax hereby levied by this article, or whosoever removed a sealed machine from its location when the seal was affixed, shall be deemed in violation of this article and upon conviction shall be assessed a fine not to exceed $200.00. 
(Ord. No. 1901, § 4, 11-9-1999) 
Secs. 12-146-12-173. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SOLICITATION OF CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to license, tax, suppress or otherwise regulate hawkers and peddlers, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 215.031; cancellation of certain home solicited consumer transactions, V.T.C.A., Business and Commerce Code § 601.001 et seq.; certain peddlers regarded as retailers for purposes of sales and use taxes, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 151.024. 

Sec. 12-174. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Charitable contribution is hereby defined pursuant to V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 552.007(c) as being "a contribution to an organization defined as charitable by the standards of the United States Internal Revenue Service." 
(Ord. No. 2082, § 5, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 12-175. - Solicitation in right-of-way prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person other than those specified in sections 12-176 and 12-177 to stand in the right-of-way within the city to solicit a charitable contribution from any occupant of a vehicle without first having obtained the necessary and, hereto established, permit and displaying the day identification tag. 
(Ord. No. 2082, § 4, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 12-176. - Registration of solicitors. 
(a)  Employees or agents of the city shall, before commencing solicitations of contributions on all local streets and highways, register and file an application with the office of the city secretary, ten days or more before conducting the solicitations. The application shall include the following: 
(1)  The date or dates and times when the solicitations will take place. 
(2)  The purpose for the solicitations. 
(3)  Each location at which solicitations are to occur. 
(4)  The number of solicitors to be involved in solicitations at each location. 
(5)  Solicitors under this section shall wear a uniform or identification clearly indicating their association with the city. 
(b)  There shall be no fee nor other requirements for these employees or agents of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2082, § 2, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 12-177. - Regulations for nonprofit solicitors. 
(a)  All other nonprofit organizations that desire to conduct solicitations of charitable contributions as pedestrians upon city streets or highways must comply with all of the following regulations: 
(1)  Register with the office of the city secretary ten days or more before conducting such solicitations. 
(2)  File an application indicating the same requirements established for employees or agents of the city as per section 12-176 and, in addition, provide a copy of the formal documentation from the internal revenue service acknowledging their organization as a nonprofit organization in the state. 
(3)  Furnish to the city proof of liability insurance in the amount of at least $1,000,000.00 to cover the cost of damages that may arise from the solicitation. The insurance provided must also provide coverage against claims against the applicant and claims against the city arising from their permitted solicitation. 
(4)  Pay a fee per day as provided in the city fee schedule during the time they propose to solicit on the streets and highways of the city through the city secretary to cover up to ten solicitors acting on behalf of the qualified organization. No more than ten solicitors for a particular organization will be permitted in a single day within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  Upon filing the required information and fee, the city secretary shall issue a day permit to the applying nonprofit organization and provide personal tags to be worn by the solicitors during solicitation showing the month and day permitted which shall be conspicuous to law enforcement officers. 
(Ord. No. 2082, § 3, 9-12-2006)

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 14-40-14-66. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COURT TECHNOLOGY FUND 

Sec. 14-67. - Established. 
    A municipal court technology fund is hereby established pursuant to the authority given to the city council by Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 102.0172. The fund may be maintained in an interest bearing account and may be maintained in the general revenue account. 
(Ord. No. 2030, § 1, 7-13-2004) 
Sec. 14-68. - Amount payable upon conviction of misdemeanor. 
    Defendants convicted of a misdemeanor offense in municipal court shall pay a municipal technology fee as provided in the city fee schedule as a cost of court. The clerk of the court shall collect the fee and pay the fee to the finance director of the city who shall deposit the fee into the municipal court technology fund. A defendant is considered convicted if: 
(1)  Judgment, sentence, or both are imposed on the person; 
(2)  The person is placed on deferred disposition; or 
(3)  The court defers final disposition or imposition of the judgment and sentence. 
(Ord. No. 2030, § 2, 7-13-2004) 
Sec. 14-69. - Disposition of funds; administration. 
    The fund shall be used only for the purpose of financing the purchase of or maintaining technology enhancements for the municipal court of the city. "Technology enhancements" shall include any and all items described in Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 102.0172(d). The fund shall be administered by or under the direction of the city council of the city. The purpose of the use of any funds remaining in the fund shall continue to be used and administered as required by this article and for that purpose this article remains in effect. 
(Ord. No. 2030, §§ 3, 7, 7-13-2004) 
Secs. 14-70-14-96. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COURT BUILDING SECURITY FUND 

Sec. 14-97. - Established. 
    The city has created and established a municipal court building security fund pursuant to Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 102.017. 
(Ord. No. 2031, § 1, 7-13-2004) 
Sec. 14-98. - Fee assessed; collection. 
(a)  The municipal court shall assess a municipal court building security fee in the amount provided by the city fee schedule against all defendants convicted of a misdemeanor offense by the municipal court. Each misdemeanor conviction shall be subject to a separate assessment of the fee. A person is considered to have been convicted in a case if: 
(1)  Judgment, sentence, or both are imposed on the person; 
(2)  The person receives deferred disposition; or 
(3)  The court defers final disposition or imposition of the judgment and sentence. 
(b)  The municipal court clerk is hereby authorized and required to collect the fee and to pay same to the treasury of the city. All fees so collected and paid over to the treasury of the city shall be segregated in the fund. 
Sec. 14-99. - Disposition of funds; administration. 
    The fund shall be administered by or under the direction of the city council of the city. The fund shall be used only for the purpose of financing the purchase of security devices or services for the building or buildings housing the municipal court of the city. "Security devices or services" shall include any and all items described in Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 102.017(d). 
(Ord. No. 2031, § 1, 7-13-2004) 
Chapter 16 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AND SERVICES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Texas Disaster Act of 1975, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 418.001 et seq.; local emergency management, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 418.101 et seq.; statewide mutual aid system, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 418.111; disaster mitigation, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 418.121 et seq.; citizen duties and claims of compensation resulting from disasters, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 418.151 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Fees for emergency medical services. 
    Fees for emergency medical services shall be as established by the city council from time to time as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Ord. No. 1792, § I, 10-25-1994) 
Secs. 16-2-16-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OPERATIONAL EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT ORGANIZATION 

Sec. 16-21. - Director; coordinator. 
(a)  The city has established the office of city-county emergency management director, which shall be held by the mayor in accordance with state law. The city and the county each contribute one-half of the director's compensation and participate in the city-county emergency management plan implemented by the director. 
(b)  The director is responsible for a program of comprehensive emergency management within the city, and in the county to the extent authorized by the county, and for carrying out the duties and responsibilities set forth in this article. 
(c)  The duties and responsibilities of the emergency management director shall include the following: 
(1)  Conduct of an ongoing survey of actual or potential hazards which threaten life and property within the city and an ongoing program of identifying and requiring or recommending the implementation of measures which would tend to prevent the occurrence or reduce the impact of such hazards if a disaster did occur. 
(2)  Supervision of the development and approval of an emergency management plan for the city, and shall recommend for adoption by the city council all mutual aid arrangements deemed necessary for the implementation of such plan. 
(3)  Authority to declare a local state of disaster. The declaration may not be continued or renewed for a period in excess of seven days except by or with the consent of the city council. Any order or proclamation declaring, continuing, or terminating a local state of disaster shall be given prompt and general publicity and shall be filed promptly with the city secretary. 
(4)  Issuance of necessary proclamations, regulations or directives which are necessary for carrying out the purposes of this article. Such proclamations, regulations, or directives shall be disseminated promptly by means calculated to bring its contents to the attention of the general public and, unless circumstances attendant of the disaster prevent or impede, promptly filed with the city secretary. 
(5)  Direction and control of the operations of the city emergency management organization, as well as the training of emergency management personnel. 
(6)  Determination of all questions of authority and responsibility that may arise within the emergency management organization of the city. 
(7)  Maintenance of liaison with other municipal, county, district, state, regional or federal, emergency management organizations. 
(8)  Marshaling of all necessary personnel, equipment or supplies from any department of the city to aid in the carrying out of the provisions of the emergency management plan. 
(9)  Supervision of the drafting and execution of mutual aid agreements, in cooperation with the representatives of the state and of other local political subdivisions of the state, and the drafting and execution, if deemed desirable, of an agreement with the county in which the city is located and with other municipalities within the county, for the county-wide coordination of emergency management efforts. 
(10)  Supervision of, and final authorization for, the procurement of all necessary supplies and equipment, including acceptance of private contributions which may be offered for the purpose of improving emergency management within the city. 
(11)  Authorizing of agreements, after approval of the city attorney, for use of private property for public shelter and other purposes. 
(12)  Survey of the availability of existing personnel, equipment, supplies and services which could be used during a disaster, as provided for herein. 
(13)  Other requirements as specified in V.T.C.A., Government Code § 418.001. 
(Ord. No. 1561, §§ 1, 2, 6-24-1986) 
State Law reference- Municipal emergency management programs, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 418.103; emergency management directors, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 418.1015. 
Sec. 16-22. - Officers and employees; functions and duties. 
    The operational emergency management organization of the city shall consist of the officers and employees of the city so designated by the director in the emergency management plan, as well as organized volunteer groups. The functions and duties of this organization shall be distributed among such officers and employees in accordance with the terms of the emergency management plan. 
(Ord. No. 1561, § 1, 6-24-1986) 
Sec. 16-23. - Emergency management plan. 
(a)  A comprehensive emergency management plan for the city shall be developed and maintained in a current state. The plan shall set forth the form of the organization, establish and designate divisions and functions, assign responsibilities, tasks, duties, and powers, and designate officers and employees to carry out the provisions of this article. As provided by state law, the plan shall follow the standards and criteria established by the state division of emergency management. Insofar as possible, the form of organization, titles and terminology shall conform to the recommendations of the state division of emergency management. 
(b)  It is the duty of all departments and agencies to perform the functions assigned by the plan and to maintain their portion of the plan in a current state of readiness at all times. 
(c)  The emergency management plan shall be considered supplementary to this article and have the effect of law during the time of a disaster. 
(Ord. No. 1561, § 3, 6-24-1986) 
State Law reference- Declaration of local disaster, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 418.108; local and interjurisdictional emergency management plans, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 418.106. 
Sec. 16-24. - Article supersedes other law during periods of emergency. 
    At all times when the orders, rules, and regulations made and promulgated pursuant to this article shall be in effect, they shall supersede and override all existing ordinances, orders, rules, and regulations insofar as the latter may be inconsistent therewith. 
(Ord. No. 1561, § 4, 6-24-1986) 
Sec. 16-25. - No liability created by article or assistance with local emergencies. 
(a)  This article is an exercise by the city of its governmental functions for the protection of the public peace, health, and safety and neither the city, the agents and representatives of the city, nor any individual, receiver, firm, partnership, corporation, association, or trustee, nor any of the agents thereof, in good faith carrying out, complying with or attempting to comply with, any order, rule, or regulation promulgated pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be liable for any damage sustained to persons as the result of the activity. 
(b)  Any person owning or controlling real estate of other premises who voluntarily and without compensation grants to the city a license of privilege, or otherwise permits the city to inspect, designate and use the whole or any part or parts of such real estate or premises for the purpose of sheltering persons during an actual, impending or practice enemy attack or natural or man-made disaster shall, together with his successors in interest, if any, not be civilly liable for the death of, or injury to, any person on or about such real estate or premises under such license, privilege or other permission or for loss of, or damage to, the property of such person. 
(Ord. No. 1561, § 5, 6-24-1986) 
Sec. 16-26. - Funding; expenditures. 
    No person shall have the right to expend any public funds of the city in carrying out any emergency management activity authorized by this article without prior approval by the city council, nor shall any person have any right to bind the city by contract, agreement or otherwise without prior and specific approval of the city council unless during a declared disaster. During a declared disaster, the mayor may expend or commit public funds of the city when deemed prudent and necessary for the protection of health, life or property. 
(Ord. No. 1561, § 6, 6-24-1986) 
Sec. 16-27. - Obstruction of personnel, impersonation of personnel, and warning simulations. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person willfully to obstruct, hinder, or delay any member of the emergency management organization in the enforcement of any rule or regulation issued pursuant to this article, or to do any act forbidden by any rule or regulation issued pursuant to the authority contained in this article. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to wear, carry or display any emblem, insignia or any other means of identification as a member of the emergency management organization of the city, unless authority to do so has been granted to such person by the proper officials. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any unauthorized person to operate a siren or other device so as to simulate a warning. 
(Ord. No. 1561, § 7, 6-24-1986) 
State Law reference- Interference with public duties, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 38.15; use of siren, whistle and bells restricted, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 547.501; impersonating public servant prohibited, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 37.11. 
Sec. 16-28. - Conflicts with state, federal and military law and rules. 
    This article shall not be construed so as to conflict with any state for federal statute or with any military or naval order, rule, or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 1561, § 9, 6-24-1986) 
Secs. 16-29-16-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ALARM SYSTEM MANAGEMENT 

Sec. 16-60. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm protective service means any service whereby the person providing such service installs, services, repairs, maintains, sells, replaces, or responds to an alarm system or which causes any of the activities to take place. 
    Alarm site means a single premises, residence, or location served by an alarm system or systems that are under the control of one owner. 
    Alarm system means any assembly of equipment, device or devices arranged to signal the presence of a hazard requiring urgent attention and to which police respond. The term "alarm system" shall include the terms "automatic holdup alarm system," "burglar alarm system," "holdup alarm system," and "manual holdup alarm system" and specifically excludes: 
(1)  Fire alarm systems and other alarm systems that monitor temperature, humidity, or any other condition not directly related to the detection of an unauthorized intrusion into a premises or an attempted robbery at a premises. 
(2)  An alarm system installed upon the premises occupied by the United States government, the this state, the city, or any county government or school districts situated within the corporate limits of the city. 
(3)  An alarm system installed on a motor vehicle. 
    Alarm system user means the owner of the property on which an alarm system or systems is maintained within the corporate limits of the city. 
    Automatic holdup alarm system means an alarm system in which the signal transmission is initiated by the action of a robber. 
    Burglar alarm system means an alarm system signaling an entry or attempted entry into an area protected by the alarm system. 
    False alarm means any activation of an alarm system through mechanical or electronic failure, malfunction, improper installation, negligence of the owner, agent, or person in control of the property or any other such activation which is not a result of an emergency or threat of emergency for which the alarm system was designed to give notice and which the responding police officer finds no evidence of any criminal activity. The term "false alarm" shall not include any activation of an alarm system which is caused by hurricanes, tornadoes, or earthquakes. 
    Five minute shutoff means an automatic device associated with an alarm system which automatically causes the alarm to shut off and discontinue the emission of an audible signal after a period of tome not to exceed five minutes of continuous operation. 
    Holdup alarm system means an alarm system signaling a robbery or attempted robbery. 
    Manual holdup alarm system means an alarm system in which the signal transmission is initiated by the direct action of the person attacked or by an observer of the attack. 
    Permit means a certificate of authorization issued by the police department to the owner, agent, or person in control of the property which authorizes the operation of an alarm system or systems at an alarm site. 
    Permit holder means any individual, corporation, partnership or other legal entity to whom an alarm system permit is issued. 
(Ord. No. 1819, § 1, 12-12-1995) 
Sec. 16-61. - Alarm system permits. 
(a)  No person shall operate, cause to be operated, or permit the operation of an alarm system or systems at an alarm site unless a valid permit has been issued by the police department for such system. This requirement shall not be applicable to an alarm protective service unless the alarm protective service is the owner of the property which the alarm system is designed to protect. An alarm system user shall be in violation of this article if he permits the operation of such system without a proper permit. 
(b)  An alarm system user or his agent shall obtain a permit for each alarm site. 
(c)  Application for a permit for the operation of an alarm system or systems at an alarm site shall be made with the police department by the owner having control over the property on which the alarm system is to be installed and operated. Application shall be made in writing on a form designed by the city. 
(d)  The police department shall issue a permit to the individual, corporation or other legal entity in control of the property to be protected upon submission in person of a completed application and payment of the appropriate fee, unless any statement made on the application is incomplete or false. 
(e)  The police department shall treat all information on the application as confidential. 
(f)  Any permit issued pursuant to the article shall be applicable only to the permit holder and is not transferable. 
(g)  Each permit issued to an alarm system user shall be valid for one year from the date of issuance. The permit holder is required to obtain a renewal permit within ten days upon expiration. 
(h)  Each permit automatically becomes void upon the occurrence of any of the following: 
(1)  Control of protected property is transferred from the permit holder; 
(2)  Permit holder voluntarily discontinues services provided by a particular alarm protective service, or disconnected the alarm system; 
(3)  Revocation of the permit by the police department pursuant to this article. 
(i)  Each permit holder shall notify the police department of any change of information, or of any occurrence that voids the current permit. 
(j)  The fee for a permit issued or renewed pursuant to this article shall be as set forth in the city fee schedule. 
(Ord. No. 1819, § 2, 12-12-1995) 
Sec. 16-62. - Permit revocation. 
(a)  The city police chief may revoke an alarm system permit if he determines that: 
(1)  There is a false statement of a material matter on the application for a permit; 
(2)  The permit holder has violated this article or any of its provisions; or 
(3)  The permit holder has failed to make timely payment of a service fee assessed under this article. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any permit to operate an alarm system during the period in which his alarm permit is revoked. 
(Ord. No. 1819, § 4, 12-12-1995) 
Sec. 16-63. - Appeal of permit denial or revocation. 
(a)  If the city police chief refuses to issue or revokes a permit, he shall send to the applicant or permit holder by certified mail, return receipt requested, written notice of his action and a statement of the right an appeal. The applicant or permit holder may appeal the decision of the city police chief to the city manager by filing with the city manager a written request for a hearing, setting forth the reasons for the appeal, within ten days after receipt of the notice from the city police chief. The filing of a request for an appeal hearing with the city manager stays an action of the city police chief is revoking a permit until the city manager or his designated representative makes a final decision. If a request for an appeal hearing is not made within the ten-day period, the action of the city police chief is final. 
(b)  The city manager or his representative shall serve as hearing officer at an appeal and consider evidence by any interested person. The formal rules of evidence do not apply at any appeal hearing; the hearing officer shall make his decision on the basis of a preponderance of the evidence presented at the hearing. The hearing officer must render a decision within 30 days after the request for an appeal hearing is filed. The hearing officer shall affirm, reverse, or modify the action of the city police chief. The decision of the hearing officer is final as to administrative remedies with the city. 
(Ord. No. 1819, § 5(A), (B), 12-12-1995) 
Sec. 16-64. - False alarm response service fees; appeal. 
(a)  Service fees for alarm responses shall be in the amount provided in the city fee schedule. A permit holder will not be assessed a service fee for a response to notification of the activation of an alarm system if the permit holder shows to the police chief or his designated representative that the activation was not a false alarm and any response by the police department to such notification of an alarm system will not be included in determining the service fee set out above. For the purposes of determining the service fee, the burden shall be on the permit holder to prove that the activation of the alarm system was not a false alarm. 
(b)  Any permit holder aggrieved by the decision to assess a service fee by the city police chief or his designated representative as provided for in this article, may appeal the decision to the city manager by filing with the city manager a written request for a hearing, setting forth the reasons for the appeal within ten days after the city police chief or his designated representative renders the decision. The filing of a request for an appeal hearing with the city manager stays an action of the city police chief in assessing a service fee until the city manager or his designated representative makes a final decision. If a request for an appeal hearing is not made within the ten-day period, the action of the city police chief or his designated representative is final. 
(Ord. No. 1819, §§ 3, 5(A), 12-12-1995) 
Sec. 16-65. - Rules, standards and procedures may be established by police chief. 
    The city police chief may promulgate regulations reasonable necessary to further the enforcement of this article. In addition, the city police chief may set reasonable standards and procedures to be followed by any alarm protective service when giving notice to the police department of activation on an alarm system. Such standards and procedures shall be set out in writing and made available to any alarm system business requesting same. 
(Ord. No. 1819, §§ 6(A), 7, 12-12-1995) 
Sec. 16-66. - Automatic dialing devices prohibited. 
    No person shall operate or cause to be operated any automatic dialing devise which when activated uses a telephone devise or attachment to automatically select a telephone line leading into the communication center of the police department and then transmits any prerecorded message or signal. 
(Ord. No. 1819, § 6(B), 12-12-1995) 
Sec. 16-67. - Alarms must emit audible sound; five minute shut-off required. 
    All alarms systems which emit an audible sound shall have a five-minute shut-off. 
(Ord. No. 1819, § 6(C), 12-12-1995) 
Chapter 18 - ENVIRONMENT[1]

State Law reference- Texas Clean Air Act, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 382.001 et seq.; outdoor burning, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 382.018; pollution prevention, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 361.501 et seq.; Flood Control and Insurance Act, V.T.C.A., Water Code § 16.311 et seq.; authorizing municipalities to take all necessary and reasonable actions to comply with the requirements and criteria of the National Flood Insurance Program, V.T.C.A., Water Code § 16.315; Geothermal Resources Act, V.T.C.A., Natural Resources Code § 141.001 et seq.; water quality control, V.T.C.A., Water Code § 26.001. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 18-1-18-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FLOOD PREVENTION AND CONTROL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-19. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alluvial fan flooding means flooding occurring on the surface of an alluvial fan or similar landform which originates at the apex and is characterized by high-velocity flows; active processes of erosion, sediment transport, and deposition; and unpredictable flow paths. 
    Apex means a point on an alluvial fan or similar landform below which the flow path of the major stream that formed the fan becomes unpredictable and alluvial fan flooding can occur.
