Sec. 30-119. - Declaring certain property a nuisance; authorizing impoundment. 
    Any vehicle or other property or obstruction, placed, left, standing, parked, erected or lying in violation of any ordinance of the city or left unattended for more than 48 continuous hours in or on any public street, alley, sidewalk, park, or other public place of the city is declared to be a nuisance, and any such property when so found shall be removed summarily by any police officer of the city and taken to the police pound and shall be kept there until redeemed or sold as herein provided. 
(Code 1973, 11-42; Ord. No. 1103, § 2, 1-23-1973) 
State Law reference- Junked vehicles declared public nuisance, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.071; authority to take abandoned motor vehicles into custody, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.011. 
Sec. 30-120. - Lien on impounded property. 
    The city shall have a lien on such impounded personal property for all costs incurred in impounding, storing, advertising, selling and providing notices with regard to such property and such lien shall be prior and superior to all other liens of every kind, save and except liens of ad valorem taxes, and the city may retain possession thereof until all costs are paid and may sell the same as herein provided. 
Sec. 30-121. - Notice of sale of property other than motor vehicles. 
(a)  When any personal property, other than motor vehicles, is not redeemed within 60 days after being impounded, the chief of police shall sell the same at public auction to satisfy the lien of the city. Before selling such personal property, the chief of police shall post two notices thereof in conspicuous places as determined by the city council, the same being the entrance of the city hall, and shall cause a copy thereof to be published in a newspaper published in the city once a week for two consecutive weeks, the date of the first publication to be at least 14 days prior to the day of the auction sale. 
(b)  The notice of sale shall describe the impounded property, state that the same is unredeemed, state that the same will be sold at public auction, designate the place of sale, and state a time and date of sale which shall not be less than 14 days from the date of posting such notices as herein required. 
Sec. 30-122. - Notice of sale of motor vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the chief of police to submit to the state highway department and similar agency of the proper state when the vehicle is from another state all information in his possession concerning the vehicle and to request that the department supply to him all information the records of the department contain on the vehicle. 
(b)  Except as otherwise specifically provided by statute, immediately on receipt of such information, and not more than ten days from the date of impoundment, the chief of police shall notify the owner and lienholders as shown by the records of the department by registered mail with return receipt requested that the vehicle has been impounded and the provisions of this division in regard to redemption and sale of impounded property. The notice under this section shall include all information required by V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.012. 
(c)  If the identity of the last registered owner cannot be determined, if the registration has no address for the owner, or the determination with reasonable certainty of the identity and address of all lienholders is impossible, notice shall be published, not more than ten days from the date of impoundment, in a newspaper of general circulation within the city. The notice under this section shall include all information required by V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.012. 
(d)  In the event a motor vehicle has not been redeemed within 20 days from receipt of the return receipt of notice of non-delivery of the registered mail or 20 days from the date of publication of the notice, the chief of police shall prepare a notice of sale of such vehicle, in the manner prescribed in this division for other personal property, shall send a copy of the notice to owner and lienholders, as shown by the records of the highway department, by registered mail, and shall post and advertise the notices in the manner required in the preceding section. Notice by registered mail to the address shown on the records of the highway department shall constitute notice of the pending sale to such owner and lienholders. 
(Code 1973, 11-43; Ord. No. 1103, § 3, 1-23-1973) 
State Law reference- Seizure and auction of motor vehicles, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.014 et seq. 
Sec. 30-123. - Sale of property. 
    When any impounded property, including motor vehicles, is not redeemed by the date and time designated in the notice of sale, the chief of police shall sell the property at public auction, and, as city auctioneer, shall execute bill of sale of the property to the purchaser thereof; provided, he shall not execute or deliver any but a conditional bill of sale unless and until the title of the buyer has become absolute by an expiration of 30 days in time, exclusive of the day of sale, without being redeemed by the owner of the impounded property. 
Sec. 30-124. - Redemption. 
    The owner or any person legally entitled to possession of personal property impounded pursuant to this article may redeem the same as follows: 
(1)  Before sale. By paying to the chief of police the impounding fee and any other actual expenses incurred by the city in impounding and keeping the impounded property, as determined by the chief of police. 
(2)  After sale. By paying to the buyer at the auction sale double the amount paid by him for such personal property and any reasonable expenses incurred by him for keeping same; providing that the property must be redeemed from the auction buyer within 30 days after the date of the auction sale, excluding the date of sale; otherwise, title to the property shall become absolute in the auction buyer. 
Sec. 30-125. - Records and fees. 
    The chief of police shall keep a record book which shall contain a description of all property impounded, the date and time of such impounding, the date notices of sale were posted and advertised and mailed to owners and lienholders, the return of receipts of registered notices, the date at auction, the amount realized for each article at such sale, the name and address of the owner and lienholders, if known, the name and address of the auction buyer, and any such other information as he may deem necessary. Fees charged under this division shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1973, 11-45; Ord. No. 1103, § 5, 1-23-1973) 
Chapter 32 - OFFENSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Concurrent jurisdiction of municipal court concerning certain violations of state statutes, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 29.003(b); municipal authority for regulation of firearms and explosives, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 229.001; municipal regulation of discharge of firearms, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 229.002; municipal authority for regulation of nuisances and disorderly conduct, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 217.001 et seq.; juvenile curfews in general law municipalities, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 341.905; review of juvenile curfew orders or ordinances, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 370.002; municipal policy regarding enforcement of drug laws, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 370.003; municipality may not enact or enforce a law making conduct covered under state Penal Code an offense subject to criminal penalty, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 1.08; Weapons, V.T.C.A., Penal Code ch. 46; Controlled Substances Act, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code ch. 481; Simulated Controlled Substances Act, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code ch. 482. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 32-1. - Loitering. 
    It is unlawful for any person within the city at nighttime to be in or about public or private buildings or premises, where he has no right or permission to be, under suspicious circumstances, and without being able to give a satisfactory account of the same. Violation of this section is punishable by a fine of up to $200.00. 
(Code 1973, 11-1; Ord. No. 759, § 1, 7-27-1965) 
Sec. 32-2. - Discharging firearms or air guns. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to fire or discharge any gun, pistol, rifle or other firearm of any description within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to shoot or discharge, any air gun, air rifle or BB gun of any description within the corporate limits of the city. 
(c)  This section shall not apply when the firing, shooting or discharging of the arms described herein is done in the necessary and lawful protection of persons, premises or property. 
(d)  There shall be exempt from the provisions of this section all commercial shooting galleries, pistol ranges, trap shooting, and skeet shooting establishments as may be established and operated in the city, provided the location of such commercial shooting gallery, pistol range, trap shooting or skeet shooting establishment is in full compliance with the zoning ordinance of the city and the building and fixtures of such establishment comply with the building code of the city, and all equipment used in connection with such business is approved by the city. 
(Code 1973, 11-14; Ord. No. 1129, § 4, 8-14-1973) 
Secs. 32-3-32-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES 

Sec. 32-26. - Sale, delivery, offer or gift prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to possess to sell, offer to sell, deliver or to give the herein described product containing some or all products containing some or all of the above substance that are currently being marketed under the following commercial names: "K-2," "K-2 SUMMIT," "K-2 SEX," "GENIE," "DASCENTS," "ZOHAI," "SAGE," "SPICE," "KO KNOCK-OUT 2," "SPICE GOLD," "SPICE DIAMOND," "YUCATAN FIRE," "SOLAR FLARE," "PEP SPICE," "FIRE N' ICE," and "SALVIA DIVINORUM". 
(Ord. No. 2179, § 2, 11-9-2010) 
Sec. 32-27. - Intentional intoxication by inhalation prohibited. 
    No person shall, for the purpose of causing a condition of intoxication, euphoria, excitement, exhilaration, stupefaction, or dulling of the senses or nervous system, intentionally smell or inhale the fumes from any glue or spray paint. 
(Ord. No. 1336, § 3, 3-27-1980) 
Sec. 32-28. - Possession for intentional misuse prohibited. 
    No person shall for the purpose of violating or aiding another to violate any provision of this article, intentionally possess, buy, sell, transfer possession, or receive possession of any glue or spray paint. 
(Ord. No. 1336, § 4, 3-27-1980) 
Sec. 32-29. - Use by minors regulated. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section and section 32-30, no person under 18 years of age shall possess or buy any glue or spray paint. 
(b)  Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section and section 32-30, no person shall sell or transfer possession of any glue or spray paint to another person under 18 years of age. 
(c)  Provided, however, a person may sell or transfer possession of glue or spray paint to a person under 18 years of age for model building or other lawful use where the minor is accompanied by his parent or guardian. 
(Ord. No. 1336, § 5, 3-27-1980) 
Sec. 32-30. - Violation and penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $200.00. 
(Ord. No. 1336, § 6, 3-27-1980) 
Secs. 32-31-32-48. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CURFEW FOR MINORS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to establish a juvenile curfew, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 341.905; requirement that juvenile curfew ordinances be reviewed and readopted every three years, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 370.002. 

Sec. 32-49. - Loitering of minors prohibited. 
(a)  No person under the age of 17 years shall loiter about the public streets, avenues, alleys, parks, vacant lots, unsupervised places or any other place to which the public is admitted, whether with or without the payment of any consideration for such admission within the city between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. on weekdays and between the hours of midnight and 6:00 a.m. on Friday and Saturday nights when not accompanied by his parent, legal guardian, having legal custody and control of such person, or by the spouse of such person. 
(b)  It is defense to prosecution under this article that the minor was: 
(1)  Accompanied by the minor's parent; 
(2)  In a motor vehicle engaged in interstate travel, beginning, ending, or passing through city; 
(3)  Engaged in a n employment activity, including, but not limited to newspaper delivery, and was using a direct route; 
(4)  Involved in an emergency; 
(5)  On the driveway or yard of the minor's residence or on the sidewalk abutting the minor's residence; 
(6)  Attending an official school, civil, or religious, or recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the city, a civic organization, school district, or another similar activity that takes responsibility for the minor, or going to or returning home from, taking a direct route, an official school, civil, religious, or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the city, a civic organization, school district, or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor; 
(7)  Attending or traveling directly to or from an activity involving the exercise of First Amendment rights protected by the United states Constitution, including the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech and the right of assembly; 
(8)  Married or had been married or had disabilities of minority removed in accordance with state law; or 
(9)  Accompanied by a person of at least 21 years of age, and the minor was carrying a written communication signed by the parent stating the name of the person who is at least 21 years of age and accompanying the minor and that the named minor has consent to be in the company of the named person. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 8-26-1986) 
Sec. 32-50. - Responsibility of parents. 
    It is unlawful and a violation of this article for any parent or person in loco parentis having the legal care, custody and control of any person under the age of 17 years to knowingly permit, aid, abet or encourage such person described in section 32-49 to violate any of its provisions. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 2, 8-26-1986) 
Sec. 32-51. - Loitering defined. 
    The term "loiter" as used in section 32-49 means to idle, to loaf, to stand idly by, or to walk, drive or ride about aimlessly without lawful purpose and or specific destination. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 3, 8-26-1986) 
Sec. 32-52. - Not a limitation. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed in any way limiting the present power of the right of law enforcement officers to make such investigations, detentions or arrests. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 4, 8-26-1986) 
Sec. 32-53. - Penalty clause. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article, upon conviction thereof, shall be found guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be assessed a fine in a sum not exceeding $200.00, and each violation shall be considered a separate offense, provided that any such person falling within the age classification of a delinquent child under the laws of this state and amendments thereof, shall be proceeded against as a delinquent child. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 6, 8-26-1986) 
Chapter 36 - PARKS, RECREATION AND OTHER CITY FACILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal parks and other recreational and cultural resources generally, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 306.001 et seq.; municipal authority to acquire and maintain parks, museums, and historic sites, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 331.001 et seq.; public use of municipal recreational facilities, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 331.007; municipal parks outside municipal limits, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 315.001; municipal recreational programs and facilities, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 332.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 36-1. - Assembly Hall. 
    Fees for rental of the Assembly Hall shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Ord. No. 1505, §§ I, II, 8-28-1984) 
Sec. 36-2. - City golf course. 
(a)  The John C. Beasley Municipal Golf Course in Veterans Memorial Park may be used for golf only. No one may play without paying green fees unless previously approved for a specific purpose by the city council. 
(b)  Fees for use of the municipal golf course shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. One quarterly membership fee payable in advance shall include an individual and any members of their immediate family including spouse, or children up to 18 years of age. Membership fees are not pro-rated, refundable, or transferable. Purchase of a membership entitles the member to play without payment of normal green fees, but does not constitute a waiver of any other established normal fee. 
(Ord. No. 1730, § XII, 8-11-1992; Ord. No. 1779, 6-28-1994; Ord. No. 1832, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 1833, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 1839, 12-17-1996; Ord. No. 1856, 9-9-1997; Ord. No. 1887, 4-13-1999; Ord. No. 2015, 10-14-2003) 
Secs. 36-3-36-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY PARKS 

Sec. 36-23. - City park pavilions. 
(a)  Veterans Memorial Park Pavilions (Pavilions No. 1 and 2) are rented on a first come first serve basis. Reservations will not be made by telephone. Use of these pavilions is by reservation only. There shall be three portable picnic tables at each pavilion and these tables shall not be moved off the pavilion area. The concrete table and bar-b-que pit are part of the pavilion. 
(b)  The rental fee is as provided in the city fee schedule. Renters intending to cancel their reservations must call ten days prior to date reserved. Those renters failing to abide by this cancellation requirement will not be given a refund. All checks, money orders, drafts for rental use shall be made payable to the city. It shall be acknowledged by all renters that Veterans Memorial Park hours are from 7:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. and that the hours are subject to change. 
(c)  Renters of pavilions in Veterans Memorial Park must come by the city manager's office to make the reservations during regular city hall business hours (Monday through Friday from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. except between the hour of 12:00 noon and 1:00 p.m. and on designated holidays.) 
(Ord. of 10-23-1990, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 1730, § II, 8-11-1992) 
Sec. 36-24. - General park use regulations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to do any of the following in any city park: 
(1)  Hunt, shoot or kill birds, animals, or game of any sort; 
(2)  Fish on the golf course lakes in Veterans Memorial Park (or any other body of water on grounds maintained by the city); 
(3)  Pick, cut, or otherwise mutilate any wild flowers, trees, rocks, or shrubs; 
(4)  Willfully injure, destroy, or attempt to injure or destroy any property of any kind; 
(5)  Bring or use glass bottles or glass containers; 
(6)  Use or display firearms; 
(7)  Use or display fireworks except in compliance with this Code; 
(8)  Litter or otherwise fail to place all trash and garbage in appropriate trash containers; 
(9)  Engage in horseback riding; 
(10)  Have any pet in the city parks except on a leash; 
(11)  Climb over, under, or through any fence, structure, building, or water gap on all city parks and its perimeter fencing; 
(12)  Make loud noises, to cause unnecessary noises, and to cause public nuisance; or 
(13)  Wade, or swim in any body of water on grounds maintained by the city. 
(Ord. of 10-23-1990, §§ 3-17; Ord. No. 1730, §§ I, III, IV, VI-XVII, 8-11-1992) 
Sec. 36-25. - Alcoholic beverages. 
    Alcoholic beverages will not be allowed in Veterans Memorial Park at the two little league fields, the junior football, or the Babe Ruth field. 
(Ord. of 10-23-1990, § 14; Ord. No. 1730, § XIV, 8-11-1992) 
Sec. 36-26. - Use of picnic shelters. 
    Picnic shelters on all city parks are intended for public use. Tables shall not be moved off picnic shelters. All picnic areas are to be left clean. 
(Ord. of 10-23-1990, § 15; Ord. No. 1730, § XV, 8-11-1992) 
Sec. 36-27. - Ballfield use. 
    No person or group of persons shall have access to any ballfield without the specific permission of the organization or league that contracts with the city for operation and maintenance. 
(Ord. of 10-23-1990, § 20; Ord. No. 1730, § XX, 8-11-1992) 
Sec. 36-28. - Park hours. 
    Veterans Memorial Park hours are from 7:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. Park hours are subject to change. 
(Ord. of 10-23-1990, § 23) 
Sec. 36-29. - Vehicle use. 
(a)  Travel on city parks is limited to designated and authorized roads. It is unlawful for any person to drive or tow a motor vehicle, motorcycle, motor scooter, wagon, trailer or any other wheeled carrier or vehicle in and upon the public parks, in the city, except upon designated roadways and parking areas thereof. 
(b)  All vehicles on city parks must be properly licensed for street operation. It is unlawful for any person to use off-road vehicles on city parks. 
(c)  Parking on city parks is limited to designated areas. It shall be unlawful for operators of authorized vehicles to park in non-designated areas. 
(d)  It is unlawful for any operator of an authorized vehicle to travel at a speed greater than 15 miles per hour on any city park. 
(Code 1973, § 17-10; Ord. No. 753, § II, 5-11-1965; Ord. of 10-23-1990, § 18; Ord. No. 1730, §§ XVIII, XIX, 8-11-1992) 
Secs. 36-30-36-46. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CITY SWIMMING POOL 

Sec. 36-47. - Operation schedule. 
(a)  The pool will open for late afternoon and weekend swimming during the later part of April or early May. The pool will open for the following schedule once school dismisses for the summer for the duration of the summer recess: 
12:00 noon to 8:00 p.m. Tuesday through Saturday 2:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m. Sundays Closed Mondays Changes to the regular schedule may be made and posted at the pool for holidays, such as July 4 which occur during the summer.  
(b)  The pool's operating schedule is subject to weather conditions and coordination with school schedules. As a result the hours of operation are subject to change, and will be posted at the pool. 
(Ord. No. 1826, § I, 3-26-1996) 
Sec. 36-48. - Regular admission fees. 
(a)  The regular admission fee for all adults and children is as provided in the city fee schedule. This applies to anyone who enters the pool grounds whether they intend to swim or not with the following exceptions: 
(1)  An adult who accompanies a child and does not enter the pool; or 
(2)  A child who is too young to swim and is accompanied by an adult. 
(b)  Admission fees are good for one admission only. Once a person leaves the pool grounds, he is required to pay a new admission fee if he returns. 
(c)  Cash refunds of admission fees are not allowed. The pool manager may issue "rain passes" if bad weather abruptly causes the pool to be closed. 
(Ord. No. 1826, § II, 3-26-1996) 
Sec. 36-49. - Reservations for special functions. 
(a)  The pool may be reserved for special functions or private parties to be held after normal operating hours. Reservations should be arranged with the pool manager, and are subject to: 
(1)  Availability of the pool; and 
(2)  Ability of the pool manager and staff to accommodate the request. 
(b)  The city requires that a minimum of two lifeguards from its staff be present at the pool during any special functions. The pool manager may require additional lifeguards at his discretion depending on the size of the group, age and type of function. 
(c)  A reservation fee as provided by the city fee schedule shall be payable when the reservation is made as compensation for use of the pool. This fee is not refundable unless: 
(1)  The reservation is canceled by notice to the pool manager ten days in advance of the reservation date; or 
(2)  Weather conditions force cancellation of the event. 
(d)  Prior to the reservation date, a $50.00 deposit shall be paid. Failure to pay the deposit automatically cancels the reservation without refund. The deposit shall cover: 
(1)  Cost of any damage done to the pool; and 
(2)  Cost of lifeguards provided for the function. Cost shall be calculated at a minimum of two hours per event at the lifeguard's hourly wage plus employer fringe costs. 
(3)  The remaining balance shall be refunded to the customer. 
(Ord. No. 1826, § III, 3-26-1996) 
Sec. 36-50. - Instructional classes. 
(a)  Instruction classes for swimming lessons or lifeguard certification may be conducted at the pool. 
(b)  The pool manager may conduct and charge a fee for classes taught before, during or after normal operating hours subject to the following: 
(1)  The instructor will schedule classes so that they do not interfere with his normal work schedule and responsibilities at the pool; 
(2)  The instructor will schedule classes when there is adequate space available in the pool; and 
(3)  The city shall be paid the amount specified in the city fee schedule as compensation for use of the pool facility. 
(c)  Other organizations may be authorized to conduct classes at the pool subject to the following: 
(1)  Only qualified and certified instructors will be allowed to conduct the classes; 
(2)  Classes may be scheduled when there is adequate space available in the pool; and 
(3)  The city shall be paid $15.00 per student enrolled as compensation for use of the pool facility. 
(Ord. No. 1826, § IV, 3-26-1996) 
Sec. 36-51. - Safety regulations. 
    The pool manager and staff are responsible for providing a clean and enjoyable swimming facility for the public, and insuring that it is safely and properly used. The observance of accepted safety standards is required in order to achieve this. The pool manager will post safety regulations at the pool. These regulations are subject to review on occasions, and may be revised by the pool manager upon approval by the city manager. Persons are reminded that failure to abide by these regulations or directions of pool lifeguards can result in being expelled from the pool grounds, and forfeiture of their right to return. 
(Ord. No. 1826, § V, 3-26-1996) 
Chapter 40 - RECREATIONAL VEHICLE PARKS 

Sec. 40-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building official means designated inspection authority of the city, or its authorized representative. 
    Certificate of occupancy means a certificate issued by the building official for the use of a building, structure or land when it is determined by him that the building, structure, or land complies with the provisions of all applicable city codes, ordinance, and regulations. 
    Common access route/internal street means private drive allowing principal means of access to individual recreational vehicle lots. 
    Driveway means minor entranceway of the common access route within the park, into an off-street parking area serving one or more recreational vehicle lots. 
    Licensee means any person licensed to operate and maintain a recreational vehicle park under the provisions of this chapter. 
    Natural or artificial barrier means any embankment, fence, hedge, or other feature that serves to block direct pedestrian access or visibility. 
    Operator means includes the person in charge of operating any recreational vehicle park, either under written or verbal (oral) lease, or any other arrangement whereby he exercises control over the premises. 
    Owner means and includes the person in whose name the title to the lot, block, tract, or parcel of land is shown to be. 
    Recreational vehicle means includes any of the following: 
(1)  Camping trailer. A folding structure mounted on wheels and designed for travel, recreation, and vacation use. 
(2)  Motor home. A portable, temporary dwelling to be used for travel, recreation, and vacation constructed as an integral part of a self-propelled vehicle. 
(3)  Pickup coach. A structure designed to be mounted on a truck chassis for use as a temporary dwelling for travel, recreation, and vacation. 
(4)  Travel trailer. A vehicular structure built on a chassis with body width less than eight feet and body length less than 32 feet, that structure designed to be transported and intended for human occupancy as a dwelling for short periods of time and containing limited or no kitchen or bathroom facilities. 
    Recreational vehicle park means a contiguous parcel of land licensed or used in whole or in part, with or without charges, for the parking of recreational vehicles occupied or intended to be occupied for dwelling or sleeping purposes for any length of time. 
    Recreational vehicle space means a plot of land within a recreational vehicle park designed for the accommodation of one recreational vehicle in accordance with the requirements of this chapter. 
    Service building means a structure housing toilet, lavatories and such other facilities shall be required by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2180, § I, 12-14-2010) 
Sec. 40-2. - Parks licenses. 
(a)  License required. It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or operate a recreational vehicle park within the limits of the city, and its extra territorial jurisdiction unless that person shall first obtain a license as issued by the building official of the city. This license shall be valid for a period not to exceed one year and is subject to renewal upon expiration. 
(b)  License fees. 
(1)  The annual license fee for each recreational vehicle park shall be in accordance with the city fee schedule. 
(2)  The fee for transfer of a license shall be as provided by the city fee schedule. 
(3)  Upon inception of this article and applicable to all new parks, this annual fee shall be pro-rated to accommodate the December 31 expiration of all permits. 
(c)  License application. 
(1)  Application for initial license. An application for initial development of a recreational vehicle park shall be filed with and issued by the building official of the city. 
a.  The application shall be in writing, signed by the applicant, and shall include the following: 
1.  The name and address of applicant; 
2.  The location and legal description of the recreational vehicle park; 
3.  A complete plan of the subject park in conformity with the requirements of section 40-4; 
4.  Plans and specifications of all buildings, improvements, and facilities constructed or to be constructed within the recreational vehicle park. 
b.  The building official of the city shall inspect the application and the proposed plans and specifications. In the event that the proposed recreational vehicle park will, when constructed or altered in accordance with the plans and specifications, be in compliance with all provisions of this chapter and all other applicable ordinances and statutes, the building official shall approve the application, and upon completion of the park according to the plans, shall issue the license. 
(2)  Application for renewal license. Upon application in writing by a licensee for renewal of a license and upon payment of the annual license fee, the building official of the city shall conduct requirements established in this chapter. Subsequent to a determination of compliance, the building official shall issue a certificate renewing the license for another year. 
(3)  Transfer of license. Upon application in writing for a transfer of license, the provision of evidence of special permit transfer, if required, and payment of the license transfer fee, the building official shall issue a transfer of license. 
(4)  Expiration date of license. All licenses issued under the terms and conditions of this article shall expire on the December 31 following the issuance date. 
(Ord. No. 2180, § II, 12-14-2010) 
Sec. 40-3. - Posting of license. 
    The license certificate shall at all times by conspicuously posted in the office of or on the premises of the recreational vehicle park. 
(Ord. No. 2180, § III, 12-14-2010) 
Sec. 40-4. - Development and operation regulations. 
    These development plans shall exhibit on a scale of 100 feet to one inch the following site improvement data: 
(1)  Name of the developer; 
(2)  Name of the record owner of the subject property; 
(3)  Legal description of the tract to be developed; 
(4)  Tract boundary lines, the precise locations and width of all existing or recorded streets, easements and other rights-of-way forming the boundary of the subject tracts; 
(5)  Scale, north arrow, and date; 
(6)  Final contour data at two-foot intervals to show drainage of the site; 
(7)  Width of each private street or other roadway or right-of-way; 
(8)  Source of water supply and layout of water system, including locations of standard fire hydrants, regarding fire protection; 
(9)  Method of sewage disposal and layout of sewer system; 
(10)  Name of the recreational vehicle park; 
(11)  Location, dimensions, and purposes of any easements; 
(12)  Boundaries of each recreational vehicle space; 
(13)  Address assignments (number or letters) to identify individual recreational vehicle spaces; 
(14)  Entrance park name signage shall meet department of transportation requirements. 
(Ord. No. 2180, § IV, 12-14-2010) 
Sec. 40-5. - Recreational vehicle park regulations. 
    The regulations described herein govern the development, operation, and maintenance of recreational vehicle parks, as previously defined. 
(1)  Park development requirements. Recreational vehicle parks shall be developed to conform to those requirements as herein delineated: 
a.  All access road leading to recreational vehicle parks shall be durably surface with asphalt or concrete shall allow for proper drainage of its right-of-way unto established city, county or state right-of-way connecting to the access roads. The drainage must comply with applicable entity regulations. 
b.  No minimum area is established for a recreational vehicle space except that utility hookups shall be located so that a ten-foot clearance shall be maintained between recreational vehicles when parked. 
c.  Not less than eight percent of the gross land area within the park site is to be utilized for common recreational purposes services buildings. 
d.  Internal streets shall be paved and shall exhibit the appropriate dimension as required in the following 
Street Width in Feet Comments One-way, no parking 11 Acceptable only if park provides less than 25 spaces One-way, parking on one side only 18 Acceptable only if park provides less than 50 spaces Two-way, no parking 24 Two-way, parking on one side only 27 Two-way, parking on either side 34  
e.  Parking facilities shall be provided at the park office as will accommodate five recreational vehicles. 
f.  Each recreational vehicle space shall afford parking and maneuvering space sufficient so that the parking, loading, and the like, of recreational vehicles shall not necessitate the use of any public right-of-way or privately owned property which may abut the park. 
g.  Each recreational vehicle space provided with electrical service shall be so served through an underground distribution system. The park office and service building may receive electrical service as provided through overhead facilities. 
h.  Each recreational vehicle park shall provide, at minimum, one sanitary disposal site (dump station) which discharges into the city sewage system or a state approved septic system with provided written confirmation. 
i.  All site-built structures located within the recreational vehicle park shall be constructed and placed in compliance with the technical codes of the city. 
(2)  Service building; laundry and sanitation facilities. Each recreation vehicle park shall provide one or more service buildings for the use of park patrons. 
a.  The service building shall provide for: 
1.  One flush toilet for women; 
2.  One flush toilet for men; 
3.  One lavatory for each sex; 
4.  One shower and dressing accommodation for each sex, provided in an Individual compartment or stall; 
5.  One washing machine; 
6.  One slop sink, not less than 14 inches by 14 inches deep; 
7.  One cloth dryer. 
(b)  Service building requirements. Service buildings providing the forenamed facilities shall satisfy requirements as included: 
1.  Service building housing sanitation or laundry facilities shall be permanent structures which comply with all applicable laws and ordinances regulating buildings, electrical installation, plumbing, and sanitation systems. 
2.  Service buildings shall afford appropriate illumination, shall be well ventilated with screened openings, shall be constructed of moisture-proof materials, to include painted woodwork, as shall permit frequent clearing and washing. Floors shall be constructed of concrete or other equally impervious material, easily cleanable, and provided with floor drains which are connected to the sanitary system. 
3.  The toilet and other sanitation facilities for males and females either shall be in separate buildings or shall be separated, if in the same building, by a soundproof wall. 
4.  All service buildings and park grounds shall be maintained in a clean sightly condition and kept free of any condition that will menace the health of any occupant or the public or constitute a nuisance. 
5.  Service buildings housing sanitation facilities shall be located not closer than 15 feet nor farther than 200 from any recreational vehicle space within the park; 
6.  Service building shall provide a common space for activities or meetings. 
(Ord. No. 2180, § V, 12-14-2010) 
Sec. 40-6. - Water supply. 
(a)  Recreational vehicle park shall provide an adequate supply of pure water to all recreational vehicle spaces within the park in accordance with applicable ordinances, each individual recreational vehicle space shall be provided with a cold water tap not less than four inches above the ground. 
(b)  All plumbing work performed within a recreational vehicle park shall comply in all respects with the requirements of the plumbing code of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2180, § VI, 12-14-2010) 
Sec. 40-7. - Sewage disposal. 
(a)  Wastewater from showers, bathtubs, flush toilets, lavatories, and laundry facilities within the service or other buildings within the recreational vehicle park, in addition to dump station facilities, shall be discharged into a public sewer system in compliance with applicable ordinances, or state approved septic systems where applicable. 
(b)  Each recreational vehicle park space located within a recreational vehicle park facility shall be provided a trapped sewer not less than four inches in diameter. The trapped sewer in each recreational vehicle space shall discharge wastewater into a public sewer system in compliance with applicable ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2180, § VII, 12-14-2010) 
Sec. 40-8. - Electrical service. 
(a)  Electrical service to individual recreational vehicle spaces, in addition to any service or office buildings, shall conform to those requirements specified in the electrical code adopted for us by the city. 
(b)  Within recreational vehicle parks, trash dumpsters or garbage cans possessing secure covers shall be provided in quantities adequate to permit disposal of all garbage and rubbish. These garbage receptacles shall be located not further than 300 feet from recreational vehicle spaces. These receptacles shall be maintained in sanitary conditions at all times. Garbage and rubbish shall be collected and disposed of as frequently as may be necessary to ensure that the receptacles shall not overflow. 
(Ord. No. 2180, § VIII, 12-14-2010) 
Sec. 40-9. - Animals and pets. 
    No owner or person in charge of any dog, cat, or other pet animal shall permit that animal to run at large or commit any nuisance within the limits of any recreational vehicle park. 
(Ord. No. 2180, § IX, 12-14-2010) 
Sec. 40-10. - Administration and enforcement. 
(a)  Registered occupants. 
(1)  It shall be the duty of each licensee to maintain a registry containing a record of all recreational vehicle owners and occupants located within recreational vehicle parks. The registry shall contain the following information: 
a.  The name and address of each recreational vehicle occupant; 
b.  The name and address of the owner of each recreational vehicle within the park; 
c.  The make, model, year, and license number of each recreational vehicle located within the park; 
d.  The state, territory, or country issuing those licenses; 
e.  The date of arrival and or departure of each recreational vehicle. 
(2)  The park shall keep the register available for inspection at all times by law enforcement officers, public hearing officials, and other officials whose duties necessitate acquisition of the information, contained in the register. The registry record for each occupant registered shall not be destroyed for a period of three years following the date of departure of the registrant from the park. 
(b)  Supervision. The licensee, or duly authorized attendant or caretaker, shall be in charge at all times to maintain the recreational vehicle park, and its facilities and equipment, in a clean, orderly, and sanitary condition. The attendant or caretaker shall be answerable, with the licensee, for the violation of any provision of this chapter to which the licensee is subject. 
(Ord. No. 2180, § X, 12-14-2010) 
Sec. 40-11. - Complaints; license suspension. 
(a)  Where the building official, or his agent, determined that the operation of a recreational vehicle park violates some provision of this chapter, or any other provisions in this Code, a complaint may be filled in the municipal court for the city against either the owner or the operator of the park or both or in the appropriate court of the county or state where applicable. 
(b)  Where the building official, or his agent, determined that the operation of a recreational vehicle park violates some provision of this chapter; he may suspend the park's license to operate until that time as the park complies with the chapter. This license may appeal this suspension to the board of adjustment, as provided for in city zoning ordinance, regarding appeals, as amended. Operation of a park while the license is suspended shall constitute a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2180, § XI, 12-14-2010) 
Sec. 40-12. - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and punished according to section 1-14. Each day the violation shall be permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. Any person who is found guilty of violation of this chapter shall be fined a penalty not to exceed the maximum limit established by most current state statutes. 
(Ord. No. 2180, § XII, 12-14-2010) 
Sec. 40-13. - Location. 
(a)  Recreational vehicle parks may be located only in an area zoned for such use under the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  The park shall comply with state and federal standards for accessibility for the mobility impaired. The applicant shall show proof of compliance as outlined by state statutes. 
(Ord. No. 2180, § XIII, 12-14-2010) 
Sec. 40-14. - Inspection. 
(a)  The building official, building inspector, the city fire chief, and the city police chief are hereby authorized and directed to make such inspection as necessary to determine compliance with this chapter. 
(b)  The building official, building inspector, the city fire chief, and the city police chief shall have the power to enter at reasonable times upon any private or public property for the purpose of inspecting and investigating conditions relating to the enforcement of this chapter. 
(c)  The building official, building inspector, the city fire chief, and the city police chief shall have the power and authority in discharging their official duties to inspect the registry containing a record of all residents of the park. 
(Ord. No. 2180, § XIV, 12-14-2010) 
Sec. 40-15. - Revocation of license. 
(a)  The city manager may revoke any license to maintain and operate a park where the license has been guilty by a court of competent jurisdiction of violating any provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  After such conviction, a new license may be reissued if the circumstances leading to conviction have been remedied and the park is being maintained and operated in full compliance with the law. 
(Ord. No. 2180, § XV, 12-14-2010) 
Chapter 42 - SIGNS AND OTHER ADVERTISING[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Regulation of signs by municipalities generally, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 216.001 et seq.; authority for municipal regulation of signs, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 216.901; regulation of political signs by municipality, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 216.903; municipal boards on sign control, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 216.004; regulation of outdoor advertising generally, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 391.031 et seq.; licenses and permits for outdoor advertising, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 391.061 et seq.; municipal authority to regulate sign placement, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 393.0025. 

Sec. 42-1. - Intent and purpose. 
    It is the intent of this chapter to provide comprehensive regulation of signs, including the erection, alteration and maintenance of all types of billboards, signs, campaign signs, bills and posters within the city limits, in order to protect and enhance the health, safety and welfare of the general public, and provide such comprehensive regulations in a manner which will be compatible with all city ordinances. Further, it is the purpose of this chapter to provide uniform sign standards which promote a positive city image reflecting order, harmony and pride, thereby by strengthening the economic stability of the city's business, cultural and residential areas. 
(Ord. No. 2033, § 1, 7-27-2004) 
Sec. 42-2. - Objectives. 
    Objectives to be pursued to applying specific sign standards are as follows: 
(1)  To identify individual business, residential, and public use without creating confusion, unsightliness, or visual obscurity. 
(2)  To ensure that all signs are properly related to the overall adjacent land use, character and development lot size, scale, height, and location. 
(Ord. No. 2033, § 2, 7-27-2004) 
Sec. 42-3. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all signs, as that term is defined herein, within city limits, except for the following: 
(1)  Official government signs and notices. 
(2)  National, state, and local governmental flags. 
(3)  Scoreboards facing an athletic area. 
(Ord. No. 2033, § 3, 7-27-2004) 
Sec. 42-4. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
    Abandoned sign means any sign which no longer correctly advertises a business product, service, or activity. 
    Advertise means and includes promoting, identifying, or calling attention to a business, product, service, candidate, issue, or activity, through use of words, symbols, figures, or similar means. 
    Area means the area of a sign shall be the area of the sign face. In computing any maximum allowable sign area, only one side of the double sign face shall be considered. 
    Banner sign means any sign other than a pennant which is made from or on cloth or other limp material. Any such sign displayed behind glass or within a building shall be deemed a wall sign. 
    Billboard sign means any sign, with the exception of portable signs, pertaining to a business, activity, product, or service not being offered or conducted on the premises upon which the sign is located. 
    Campaign sign means any sign that promotes the election or re-election of any candidate or pro or con on an issue before the local electorate. M-1 campaign signs are hereto limited to private property and are prohibited for being lighted or from flashing lighting while on established residential areas. 
    Canopy sign means any sign attached to, hung from, or supported by a canopy structure. 
    Clearance means the smallest vertical distance between the ground or improvements underneath a sign and the lowest point of the sign, including framework and embellishments. 
    Construction sign means a sign identifying a business participating in construction on the property on which the sign is located. 
    Copy means the working, symbols, and figures on a sign face in either permanent or changeable form. 
    Directional sign means any on-premises sign giving directions, instructions, or facility information, such as parking or exit and entrance signs. 
    Erect means to construct, build, raise, assemble, emplace, affix, attach, create, paint, draw or in any other way bring into being or establish. 
    Electrical sign means any sign or sign structure which uses or incorporates electrical wiring, connections, lights or fixtures. 
    Electronic message sign means a sign, the copy of which automatically changes at least once every three seconds. Such signs shall be considered on-premises signs if no more than 50 percent of the total number of messages displayed on the sign relate to off-premises activities. 
    Face means the entire advertising area of a sign excluding framing, trim, or supporting structure. 
    Financing sign means any sign identifying a financial institution participating in development of the property on which it is located. 
    Freestanding sign means any on-premises sign permanently affixed to the ground which is not attached to a building. 
    Frontage means the length of the property lines of a lot which abut public streets. 
    Height means the vertical distance between the highest part of the sing or its supporting structure, whichever is higher, and the average ground level beneath the sign. 
    Lot means a parcel of land legally defined as a lot on a duly approved subdivision plat of record, or a parcel of land defined by a legal record or survey map. 
    Noncommercial sign means any sign that conveys a political, social, ideological, community service, or similar message. 
    Occupancy means the purpose for which a building, lot, or sign, or structure is used or intended to be used. 
    On-premises sign means any sign which advertises a business, product, service, or activity offered, sold or conducted on the premises on which the sign is located. 
    Pennant sign means any sign consisting of a series of flags constructed of cloth or other limp material. 
    Portable sign means any sign not permanently affixed to the ground or to a building which is designed to permit removal and reuse. 
    Premises means a parcel of land with its appurtenances and buildings which is devoted to a particular commercial, industrial, or residential use. 
    Projecting sign means any sign, other than a flat wall sign, which is attached to and projects from a building wall or other structure not designed primarily to support a sign. 
    Public street or right-of-way means shall mean the entire width between property lines of any road, street, way, alley, bridge, or other similar thoroughfare publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the public for vehicular traffic. 
    Realty sign means any sign used to advertise a real estate development site or to advertise that real estate is for sale, rent or lease. 
    Roof sign means any sign affixed to the roof of a building. 
    Setback means the horizontal distance between a sign and the front lot line, as measured from the part of the sign nearest to the front lot line. 
    Sign means any object, display, or part thereof, visible from a public street, which is used to advertise a business, product, service, promoting the election or re-election of any candidate or pro or con on an issue before the local electorate, or any other activity. 
    Wall sign means any sign affixed flat against and parallel to a building wall. For the purposes of this definition, the term "wall" shall include window areas. 
(Ord. No. 2033, §§ 4, 5, 7-27-2004) 
Sec. 42-5. - Sign design and construction criteria generally. 
(a)  No sign, sign structure, or sign support shall be placed upon or project over any public property or right-of-way; provided that a wall sign affixed to a building wall located upon a property line may project up to eighteen inches from the back of the curb so long as it maintains a clearance of at least eight feet. 
(b)  No sign shall be erected, constructed, or maintained so as to obstruct any means of egress, or any opening necessary for required light, ventilation or firefighting or for escape from the premises, or as to prevent free passage from one part of a rooftop to any other part thereof. 
(c)  No sign shall be attached to any exterior stairway, fire escape, fire tower balcony, fire wall, or balcony serving as a horizontal exit. 
(d)  No sign shall be erected, constructed or maintained so as to interfere with the free operation of a counterbalanced section of a fire escape, and no projecting sign shall be erected, constructed or maintained without a minimum of seven feet clearance over any such counterbalance section. 
(e)  No sign shall obstruct the free use of any window above the first story as a required means of egress to a fire escape. 
(f)  The ground surface area under and adjacent to signs shall be kept clean of weeds, high grass, and rubbish. 
(g)  Signs shall maintain clearance from telephone, cable television, and electric power line in accordance with utility company standards. 
(h)  In the event that more than one sign-related definition applies to a proposed sign, resulting in conflicting regulations thereon, the sign applicant may choose the definition that is to apply, with the qualification that all regulations related to the definition must be adopted. Where the proposed sign is of a type that is prohibited, it shall remain prohibited notwithstanding that it may also come with the definition of an approved type of sign. 
(i)  All signs shall meet applicable construction standards of the Southern Building Code and the National Electrical Code, as adopted by the city. 
(j)  A noncommercial sign shall be allowed in any instance in which an on-premises or billboard sign is allowed within this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2033, § 6, 7-27-2004) 
Sec. 42-6. - Prohibited signs. 
    The following signs shall be prohibited: 
(1)  Signs in zones other than "B-2" Secondary and Highway Business District, "B-3" Central Business District, "I-1" Light Industrial District, and "I-2" Industrial District with flashing, blinking, or traveling lights, except for time and temperature or electronic message signs. 
(2)  Banners, flags, searchlights, twirling signs, sandwich or A-Frame signs, sidewalk or curb signs, balloons or other gas filled objects, except as expressly provided in section 42-9. 
(3)  Signs upon trees, rocks, bridges, power lines (all telephone poles), or signs utilizing such objects for all or part of their support. 
(Ord. No. 2033, § 7, 7-27-2004) 
Sec. 42-7. - On-premises signs. 
(a)  Freestanding signs structure shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  Only one such sign structure shall be allowed for each lot of 50 feet frontage or lease which front only one public street. Lots with fronts of 150 feet shall be allowed an additional such sign structure and one other such sign structure for every 150 feet of frontage thereafter. For lots fronting more than one public street, the same regulations shall apply to each street and sign. 
(2)  Permanent portable signs and portable trailer signs are exceptions and are handled in sections 42-10 and 42-11. 
(3)  The maximum height of such signs shall be 421/2 feet on lots within the city limits fronting United States and state highways, including Texas Farm to Market roads. 
(4)  Campaign signs shall be restricted to on-premises only and shall not exceed 32 square feet and shall be temporary in nature to be removed by the property owner or candidate within seven days following the election. 
(b)  Roof signs shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  Such signs shall not project beyond any exterior wall of the building on which such signs are mounted. 
(2)  The maximum height of such signs shall be 15 feet above the building upon which such signs are mounted. 
(c)  Canopy signs shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  The face of such signs shall not exceed six feet in height. 
(2)  Such signs shall not extend beyond the sides of the canopy. 
(3)  One sign may be hung beneath a canopy, provided such sign maintains a minimum clearance of eight feet. 
(d)  Projecting signs shall maintain a minimum clearance of nine feet. 
(e)  Construction and realty signs shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  Such signs shall be used only temporarily during relevant periods of development or listing. Such signs shall become abandoned signs upon occupancy of the premises. Realty signs, when anchored or mounted securely to the ground, shall not be considered to be portable signs. 
(2)  One construction sign up to 128 square feet, and one realty sign up to 32 square feet, may be used on a lot; provided that on corner lots, such allowable areas may be divided between two construction and two realty signs oriented towards different streets; and provided further that for lots with frontage exceeding 500 feet, one such realty sign may be sued for each 500 feet of frontage. 
(Ord. No. 2033, § 8, 7-27-2004; Ord. No. 2042, § 1, 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 42-8. - Billboards. 
(a)  No billboards shall be located: 
(1)  Within 200 feet of any on-premises freestanding sign. 
(2)  Within 100 feet of any intersection controlled by a traffic control signal. 
(3)  Within 300 feet of any other billboard on the same side of a street other than a highway designated as a "loop" highway. 
(4)  Within 500 feet of any other billboard on the same side of a highway designated as a "loop" highway. 
(b)  Billboards shall have maximum height of 421/2 feet and a minimum clearance of seven feet. 
(c)  The maximum area of billboards shall vary directly with the setback, in accordance with the following: 
Area of Sign Face Minimum Setback Less than 200 square feet 10 feet 200-300 square feet 25 feet More than 300 square feet 30 feet  
Billboards erected after passage of this chapter shall have an absolute maximum area of 325 feet. All single-faced billboards shall have their backsides painted with industrial or commercial coating. 
(d)  Extensions shall be allowed provided such extensions do not exceed 25 percent of the width of the sign, and provided the extension complies with the height limitations in subsection (b) of this section. 
(e)  Billboards larger than 200 feet in area shall be built in compliance with all applicable Southern Building Code requirements. 
(Ord. No. 2033, § 9, 7-27-2004) 
Sec. 42-9. - Banner and pennant signs, searchlights, flags. 
(a)  On-premises banner signs, flags, balloons, and searchlights may be used subject to the following: Such displays shall comply with height and setback requirements applicable to on-premises freestanding signs. 
(b)  Banner signs extending across a public street shall advertise only civic and nonprofit activities, and shall be allowed only with written permission of the city manager or designee and proper agents from the state and utility companies when affected and must be removed no later than 30 days after the advertised event ceases. Approved location of the banners shall be based on all aspects of public safety. 
(Ord. No. 2033, § 10, 7-27-2004) 
Sec. 42-10. - Permanent portable signs. 
    Permanent portable signs will be allowed on commercial property subject to meeting wind loads as specified in Southern Building Codes. 
(1)  Lighted permanent portable signs will be wired electrically to meet National Electric Codes. 
(2)  Only one permanent portable sign for every 300 feet of frontage and not to exceed two will be allowed per front frontage provided except two signs will be allowed if corner property is involved oriented toward different street or street corners. 
(3)  No part of permanent portable sign shall extend into right-of-way nor block adjacent properties, on-premises signs nor obscure visibility of any entering and existing driveway. 
(4)  Permanent portable signs shall require property permits from the city prior to installation. 
(Ord. No. 2033, § 11, 7-27-2004) 
Sec. 42-11. - Portable trailer signs. 
    Portable trailer signs may be used for short promotions with a permit from the city, provided: 
(1)  Such sign is located entirely on private property; 
(2)  No electrical connections are made or that connections meet all National Electrical Code requirements. 
(Ord. No. 2033, § 12, 7-27-2004) 
Sec. 42-12. - License and permit requirements. 
(a)  Only companies engaged in sign construction business with acceptable certificates of insurance with a minimum of $55,000.00 of liability coverage shall be allowed to erect and construct signs in the city. 
(b)  All lighted signs will require permits prior to installation. 
(c)  All non-lighted sign structures larger than 32 square feet will require permits prior to erection. 
(d)  Campaign signs, as herein defined shall be exempt from these fees provided they do not exceed subsection (c) of this section and only so long as they confirm to the provisions of section 42-7 and all other applicable provisions. 
(e)  Fees will be based on evaluation of work performed and product provided as with all city building permits issued. 
(Ord. No. 2033, § 13, 7-27-2004) 
Sec. 42-13. - Existing signs; applicability of chapter. 
(a)  Within this section, the term "existing sign location" shall mean the location of an on-premises sign in existence at the time of adoption of this chapter, upon premises where no lapse of business operations exceeding 180 days has occurred since that date. 
(b)  The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to existing sign locations except as follows: 
(1)  New signs constructed or installed at existing sign locations shall be on the property of the business or activity. 
(2)  New signs constructed or installed at existing sign locations shall maintain clearance from utility lines in accordance with utility company standards. 
(3)  New signs constructed or installed at existing sign locations shall not exceed 421/2 feet in height for lots fronting U.S. Loop Highway 181, U.S. Business 181, U.S. 59, Texas Highway 202 and FM 673 and 35 in height for all other lots, and shall maintain adequate clearance for vehicles passing underneath and traffic viewing. 
(c)  On-premises signs on premises where a lapse in business operations exceeding 180 days has occurred shall be deems to be abandoned signs. Such abandoned signs shall be removed by the owner of the premises within 30 days after written notice to remove is given by the city manager or designee. The city manager or designee may cause the removal of any such sign remaining after such time, to be stored at owner's expense unless at discretion of the city such sign is allowed to stay with faces blacked out. 
(d)  The provisions of this article shall not apply to billboards in existence at the time of adoption of this article; provided that any alteration or repair to the structure of such a billboard shall require such billboard to comply with the requirements of section 42-8 and shall not increase the area or height of such billboard. 
(Ord. No. 2033, § 14, 7-27-2004) 
Sec. 42-14. - Abatement of prohibited signs. 
(a)  All signs, sign structures, and supports placed upon or projecting across public property or right-of-way as of the time of adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived shall be removed in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Those which present a danger to the persons or property because of their condition may be removed immediately by the city manager or designee and stored at the owner's expense. 
(2)  Those which may present a visual obstruction to traffic, as determined by the city engineer or such engineer's representative, may be removed immediately by the city manager or designee and stored at the owner's expense. 
(3)  All other such signs which become abandoned signs after such date shall be removed by the owner or user thereof within 30 days after written notice to remove is given by the city manager or designee. The city manager or designee may cause the removal of any such sign remaining after such time, to be stored at the owner's expense. 
Any such sign which is removed may be relocated on private property without regard to setback requirements otherwise applicable to such sign. 
(b)  All other signs in violation of any provision of section 42-6 or section 42-10 in existence as of the time of adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived shall be removed by the owner or user thereof within six months after such date. The city manager or designee may cause the removal of any such sign remaining after such time, to be stored at the owner's expense. 
(c)  Any sign constructed, installed, or erected after the time of adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived which becomes in violation of a location restriction contained in sections 42-8 and section 42-9 shall be made to conform to such restriction within six months after it becomes in violation, or such sign shall be removed. The city manager or designee may cause the removal of any such sign remaining after such time, to be stored at the owner's expense. 
(d)  Any sign which presents a danger to persons or property because of its condition may be removed by the city manager or designee and stored at the owner's expense. 
(e)  All signs shall be maintained in good condition in terms of structure and appearance. No sign owner or user shall allow the copy or face of a sign to become torn, cracked, or otherwise dilapidated. Upon the second or subsequent conviction of the owner or user of a sign for violation of this provision in the municipal court, the court may order the removal of such sign by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2033, § 15, 7-27-2004) 
Sec. 42-15. - Notice of sign removal. 
    The city manager or designee shall give written notice to the owner of a sign removed under this chapter of the right to reclaim such sign within 30 days of the notice of payment of the costs of removal and storage. Any sign not so reclaimed within such time may be disposed of by the city manager or designee in a reasonable manner. 
(Ord. No. 2033, § 16, 7-27-2004) 
Chapter 44 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal powers relating to public health, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 122.006; minimum standards of sanitation and health protection measures, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 341.001 et seq.; local regulation of sanitation, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 342.001 et seq.; Solid Waste Disposal Act, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 361.001 et seq.; Solid Waste Resource Recovery Financing Act, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 362.001 et seq.; Comprehensive Municipal Solid Waste Management, Resource Recovery, and Conservation Act, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 363.001 et seq.; Texas Litter Abatement Act, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 365.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 44-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial account means any location whose primary function or purpose is other than for residential or living purpose excluding those served by garbage containers which shall be considered garbage container accounts. Motels and hotels shall be considered commercial accounts unless served by garbage containers. 
    Garbage means all animal or vegetable matter, such as waste material and refuse from kitchens, residences, grocery stores, butcher shops, restaurants, cafes, hotels, rooming and boardinghouses, and all other habitable structures, and shall include other deleterious substances and refuse generated through normal household, residential or commercial activity that is capable of being bagged, boxed or bundled, handled and collected by hand. 
    Garbage container (dumpster) accounts means residential or commercial type accounts serviced by garbage containers (dumpsters) provided by the city. 
    Residential account means single-family and multifamily dwelling units such as duplexes and apartments excluding those served by garbage containers which shall be considered garbage containers accounts. Motels and hotels shall be considered commercial accounts unless served by garbage containers. 
    Service address means the address or actual location where garbage collection service is provided, as opposed to any account's billing address. 
    Trash means items other than normal garbage that is too heavy or bulky to be collected by hand, usually consisting of items such as trees and tree limbs, lumber, construction debris, discarded furniture and appliances, etc. and rubbish such as feathers, coffee grounds, ashes, tin cans, paper, boxes, glass, grass, shrubs, yard cleanings, grass clippings, leaves, tree trimmings, wood shavings, sawdust and wood and lumber particles. 
(Code 1973, § 8-1; Ord. No. 985, § II, 10-28-1969; Ord. No. 1102, § 2, 1-23-1973; Ord. No. 1712, § II, 11-26-1991) 
Sec. 44-2. - Disposal of litter. 
    It is unlawful to dispose or allow or permit the disposal of litter at a place that is not an approved solid waste site, including a place on or within 300 feet of a public highway, on a right-of-way, or other public or private property. In addition, it is unlawful to receive litter for disposal at a place that is not an approved solid waste site and to transport litter to a place that is not an approved solid waste site for disposal at the site. 
(Ord. No. 1992, § 6.2, 9-10-2002) 
Secs. 44-3-44-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 

Sec. 44-25. - Collection within and outside city limits. 
    The city reserves the sole right to provide garbage collection service to locations within the city limits. The city may, if so requested, provide garbage collection services to locations outside of the corporate city limits at the city's discretion on an individual case basis with the right to adjust service rates, if warranted. 
(Ord. No. 1712, §§ III, IV, 11-26-1991) 
Sec. 44-26. - Fees. 
    Fees for garbage collection and disposal shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Ord. No. 1712, § VII, 11-26-1991) 
Sec. 44-27. - Use of containers restricted. 
    The city will not collect garbage from containers (dumpsters) other than those owned and provided by the city. The city will equip containers with a lock mechanism (hasp) on the container lid to discourage this if requested by the customer. The customer will be responsible for providing the lock and key, and for unlocking and removing the lock during regularly scheduled pickup hours. Garbage containers may be shared by more than one customer. It is the responsibility of the customers to agree among themselves as to what is their fair portion of the monthly cost, and the city will then bill them accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 1712, § VIIIF., 11-26-1991) 
Sec. 44-28. - Collection schedule; placement for collection. 
(a)  Garbage collection begins at 8:00 a.m. in residential neighborhoods, except during the summer months when it begins at 7:30 a.m. This summer period will correspond to the public school year system's dismissal of classes for the summer and then the beginning of classes for the fall. 
(1)  The city collects trash throughout the city on a regularly scheduled basis, and one truck load per month (approximately eight cubic yards) of trash collection shall be provided at the service address of each active customer account at no charge. 
(2)  Additional loads, or unscheduled collection, shall be provided at a cost of $15.00 per load. 
(3)  The allowance of one free load per month is good for one month only, and cannot be carried forward or accumulated from one month to the next. 
(4)  When trash is collected at a location, the entire pile of trash will be removed, and the customer charged for any truck loads exceeding the first complimentary truck load. Trash will not be left to be picked up one month at a time. 
(5)  Trash collection is done by mechanized equipment, and trash must be placed adjacent to the street so it can be removed by the equipment from the street. 
(6)  Trash should not be placed on top of or near utility service apparatus such as water or gas meters, utility poles, etc. The city will not remove trash if a potential risk exists for damage to property or personal injury. Customers will be held responsible for damage to property that occurs during removal of trash because the property was hidden or obscured by the accumulated trash. 
(7)  The city's ability to provide trash collection service may be limited by availability of personnel or suitable equipment so situations may arise where the city will not be able to provide the service because of the size, volume or type of trash to be removed. The customer will be responsible for removal and disposal of trash in these cases. 
(b)  Garbage for residential and commercial accounts must be bagged, boxed or bundled so that it can be collected by hand. The city will not collect loose garbage, or collect by hand loose garbage contained in an enclosure. 
(c)  Garbage must be placed adjacent to the street, or in some cases alley, so that it is accessible to garbage collection crews without having to enter onto private property. 
(d)  Garbage collection. The city shall provide a garbage container meeting the requirements of section 44-27. The customer shall place, or cause to be placed, the garbage container in the location for collection approved by the director. Pack out service is offered to residents in all areas of the city. Containers other than pack out shall be placed at the curb for collection no earlier than 6:00 p.m. on the day prior to scheduled service and shall be removed by 7:00 a.m. the morning following the collection day. 
(1)  An authorized city employee has the authority to take the following actions if the garbage container is left in or about the curb area at any time other than the above described times: 
a.  First occurrence within a 12-month period. The city employee will move the container to the customer's front door area and post a notice on the customer's container notifying the customer of the violation of city Code section 44-28(d). 
b.  Second occurrence within a 12-month period. The city employee will move the container to the customer's front door area and post a notice on the container that notifies the customer of the violation of Beeville City Code section 44-28(d) and that a five-dollar container return fee will be assessed on the customer's utility bill upon the next occurrence of a section 16-4c violation requiring removal and return of customer's container. 
c.  Third occurrence within a 12-month period. The city employee will move the container to the customer's front door area and post a notice on the container that notifies the customer: 1) of the violation of this subsection, 2) that a ten-dollar container return fee has been assessed on the customer's utility bill for the violation of section 44-28(d) requiring removal and return of customer's container, and 3) that a twenty-dollar container return fee will be assessed on the customer's utility bill upon the next occurrence of a section 44-28(d) violation requiring removal and return of customer's container. 
d.  Fourth and subsequent occurrences within a 12-month period. The city employee will move the container to the customer's front door area and post a notice on the container that notifies the customer: 1) of the violation of Beeville City Code section 44-28(d), 2) that a forty-dollar container return fee has been assessed on the customer's utility bill for the violation of section 44-28(d) requiring removal and return of customer's container, and 3) that a twenty-dollar container return fee will be assessed on the customer's utility bill upon any subsequent occurrences of a section 44-28(d) violation requiring removal and return of customer's container. 
(Ord. No. 1686, 4-16-1991; Ord. No. 1712, §§ V, VI, IX, X, 11-26-1991; Ord. No. 2321, 2-14-2017) 
Sec. 44-29. - Sanitary landfill. 
    The city operates a sanitary landfill that is open to the public during hours posted at the entrance. Fees for use of the landfill are as provided in the city fee schedule. Tickets for disposal of garbage or trash at the landfill will be sold at city hall. Complimentary tickets for disposal of trash at the landfill in lieu of trash collection at the customer's service address will not be issued. The types of materials that can be disposed of at the sanitary landfill are determined by federal and state regulatory agencies. Only allowable materials will be accepted. 
(Ord. No. 1712, § XI, 11-26-1991) 
Sec. 44-30. - Citizen's collection station. 
(a)  Purpose and intent. The citizens collection station is provided for the convenience and exclusive use of residents to dispose of solid waste items which they would have normally taken to a landfill. It is not meant to be used for disposal of regular household and kitchen garbage, but instead for disposal of other than usual solid waste items homeowners sometimes need to dispose of. These items might include the larger than normal items the person wants to dispose of rather than placing them in front of their house for curbside collection. Some examples include furniture, mattresses, used clothing, old appliances, or debris from a homeowner's remodeling job. 
(b)  Location and hours. The citizen's collection station is located at 200 South Jackson Street, Beeville, Texas, and is open during the following hours: 
(1)  Mondays and Fridays, 9:00 a.m. to 12:00 noon and 1:00 p.m. to 5:00 p.m.; 
(2)  Tuesdays through Thursdays, 1:00 p.m. to 5:00 p.m.; 
(3)  Saturdays, 9:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m.; and 
(4)  Closed on Sundays and holidays observed by city. 
(c)  Fees. Fees for use of the collection station shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(d)  Prohibited uses. Persons collecting solid waste items for others in exchange for a fee or transporting debris generated at a work site where they are being paid to do work are prohibited from using the station. 
(e)  Prohibited items. The following items may not be deposited at the collection station: 
(1)  Organic household waste that may generate odor during decomposition, or attract rodents or flies; 
(2)  Brush or tree limbs; 
(3)  Dead animals, or slaughterhouse wastes; 
(4)  Used tires and oil filters;
