(5)  Wastewater treatment plant sludge, septic tank waste, or grease and grit trap wastes; 
(6)  Burned material; 
(7)  Batteries; 
(8)  Discarded materials containing asbestos; 
(9)  Any devices containing freon unless they have been drained of freon and tagged by a certified inspector; 
(10)  Hazardous waste as defined by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) pursuant to the federal Solid Waste Disposal Act as amended by the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, 42 USC 6901 et seq., as amended; 
(11)  Metal and plastic containers may be accepted if they are clean and dry, and the lids or bottoms removed; 
(12)  Roof debris (shingles, felt paper, etc.) in quantities exceeding one pickup load. 
(Ord. No. 1992, §§ 8.2-8.6, 9-10-2002) 
Sec. 44-31. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The provisions of this chapter are intended to apply to land inside the city. 
(b)  The city attorney is hereby authorized to seek injunctive or other legal or equitable relief as may be necessary and appropriate to the enforcement of this chapter. 
(c)  The health official, building official, environment inspector or other authorized designee, or any peace officer may issue citations or summons for violation of this chapter regardless of whether a notice to abate is issued. 
(Ord. No. 2321, 2-14-2017) 
Chapter 46 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- General authority of home rule municipalities concerning highways, streets and alleys, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 311.001; general authority of home rule municipality regarding sidewalks, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 311.004; use of municipal streets and sidewalks for public convenience and amenities, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 316.001 et seq.; municipal streets generally, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 312.001 et seq.; drainage on public roads, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 254.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 46-1. - Corner sight obstructions. 
    No person shall erect any wall, fence or other structure to a height greater than three feet above the level of the crown of the roadway or plant any hedge, tree, shrub or growth of a height greater than three feet above the level of the crown of the roadway, or maintain or permit the existence of any such wall, fence or other structure of a height greater than three feet above the level of the crown of the roadway, or maintain or permit the growth or existence of any hedge, tree, shrub or other structure to a height greater than three feet above the level of the crown of the roadway upon his property or on property under his control wherever such property is bounded on two adjacent sides by public rights-of-way for road, street, boulevard, alley or other public way, the area so restricted being the area of the corner or corners of such property, more particularly described as being that area bounded by two intersecting boundaries of the public rights-of-way for a distance of 20 feet of each of the boundaries from the point of intersection, and bounded by a third side determined by the drawing of a straight line from the points on the two intersecting boundaries 20 feet from their intersection; provided, however, the existence of a tree shall not be unlawful so long as such tree is free of branches and foliage for a height of at least seven feet above the level of the crown of the roadway. 
(Code 1973, § 14-1; Ord. No. 347, § 1, 7-13-1954) 
Sec. 46-2. - Minimum height of wires. 
    Every person who shall place, string or hang any telegraph, telephone, electric light or other wire along, over or across any public street, alley, highway, park or other public property within the city shall place such wires at a height of not less than 20 feet from the ground. 
(Code 1973, § 14-2; Ord. No. 38, 7-3-1912) 
Sec. 46-3. - Street improvement assessment notice and hearing. 
    Whenever the city council shall propose to make any street improvement in accordance with the provisions of Vernon's Texas Civil Statutes, the notice of assessment as provided in V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 312.041 shall be published as therein provided and the hearings shall be held before the city council, and shall be fully and fairly held, at which hearings the mayor shall preside under such rules and regulations as are required in judicial proceedings. 
(Code 1973, § 14-3; Ord. No. 87, § 1, 2-8-1921) 
Secs. 46-4-46-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DRIVEWAYS 

Sec. 46-25. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, reconstruct, alter, repair, remove or replace any sidewalk, driveway or other way, for the use of any character of vehicle, on or across any sidewalk, parkway or other space between any public roadway or right-of-way and any private property without first securing a permit from the building inspector for constructing the improvements in accordance with the regulations set forth in this article, complying with the regulations which may be provided by any other ordinance; provided the approval of the city council on a plat approving specifications for driveways shall constitute a permit for a driveway complying with the indicated specifications, which permit shall be considered valid for a period of one year from the date of the plat. 
(Code 1973, § 14-15; Ord. No. 612, § I, 5-8-1962) 
Sec. 46-26. - Application, fee. 
    Application for a permit shall be made in writing to the building inspector showing the location of such proposed improvements, together with a map, plat or sketch drawn to scale fully describing the nature of the proposed improvements and the location thereof. In the event such application complies with the requirements of this article, and such other regulations concerning the matter as may be provided, a permit shall be issued by the building inspector after the payment of a fee as provided by the city fee schedule by the applicant to the building inspector. 
(Code 1973, § 14-16; Ord. No. 612, § II, 5-8-1962) 
Sec. 46-27. - Construction and layout requirements. 
    No driveway providing access from private property to any public right-of-way or roadway shall be constructed, unless a showing is made to the satisfaction of the city manager under section 46-28, unless such approach and driveway shall be in accordance with the following requirements: 
(1)  No driveway shall have a width measured along the boundary line between the public right-of-way and the private property of more than 35 feet, except that, upon a showing under the provisions of section 46-28, such driveway may not be in excess of 45 feet in width. The number and location of driveways are shown on the following table:

Typical access layout illustrating application of regulations to commercial and public access frontage: 
(2)  Except that upon a showing under the provisions of section 46-28, one additional driveway will be permitted, provided that this additional driveway be no closer than 35 feet from the driveway or driveways permitted under the table in subsection (1) of this section. Safety zones separating driveways shall be outlined by curbs or posts as necessary to prohibit parking or driving across zones for all nonresidential uses. If curbs are used, they shall be concrete, asphalt or masonry barrier type curbs approved by the city engineer and not less than four inches in height. If posts are used, they shall be round, six inches in diameter, with domed tops, 23/4 feet in length, and shall be installed six feet apart, extending 15 inches above the ground, painted white and shall have reflector buttons or patches for night visibility when feasible. The barrier line nearest the street shall not be less than 24 feet from the center of the pavement or on line with existing curbs or established curblines. 
(3)  Except where the curb is a roll type curb, the curb return on all driveways shall have a minimum radius of not less than 21/2 feet and the point where the return falls tangent to the curb shall be within the property lines extended of the property which the driveway is designed to serve. Should two or more adjacent grantees agree to combine their property frontage for a combined access facility, it would be authorized under applicable regulations. The frontage will then be the portion of the right-of-way lying between the most distant possible lines of the combined frontage drawn perpendicularly from the center line of the street to the grantee's abutting property line. 
(4)  Sidewalks shall be constructed at an elevation so as to provide for a minimum of one-quarter inch per foot fall from the edge of the sidewalk farthest from the property line to the top of the curb, in business and commercial areas. Sidewalks in other areas will be located in accordance with current subdivision regulations of the city, except that where there is an established practice in the block, sidewalks shall be located to match the existing walks. 
(5)  Where a ramp section of the driveway is to be constructed, the ramp shall reach the grade of the sidewalk at a distance of not less than five feet from the outside edge of the street curbline. 
(6)  The grade for all curbs, sidewalks, driveways and ramps shall be fixed by the city manager. 
(7)  All driveway approaches, ramps and sidewalks constructed in connection therewith for business and commercial establishments shall be constructed of concrete having a minimum of 2500 psi in 28 days, and shall have a minimum thickness of six inches, and shall have reinforcing consisting of a minimum of six-inch by six-inch number six wire mesh, except that driveway approaches and ramps may be constructed of asphalt. 
(Code 1973, § 14-17; Ord. No. 612, § III, 5-8-1962) 
Sec. 46-28. - Variances. 
(a)  Upon the showing that unusual circumstances exist, or that a need for a driveway of greater width exists, or some variance from the requirements set forth in section 46-28 may be made, where such variances will not be contrary to the public interest and that literal enforcement of the provisions of this article will result in unnecessary hardship, the regulations may be varied with the approval of the city manager; provided in no instance shall any driveway opening be in excess of 45 feet in width. Any person requesting that the regulations in section 46-28 be varied because of unusual circumstances shall file a written request therefor with the city manager, setting forth the circumstances to show that literal enforcement of the provisions of this article will result in unnecessary hardship. The city manager shall either approve or deny in writing a request for a variance of the provisions of this article within a reasonable time, but in no event shall the city manager withhold his decision for more than 30 days. 
(b)  Any person aggrieved by the decision of the city manager under the provisions hereof shall have the right to appeal to the city council upon giving written notice to the city council, within five days after the refusal of the application made by him for a permit to construct such driveway or other way. 
(Code 1973, § 14-18; Ord. No. 612, § IV, 5-8-1962) 
Secs. 46-29-46-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 46-60. - Notice to owner. 
    The city council may by ordinance order and compel the laying and constructing of sidewalks by property owners in front of or abutting on their land after giving notice to the owners or agents of the property, the notice to be signed by the city manager attached by the city clerk by mail to the address shown on the city tax rolls, or when the owners or agents are unknown, such notice shall be served by publication in some newspaper published in the city, once each week for four successive weeks. The cost of such publication shall be a charge against the property of such unknown owners, adjacent to which such sidewalk is ordered to be constructed. 
(Code 1973, § 14-46; Ord. No. 31, § 2; Ord. No. 43, 10-7-1912) 
Sec. 46-61. - Completion time; curbing included; permit required. 
    All sidewalks ordered to be constructed shall be completed within 60 days from the serving of the notice provided for in section 46-60, and all curbing shall be completed within 30 days from the service of such notice. The serving of notice to construct sidewalks shall include curbing without special notice to construct curbing; and to secure uniformity in the construction of sidewalks and curbing, no person shall construct a sidewalk without first obtaining a permit from the city inspector or city surveyor, who shall keep in his office a record of all permits issued. 
(Code 1973, § 14-47; Ord. No. 31, § 3; Ord. No. 43, 10-7-1912) 
Sec. 46-62. - Inspection; notice to noncomplying owners. 
    At the expiration of the time a sidewalk is ordered to be completed, the city inspector or city surveyor shall inspect the same and the premises along which such sidewalk was ordered to be constructed, and make his report in writing to the city council, showing what portions of such sidewalk have not been constructed. Thereupon, notice shall be issued to the noncomplying owners or agents of such property requiring them to show cause at the succeeding meeting of the city council, not less than five days after such notice shall have been served, why such sidewalks should not be constructed by the city as provided for in this article and the cost thereof fixed as a charge and lien on the property and premises abutting the same. 
(Code 1973, § 14-48; Ord. No. 31, § 4; Ord. No. 43, 10-7-1912) 
Sec. 46-63. - Construction by city. 
    After the provisions of sections 46-60 through 46-62 have been complied with, if the owner or agent of the property shall have failed or refused to so construct the required sidewalks, then it shall be the duty of the street commissioner in conjunction with the inspector or city surveyor to immediately construct such sidewalk, along the line of the street and abutting the property of the owner or agent failing, refusing or neglecting to construct such sidewalk, by contract or otherwise, after advertising for bids therefor; provided that if the city can do the work at a lower price than the lowest bid so received, then the work may be done by the city directly. The cost of such construction shall be a charge against the owner of, and a lien upon the lot, part of lot or block to be charged with the construction of the sidewalk on which it abuts. 
(Code 1973, § 14-49; Ord. No. 31, § 5; Ord. No. 43, 10-7-1912) 
Sec. 46-64. - Impressing lien. 
    When the required sidewalk shall have been constructed by the city, as is provided for in this article, it shall be the duty of the city manager to correctly estimate the cost of the construction, grading or filling up of the sidewalk abutting each lot, part of lot or block, along the line of the street and they shall enter in a book regularly kept for the purpose, opposite each lot, part of lot or block, the cost of the construction of such sidewalk directly abutting the same, a certified copy of which shall be filed with the county clerk and recorded in the records of mortgages and liens of the office, and shall constitute a lien against such property, and be a charge against the owner thereof, and collected as city taxes are collected under the laws and ordinances of this city. Such estimate shall be sufficient if it contains a general description of the property. Such estimate, duly certified to, showing the amount due by such owner or agent, shall be furnished him upon application therefor. 
(Code 1973, § 14-50; Ord. No. 31, § 6; Ord. No. 43, 10-7-1912) 
Sec. 46-65. - Repair. 
    Whenever any agent or owner of any lot or part of lot or block abutting on any sidewalk in the city, shall be notified to repair the same, and shall fail, neglect or refuse to comply with the notification, the sidewalk shall be repaired by the city in the same manner and by the same means as is provided herein for construction of sidewalks, where the agent or owner fails, neglects or refuses to do so, and every provision of this article relating to the construction of sidewalks where the agents or owners fail, refuse or neglect to construct them, shall apply to the repair of sidewalks by the city. 
(Code 1973, § 14-51; Ord. No. 31, § 7; Ord. No. 43, 10-7-1912) 
Sec. 46-66. - Collection of cost; interest. 
    The cost of sidewalks and curbing shall be collected, if necessary, by sale of the lot or part of lot or block on which it fronts, together with the cost of collection, as taxes due the city are collected, and a sale of any lot or part of lot or block to enforce the collection of the cost of such sidewalk and curbing shall convey a good title to the purchaser, and the balance of the proceeds of the sale, after paying the amount due the city and costs of same, shall be paid to the owner; provided one-fifth of the cost of such sidewalk and curbing shall become delinquent six months after the completion of the sidewalk and one-fifth every six months thereafter until it is all paid and if one installment becomes due and is unpaid, the entire amount remaining unpaid shall immediately become delinquent, and collection thereof may be enforced, which sum shall bear interest from the time of the completion of the work at the rate of eight percent per annum. 
(Code 1973, § 14-52; Ord. No. 31, § 7; Ord. No. 43, 10-7-1912) 
Sec. 46-67. - Punishment for violation. 
    If any person shall fail, neglect or refuse to construct sidewalks in front of or abutting on his land, after being ordered so to do, as in this article provided, or shall fail, neglect or refuse to repair such sidewalks or shall fail, neglect or refuse to construct curbing as provided by this article, he shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished as provided in section 1-14 for each day of such failure, neglect or refusal. 
(Code 1973, § 14-53; Ord. No. 31, § 8; Ord. No. 43, 10-7-1912) 
Secs. 46-68-46-92. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OPENING AND CLOSING PUBLIC WAYS 

Sec. 46-93. - Request; contents. 
    All persons desiring to have the city council exercise its powers regarding the establishment or closing of public streets, alleys or other ways, shall file their request with the city secretary, in writing, directed to the city council. Such request shall contain an accurate description of the street or other public ways or portions thereof desired to be opened or closed or altered, as the case may be, and attached to the request shall be a list of all owners in the block abutting the street or alley, together with the last known address of all the owners. Unless all such owners of abutting property join in the petition, a statement shall be attached to the petition showing the reason for nonparticipation of those who have not signed the petition. 
(Code 1973, § 14-30; Ord. No. 561, § I, 1-24-1961) 
Sec. 46-94. - Deposit for administrative costs. 
    Upon the filing of a request in accordance with section 46-93 with the city secretary, a deposit shall be made with the city secretary of the sum as provided in the city fee schedule to cover the expense of mailing notices as required by section 46-95 and making any necessary publications. 
(Code 1973, § 14-31; Ord. No. 561, § II, 1-24-1961) 
Sec. 46-95. - Public hearing; setting, notice. 
    The city secretary, upon the receipt of a petition and receipt of the required deposit, shall notify the city manager, who shall at the next regular meeting of the city council, notify the city council of the filing of such petition and thereupon the city council, if it deems the request contained in the petition necessary in the public interest, shall direct that a notice of public hearing upon such petition be published in the official newspaper of the city one time and direct the city manager to notify by regular mail all known owners of property abutting on such street or public way or portion thereof of the date, time and place of such public hearing. 
(Code 1973, § 14-32; Ord. No. 561, § III, 5-24-1961) 
Sec. 46-96. - Holding. 
    A public hearing required by section 46-95 shall be held not sooner than ten days nor more than 30 days after the publication of the notice thereof in such newspaper. All persons interested in the matter contained in such petition shall be heard by the city council, after which the city council may, on the date of such public hearing or at any regular or special meeting of the council thereafter, order the street or other public way or portion thereof opened, closed, altered or abandoned as the case may be, and as the city council may find necessary and proper in the public interest. 
(Code 1973, § 14-33; Ord. No. 561, § IV, 2-14-1961) 
Sec. 46-97. - Ordinance directing improvement. 
    The action of the city council upon a petition shall be reflected in an ordinance duly passed by the city council. 
(Code 1973, § 14-34; Ord. No. 561, § V, 2-14-1961) 
Chapter 48 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal and county authority to regulate subdivisions, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 242.001 et seq.; municipal zoning authority generally, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 211.001 et seq.; municipal planning and development generally, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 371.001 et seq.; municipal zoning boards of adjustment, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 211.008; issuance of local permits, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 245.001 et seq.; municipal comprehensive plans, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 213.001 et seq.; authority for municipal regulation of signs, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 216.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 48-1. - Territorial applicability of regulations. 
    The following rules and regulations shall govern the approval and requirements for plats of subdivisions within the corporate limits of the city and within one mile of the corporate limits. 
(Code 1973, § 15-1; Ord. No. 638, 2-12-1963; Ord. No. 1069, § I, 1-25-1972; Ord. No. 2255, § I, 3-24-2015) 
Sec. 48-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commission means the city planning commission. 
    Street or alley means a way for vehicular traffic, whether designated as a street, highway, thoroughfare, freeway, parkway, throughway, road, avenue, boulevard, lane, place, or however otherwise designated. 
(1)  Major arterial streets provide for through traffic movement between areas of the city and across the city. Access to abutting property is permitted from arterial streets. They connect principal traffic generators within the city and rural routes. Arterial streets should border residential neighborhoods rather than to bisect them. 
(2)  Major collector streets are connecting streets between major arterial streets and serve traffic from several neighborhoods collecting traffic from local or minor collector streets. 
(3)  Minor collector streets serve a single neighborhood or subdivision collecting traffic from local streets and leading to a major collector or major arterial street. 
(4)  Local streets are those which are used primarily for access to the abutting residential properties and which are intended to serve traffic within a limited residential district. 
(5)  Marginal access streets are minor streets which are parallel to and adjacent to arterial streets and highways, and which provide access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic. 
(6)  Alleys are minor ways which are used primarily for vehicular service access to the back or the side of properties otherwise abutting on a street. 
    Subdivider or developer are synonymous and are used interchangeably, and means any person or any officer, agent, employee, servant and trustee thereof, who does, or participates in the doing of, any act toward the subdivision of land within the intent, scope and purview of this chapter. 
    Subdivision means the division of any tract of land within the city or within one mile thereof into two or more parts, or the laying out of suburban lots or building lots or any lots, and streets, alleys, parks or other property intended for public use, or for the use of purchasers or owners of lots fronting thereon or adjacent thereto. This definition includes the resubdivision of land or lots which are a part of a previously recorded subdivision. The following are not defined as subdivisions: A division of land into tracts greater than five acres in size not involving any new streets or easements; a division of property between two or more owners of an undivided interest by court order. An addition is a subdivision as defined herein. 
    Townhouse subdivision means those developments in which it is proposed to partition land into individually owned lots for townhouses where under specific conditions the minimum lot sizes may be less than those required for other single family homes. The term "townhouse" is defined in city zoning regulations. 
(Code 1973, § 15-2; Ord. No. 1069, § I, 1-25-1972; Ord. No. 1115, § 2, 4-24-1973; Ord. No. 2255, § II, 3-24-2015) 
Sec. 48-3. - Variances. 
(a)  Hardship. Where the planning commission finds that extraordinary hardships may result from strict compliance with this chapter, it may vary the regulations so that substantial justice may be done and the public interest secured; provided that such variation will not have the effect of nullifying the intent and purpose of the general community plan or this chapter. 
(b)  Conditions. In granting variances and modifications, the planning commission may require such conditions as will, in its judgment, secure substantially the objectives of the standards or requirements so varied or modified. 
(Code 1973, § 15-9; Ord. No. 638, § VIII, 2-12-1963) 
Sec. 48-4. - Appeal. 
    Any subdivider contesting any disapproval or the interpretation or application of any rule, standard, regulation, determination, requirement or necessity set forth in this chapter directly or by delegation of authority shall have the right, by filing a written request with the secretary of the city council within 30 days of his receipt of the written objections of the planning commission to have a hearing thereon before the city council, within 15 days after the date of filing of such request. If the subdivider is dissatisfied with the finding of the city council after such hearing, he may appeal such ruling to any appropriate court of competent jurisdiction, in which the matter shall be determined in a trial be novo, and it is expressly provided that the substantial evidence rule shall not be applicable in such appeal. 
(Code 1973, § 15-10; Ord. No. 638, § X, 2-12-1963) 
Secs. 48-5-48-26. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PROCEDURE 

Sec. 48-27. - Planning commission approval and conformity to chapter required. 
(a)  Before any plan, plat or replat of a subdivision of land inside the city or within one mile of the city limits thereof shall be recorded with the county clerk, it shall first be approved by the planning commission in conformity with state law and the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  No transfer of land in the nature of a subdivision shall be exempt from the provisions of this chapter even though the instrument or document of transfer may describe land so subdivided by metes and bounds. 
(c)  The filing of any plan, plat or replat without complying with the requirements of this chapter, or the transfer of land by the filing of any instrument in the nature of a conveyance without having first complied with the requirements of this chapter, shall be deemed a violation of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 15-3; Ord. No. 638, § II, 2-12-1963; Ord. No. 1069, § I, 1-25-1972; Ord. No. 2255, § III, 3-24-2015) 
Sec. 48-28. - Plat review and approval. 
(a)  Conference. Prior to the filing of an application for conditional approval of the preliminary plat, the subdivider shall confer with the city manager or his designee on an informal basis to discuss the proposed plat, its conformity to this chapter, relationship to surrounding property, streets, etc. 
(b)  Procedure for conditional approval of preliminary plat. 
(1)  Any person proposing to subdivide a tract of land within the city or within one mile of the city shall first prepare and submit to the planning commission a preliminary plat together with supplementary material as specified in section 48-29, except that when no new street for the public use is involved and no more than three lots are involved, the person wishing to subdivide may file a final plat, if he wishes, without the necessity of a preliminary plat as specified in this chapter. 
(2)  Four copies of the preliminary plat and supplementary material shall be submitted to the planning commission with written application for conditional approval at least 14 days prior to the meeting at which it is to be considered. 
(3)  On receipt of a preliminary plat and supplementary information, the planning commission shall render a decision thereon within 30 days. Such decision may consist of approval, disapproval or conditional approval. Conditional approval shall be considered to be approval of a plat or replat subject to conformity with the prescribed conditions, but shall be deemed to be a disapproval of such plat or replat until such conditions are complied with. All objections made to the preliminary plat or conditions imposed, shall be furnished to the subdivider in writing. 
(4)  When a preliminary plat has been approved, the subdivider may thereafter file a final plat or plats of sections of the subdivision upon which approval of the preliminary plat has been obtained, and upon the filing of a final plat or plats covering a portion of such subdivision, the remainder of the preliminary plat shall be deemed as considered approved or conditionally approved as in subsection (b)(3) of this section; provided, however, that such approval or conditional approval of the remainder of the preliminary plat shall be limited to a two year period; provided further, however, that the planning commission may at its discretion extend such period of validity. When a preliminary plat has been approved and thereafter the subdivider fails to file a plat of the subdivision or a section thereof within a period of six months, the approval of the preliminary plat shall be void, except, however, the planning commission may, in its discretion, extend such period of validity. 
(5)  The action of the planning commission shall be noted on two copies of the preliminary plat, referenced and attached to any conditions determined. One copy shall be returned to the subdivider and the other retained by the planning commission. 
(c)  Procedure for approval of final plats. 
(1)  The final plat shall conform substantially to the preliminary plat as approved, and if desired by the subdivider, it may constitute only that portion of the approved preliminary plat proposed to be recorded and developed at the time; provided, however, that such portion conforms to all requirements of this chapter. 
(2)  Application for approval of the final plat shall be submitted in writing to the planning commission at least 14 days prior to the meeting at which it is to be considered. 
(3)  Four copies of the final plat and other exhibits required for approval shall be prepared as specified in section 48-29, and shall be submitted to the planning commission within six months after approval of the preliminary plat; otherwise, such approval shall become null and void unless an extension of time is applied for and granted by the planning commission. 
(Code 1973, § 15-4; Ord. No. 638, § III, 2-12-1963; Ord. No. 1069, § I, 1-25-1972; Ord. No. 2255, § IV, 3-24-2015) 
Sec. 48-29. - Plat standards and specifications. 
(a)  Preliminary plats and data for conditional approval. The preliminary plat shall be drawn on a scale on 100 feet to the inch or larger and shall show the following: 
(1)  The title, north point, direction of prevailing breeze, scale and date; 
(2)  The name of the owner or owners and the engineer or surveyor; 
(3)  Vicinity sketch or key map at a scale of not more than 400 feet to the inch which shall show all existing subdivisions, streets and tracts of acreage in the area and the general drainage plan, ultimate destination of water and possible storm sewer connections by arrows; 
(4)  The outline of the tract the plat is proposed to subdivide with principal dimensions; 
(5)  The locations and names of existing streets and any blocks, lots, alleys, easements, building lines and watercourses or other natural features in the area affected, with principal dimensions, and all significant information, including ownership of the property immediately adjacent or across boundary streets on all sides for a distance of not less than 200 feet; 
(6)  The proposed plan of subdivision, showing streets, blocks, lots, alleys, easements, building lines, parks, etc., with principal dimensions. The preliminary plat shall cover all of the tract intended to be developed, at any time, even though it is intended by the developer or developers to file final plats and install improvements for parts of the tract by sections or units; 
(7)  The location of existing sewers, water and gas mains and other public utilities, if any; 
(8)  The names of proposed streets when new streets for public use are involved. Such names shall conform to the existing streets of which they may be or become extensions or otherwise shall not duplicate or conflict with the recognized name of any other street located in the area subject to this chapter; 
(9)  Proposed general plan for storm water drainage sufficiently detailed to indicate the location of drainage ditches or structures and the direction of flow when a new street for public use is involved; 
(10)  Any proposed zoning district change for which an application has been or will be made; 
(11)  Watercourses and all trees over eight inches in diameter between street lines when a new street for public use is involved; and 
(12)  Contours of not more than five-foot intervals may be required by the planning commission. 
(b)  Plats and data for final approval. The final plat shall be drawn to a scale of one inch to 100 feet or larger, in ink or linen, acetate film or velum, with all figures legible. The final plat shall show the following: 
(1)  The title or name by which the subdivision is to be identified, north point, scale of the map and the name of the registered professional engineer or licensed state land surveyor responsible; 
(2)  A definite legal description and identification of the tract being subdivided, which description shall be sufficient for the requirements of title examination. The plat shall be a descriptive diagram, drawn to scale, and shall show by reference that the subdivision is a particular portion or part of a previously filed plat or an original grant, which diagram and description shall show as being included in the subdivision, at least, all of the smallest unit of the last filed subdivision, plat or grant, out of which the instant subdivision is divided, or so much thereof as is owned by the subdivider; 
(3)  The boundaries of the subdivided property, the location or designation of all streets, alleys, parks and other areas intended to be dedicated or deeded to public use, with proper dimensions. The boundaries shall be indicated by a heavy line equivalent to a number five Payzant pen and shall be tied by dimension to the established center line of all existing boundary streets; 
(4)  The location of all adjacent streets and alleys, with their names, and the names of adjoining subdivisions with exact location and designation by number of lots and blocks; 
(5)  All lot, block and street boundary lines, with blocks and lots numbered or lettered consecutively. Building lines and easements shall be shown and shall be defined by dimension. The actual width of all streets shall be shown, measured at right angles or radially, where curved. All principal lines shall have the bearing given and any deviation from the norm indicated; 
(6)  Accurate dimensions, both linear and angular, of all items on the plat; the boundary survey on the site shall close and the plat for record shall so show. The angular dimensions may be shown by bearings. Curved boundaries shall be fully described and all essential information given. Circular curves shall be defined by actual length of a radius and not by degree of curve. Complete dimensional data shall be given on fractional lots; 
(7)  The description and location of all lot and block corners and permanent survey reference monuments shall be shown; 
(8)  A certificate of ownership in fee of all land embraced in the subdivision, and of the authenticity of the plat for dedication, signed and acknowledged by all owners of any interest in the land. The acknowledgment shall be in the form required in the conveyance of real estate. Approval and acceptance of all lienholders shall be included; 
(9)  A certificate by the registered professional engineer in charge or licensed land surveyor, duly authenticated, that the plat is true and correct and in accordance with the determination of surveys actually made on the ground. If the engineer or licensed land surveyor who, prepared the plat did not make the original boundary survey, this fact should be noted in the certificate. Also the certificate should show whether or not the tract is within one mile of the city limits, measured in a straight line from the nearest point in the city limits, unless the information is shown in a suitable manner elsewhere on the face of the plat; and 
(10)  In addition to other required certificates, the following form shall be printed or lettered on the plat: 
"STATE OF TEXAS 
 COUNTY OF BEE 
This plat of ____________ Subdivision approved ____________ / ____________ / ____________ (date) by the city planning commission of the city. This the ____________ day of ____________ , 20 ____________ . 
_____
Secretary _____
Chairman"  
(11)  If a subdivision is located outside the city limits, but within one mile of the city limits and provides for the dedication of area for streets or other public use, the plat shall provide a form in blank to record the acceptance of the plat by the county commissioner's court as follows: 
"STATE OF TEXAS COUNTY OF BEE 
I, ____________ , Clerk of the commissioner's Court of Bee County, Texas, do hereby certify that the foregoing map was approved and accepted by the commissioner's Court on the ____________ day of ____________ , 20 ____________ , as shown by order or record in minutes of the Court in Vol. ____________ on page ____________ . 
Witness my hand and the seal of the Court as office in Beeville, Texas, this the ____________ day of ____________ , 20 ____________ . 
_____
Clerk of the Commissioner's Court 
of Bee County, Texas"  
(12)  The final plat submitted to the planning commission and to be filed for record with the county clerk shall not show the construction features such as curblines or public utility lines or other structures not involved in the title covenant. 
(Code 1973, § 15-5; Ord. No. 638, § IV, 2-12-1963; Ord. No. 763, § I, 8-24-1965; Ord. No. 1069, § I, 1-25-1972; Ord. No. 2255, § V, 3-24-2015) 
Sec. 48-30. - Platting of land for mobile home subdivisions. 
(a)  The regulations governing the requirements and approval for platting of subdivisions within the corporate limits of the city and within its extraterritorial jurisdiction shall apply for platting of land for mobile home subdivisions except as set forth herein. 
(b)  Mobile home subdivisions inside the city shall be located only in a "M/H" Mobile Home Park/Mobile Home Subdivision District and requirements of the "M/H" district shall apply for such subdivisions located inside the city or within the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction. 
(Code 1973, § 15-5.1; Ord. No. 1116, §§ 1, 2, 4-24-1973) 
Secs. 48-31-48-48. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DESIGN, REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS AND MAINTENANCE 

Sec. 48-49. - Design standards. 
(a)  Streets. 
(1)  The arrangement, character, extent, width, grade and location of all streets shall conform to the general community plan and shall be considered in their relation to existing and planned streets, to topographical conditions, to public convenience and safety, and in their appropriate relation to the proposed uses of the land to be served by such streets. 
(2)  Where such is not shown in the general community plan, the arrangements of streets in a subdivision shall either: 
a.  Provide for the continuation or appropriate projection of existing principal streets in surrounding areas; or 
b.  Conform to a plan for the neighborhood, approved or adopted by the planning commission to meet a particular situation where topographical or other conditions make continuance or conformance to existing streets impractical. 
(3)  Minor streets shall be so laid out that their use by through traffic will be discouraged. 
(4)  Where a subdivision abuts or contains an existing or proposed arterial street, the planning commission may require marginal access streets, reverse frontage with screen planting contained in a nonaccess reservation along the rear property line, deep lots with rear service alleys, or such other treatment as may be necessary for adequate protection of residential properties and to afford separation of through and local traffic. 
(5)  Where a subdivision borders on or contains a railroad right-of-way or limited access highway right-of-way, the planning commission may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way, at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land, as for park purposes in residential districts or for commercial or industrial purposes in appropriate districts. Such distances shall also be determined with due regard for the requirements of approach grades and future grade separations. 
(6)  Reserve strips controlling access to streets may be prohibited except where their control is definitely placed in the city or county. 
(7)  Street jogs with center line offsets of less than 125 feet shall be avoided. 
(8)  A tangent at least 100 feet long shall be introduced between reverse curves on arterial and collector streets. 
(9)  When connecting street lines deflect from each other at any one point by more than ten degrees, they shall be connected by a curve with a radius adequate to ensure sight distance of not less than 50 feet for minor and collector streets and of such greater radii as the planning commission shall determine for special cases. 
(10)  Streets shall be laid out so as to intersect as nearly as possible at right angles and no street shall intersect any other street at less than 60 degrees. 
(11)  Property lines at street intersections shall be rounded with a radius of 15 feet, or of a greater radius where the planning commission may deem it necessary. The planning commission may permit comparable cutoffs of chords in place of rounded corners. 
(12)  Street right-of-way widths shall be as shown in the general community plan and where not shown therein shall not be less than as follows: 
Street type Right-of-way (feet) Arterial (major thoroughfare) 100 Major collector 65 Minor collector 55 Minor or residential 50 Marginal access 40  
(13)  Half streets shall be prohibited, except where essential to the reasonable development of the subdivision in conformity with the other requirements of this chapter; and where the planning commission finds it will be practicable to require the dedication of the other half when the adjoining property is subdivided. Wherever a half street is adjacent to a tract to be subdivided, the other half of the street shall be platted within such tract. 
(14)  Dead-end streets, designed to be so permanently, shall be longer than 400 feet and shall be provided at the closed end with a turnaround having an outside roadway diameter of at least 80 feet, and a street property line diameter of at least 100 feet. 
(15)  No street names shall be used which will duplicate or be confused with the names of existing streets. Street names shall be subject to the approval of the planning commission. 
(16)  No street grade shall be less than three-tenths of one percent. 
(b)  Alleys. 
(1)  Alleys may be provided in subdivisions and in the case of commercial and industrial districts shall be required where other definite and ensured provisions are not made for service access, such as off-street loading, unloading and parking consistent with and adequate for the uses proposed. 
(2)  The width of all alleys shall be 20 feet. 
(3)  Alley intersections and sharp changes in alignment shall be avoided, but where necessary, corners shall be cut off sufficiently to permit safe vehicular movement. 
(4)  Dead-end alleys shall be avoided where possible, but if unavoidable, shall be provided with adequate turnaround facilities at the dead end, as determined by the planning commission. 
(c)  Easements. 
(1)  Easements across lots or centered on rear or side lot liens shall be provided for utilities where necessary and shall be at least 15 feet wide when centered on rear lot lines. 
(2)  Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainage way, channel or stream, there shall be provided a storm water easement or drainage right-of-way conforming substantially to the lines of such watercourse, and such further width or construction, or both, as will be adequate for the purpose. Parallel streets or parkways may be required in connection therewith. 
(d)  Blocks. 
(1)  The lengths, widths and shapes of blocks shall be determined with due regard to: 
a.  Provision of adequate building sites suitable to the special needs of the type of use contemplated; 
b.  Zoning requirements as to lot sizes and dimensions; 
c.  Needs for convenient access, circulation, control and safety of street traffic; or 
d.  Limitations and opportunities of topography. 
(2)  Block lengths shall not exceed 1,600 feet or be less than 300 feet in length. Whenever a block exceeds 600 feet, aerial side lot line easements of at least ten feet centered on side lot lines shall be provided for street light wiring from rear lot line utility easement or alley. 
(e)  Lots. 
(1)  The lot size, width, depth, shape and orientation, and the minimum building setback lines shall be appropriate for the location of the subdivision and for the type of development and use contemplated and shall conform to the standards and requirements of the city zoning ordinance, as amended. 
a.  Residential lots where not served by a public sewer shall not be less than 100 feet wide, nor less than 12,000 square feet in area. 
b.  Depth and width of properties reserved or laid out for business and industrial purposes shall be adequate to provide for the off-street service and parking facilities required by the type of use and development contemplated. 
(2)  Corner lots for residential use shall have extra width to permit appropriate building setback from and orientation to both streets. 
(3)  The subdividing of the land shall be such as to provide, by means of a public street, each lot with satisfactory access to an existing public street. 
(4)  Double frontage and reverse frontage lots should be avoided except where essential to provide separation of residential development from traffic arteries or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation. A planting screen easement of at least ten feet, and across which there shall be no right of access may be provided along the line of lots abutting such a traffic artery or other disadvantageous use. 
(5)  Side lot lines shall be substantially at right angles or radial to street lines. 
(f)  Unsuitable land. Land which the planning commission has found to be unsuitable for subdivision due to flooding, bad drainage and other features likely to be harmful to the safety, welfare and general health of the future residents, and which the planning commission considers inappropriate for subdivision, shall not be subdivided unless adequate methods for correcting same are formulated and agreed to by the developer. 
(Code 1973, § 15-6; Ord. No. 638, § V, 2-12-1963; Ord. No. 885, § I, 3-12-1998) 
Sec. 48-50. - Required improvements. 
(a)  Monuments. 
(1)  Monuments shall be placed at all block corners, angle points, points of curves in streets, and at intermediate points as required by the planning commission. 
(2)  Monuments shall be made of an iron rod three-quarters of an inch in diameter and from 24 to 30 inches in length with its top set flush with the ground. 
(3)  Iron pins at lot corners shall be of one-half-inch iron rods, 24 inches long, with top set flush with the ground. 
(b)  Utility and street improvements. 
(1)  Before beginning any construction of the improvements outlined in this section on proposed roadways, sidewalks or public utilities pertaining to the subdivision, one complete set of plans and specifications of such construction, in the form of plats, maps and sketches or other satisfactory written description shall be prepared by the property owner or developer and shall be filed with the planning commission. These shall show such features as roadways, cross sections and longitudinal slope for drainage, full description of proposed pavement, sidewalk or street improvements, its grade and slope, dimensions and specifications concerning public utilities to be installed showing proposed position on the ground, specifications of material and construction, and profile maps of all sanitary and storm sewers showing both ground surface and flow line, and any other pertinent information of similar nature. The property owner and his agents or employees shall do and perform all work of building and constructing such improvements. All such work shall be performed under the city's supervision and approval. Performance bonds and complete insurance coverage shall be furnished as the city may require. All improvements shall be designed and constructed in accordance with standard specifications adopted by the city council for other similar construction, or in the absence of adopted specifications, in accordance with specifications approved by the planning commission. 
(2)  The following minimum standards for improvements shall be agreed to and complied with in each subdivision or addition before final approval of a plat by the planning commission. 
a.  Street or roadway pavement. Widths of pavement, measuring from the face of the curb, for the various types of streets, shall not be less than the following: 
Major arterial Two 33 foot pavements with a 16-foot median Major collector 44 feet Minor collector 36 feet Local 30 feet Marginal access 20 feet  
b.  Curb and gutter. Curbs and gutters shall be constructed on each side of each street within a subdivision. The curb shall be of a standard adopted by the city council. Subdivisions, the greater part of which are beyond one-half mile from the city limits and in certain other locations deemed by the planning commission to warrant special consideration, may have side ditches with side slopes not steeper than one on five. Where side ditches are elected, the minimum right-of-way for such street and side ditches shall be increased a minimum of ten feet and where deemed necessary by the planning commission, the required right-of-way width may be greater than the minimum to accommodate adequate size drainage structures. 
c.  Sidewalks. Sidewalks shall be required. They shall have a width of not less than four feet and a thickness of not less than four inches and shall be placed with the inside edge on the property line within the street right-of-way and shall extend along all street frontage including the side of corner lots and block ends; provided, however, that where it is impractical for the subdivider to provide such sidewalks on the side lot lines abutting major thoroughfares or drainage ditches, then in those instances sidewalks shall not be required. 
d.  Alley pavement. Alley pavements shall be a minimum of 12 feet in width and have a flexible base six inches thick, and a two course inverted topping. 
e.  Sanitary sewers. Where a public sanitary sewer is reasonably accessible, each lot within a subdivided area shall be provided with a connection to such sanitary sewer. The minimum size of mains shall be eight inches. When any proposed subdivision is not reasonably accessible to a public sanitary sewer, provision shall be made for the use of either septic tanks or an individual sewage treatment plant as follows: 
1.  Septic tanks. In all subdivisions planned for septic tank use, the minimum lot area shall be one-half acre per single-family dwelling. Septic tanks shall be installed on each lot concurrent with any development thereon, and the design of such system and the method of installation shall conform in all respects to the requirements of the county health unit. The county health unit shall have the authority to vary the lot area requirement where satisfactory evidence is presented indicating that soil conditions are such as to warrant a change. 
2.  Individual sewage treatment plant. In all subdivisions planned or to be serviced by an individual sewage treatment plant, lots may be of standard area and sewers shall be installed to serve each lot. The plant providing such sewage disposal facilities shall be constructed in accordance with the regulations and requirements of the state board of health and with the approval and under the supervision of the county health unit. 
f.  Water lines. 
1.  Where an approved public water supply is reasonably accessible or procurable, each lot within the subdivided area shall be provided with access to such water supply. The design of the system shall be such as to form a loop of at least six inch mains. No main shall be smaller than four inches, except that two inch stubs may be extended to serve a maximum of three lots. 
2.  In areas where a public water supply is not available, the subdivider shall construct other facilities in such a manner that an adequate supply of potable water shall be available to every lot in the subdivision. Such water supply system shall be constructed under the supervision of the county health unit and shall comply with all regulations of the state board of health in regard to such systems. 
g.  Utility lines. Where it shall be determined that larger mains or lines are required in order to provide for the future extension of the utility system beyond the limits of the subdivision in question, the city shall assume the responsibility for and pay any additional cost at the time of construction of same. 
h.  Drainage. Drainage shall be provided by surface construction or storm sewers. 
i.  Utility lines. All electric light and power lines and telephone lines shall be located in alleyways or along easements at the back side of lots where practical. No such utility lines shall be in the street right-of-way. 
j.  Utility extensions. Whenever a final plat of a subdivision is approved for which no city-approved water or sewer is available at the boundary of the subdivision, the same shall be provided at the subdivider's cost, as follows: 
1.  The city shall secure any necessary easement right-of-way therefor. 
2.  The subdivider shall install, or have installed, or contract with the city for the installation of such facility or facilities from the most practical existing source satisfactory to the city to the boundary of the subdivision in accordance with standard city requirements for comparable lines and extensions, and in conformity with the master plan for the extension of such utility and subject to the approval of the specifications, supervision and costs thereof by the city council. 
3.  The costs of such extensions shall be borne by the subdivider; provided, however, where the size of the extended facility is greater than is reasonably necessary to serve the subdivision adequately and the increase or excess in such size is made at the direction of the city, the city shall pay the pro rata cost of such increase or excess. In every such case, the city council shall first determine it to be in the public interest and convenience and necessity that the increase or excess facility size be made. 
(Code 1973, § 15-7; Ord. No. 638, § VI, 2-12-1963; Ord. No. 763, § II, 8-24-1965; Ord. No. 1069, § I, 1-25-1972; Ord. No. 2255, §§ VI, VII, 3-24-2015) 
Sec. 48-51. - Maintenance of property. 
    It shall be the duty of the developer to maintain all vacant property owned by him in an approved subdivision within the city limits in a manner so as not to create any fire and health hazard through accumulation of debris, discarded building materials, weed growth or any other condition creating a fire or health hazard through a lack of maintenance. In the event the city health inspector or other authorized city official deems the property to be a health or fire hazard, and states so in writing to the developer, and requests that the property be cleaned of all such materials or weeds, and the developer fails to do so within ten days, the city shall have the right to clear the property with its own forces. A record of the hours and equipment used shall be kept for a total cost, which will be payable to the city by the subdivider owning the property. The city building inspector shall be furnished this information and shall issue no further permits to the developer until payment is received for the work done by the city in cleaning the property. 
(Code 1973, § 15-8; Ord. No. 638, § VII, 2-12-1963) 
Sec. 48-52. - Street lighting. 
(a)  The subdivider shall install, at the subdivider's expense, street lights on all interior streets and on those perimeter streets designated by the planning commission. 
(b)  Electrical supply cables to the street lights shall be placed underground unless a special or extraordinary condition exists that, in the opinion of the planning commission, would make underground installation undesirable. Installation shall comply with all applicable city building and zoning restrictions, in addition to the requirements of this section. 
(c)  Street lighting shall include at least one street light at each interior street intersection in the principal area of every cul-de-sac. Street lights shall be no more than 300 feet apart. 
(d)  Where feasible, the city shall establish such standards for street lights within a subdivision as conform to standards used in the local geographic area by the utility furnishing electrical power to the subdivision. Unless otherwise provided by the planning commission, all poles or standards for street lights shall be metallic and shall be uniform throughout the subdivision. 
(e)  The planning commission may, at its discretion, require and collect in advance from the subdivider payment for the operational cost of street lights for a period of one year from their final acceptance by the city, which acceptance shall be made in writing after the lights have been installed and operating for a period of two months. The advance payment shall be calculated using the current rates established by the utility for that type of service. 
(f)  If a street light or the standard upon which it is erected does not meet the manufacturer's warranty, or the light or standard shall fail because of defects of manufacturer or improper installation, the subdivision and the manufacturer shall be jointly and severally liable for prompt replacement or repair of the light or standard upon which it is erected, notwithstanding such warranty, in a manner acceptable to the city. 
(Ord. No. 1315, 5-22-1979) 
Chapter 50 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal Sales and Use Tax Act, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 321.001 et seq.; Development Corporation Act, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 501.001 et seq.; real and tangible personal property taxable, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.01; intangible personal property taxable, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.02; freeport exemption of tangible personal property, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 11.251; homestead exemption, V.T.C.A., Property Code § 41.001; municipal hotel occupancy taxes, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 351.001 et seq.; tax abatement in municipal reinvestment zones, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 312.201 et seq.; authority to levy certain occupation taxes, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 101.008. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 50-1-50-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AD VALOREM TAX 

Sec. 50-19. - Ad valorem tax due and delinquency dates; penalties and interest. 
    The ad valorem taxes levied by the city council each year shall become due on October 1 of the year for which the levy is made and may be paid up to and including the following January 31 without penalty, but if not so paid, such taxes shall become delinquent on the following day, February 1, and the following penalty shall be payable thereon: If paid during the month of February, one percent; March, two percent; April, three percent; May, four percent; June, five percent; and on and after the first day of July, eight percent; Such unpaid taxes shall bear interest at the rate of six percent per annum from February 1 of the year next succeeding the year for which such taxes where levied or assessed. 
(Code 1973, § 6-1; Ord. No. 210, 2-13-1940; Ord. No. 1642, 12-20-1989) 
Sec. 50-20. - Taxpayer's oath. 
    The following oath shall be administered to each person upon the rendition of property for taxation: 
"I solemnly swear that the above is a full and complete inventory of the property possessed or controlled by ____________ within the limits of the city, not exempt from taxation on the first day of January, so far as I know or believe." 
(Code 1973, § 6-2; Ord. No. 3) 
Secs. 50-21-50-43. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICES 

Sec. 50-44. - Tax on telecommunications services. 
    A tax is hereby authorized on all telecommunications services sold within the city. For purposes of this section, the sale of telecommunications services is consummated at the location of the telephone or other telecommunications devise from which the call or other communication originates. If the point of origin cannot be determined, the sale is consummated at the address to which the call or other communication is billed. The rate of the tax imposed by this section shall be the same as the rate imposed by the city for all other local sales and use taxes as authorized by the legislature of the state. 
(Ord. No. 1788, 9-27-1994) 
Secs. 50-45-50-61. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - HOTEL-MOTEL OCCUPANCY TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal hotel occupancy taxes, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 351.001 et seq.; levy of tax authorized, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 351.002; tax rates, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 351.003. 

Sec. 50-62. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Consideration means the cost of the room in a hotel only if the room is ordinarily used for sleeping and not including the cost of any food served or personal services rendered to the occupant of such room not related to the cleaning and readying of such room for occupancy. 
    Extra territorial jurisdiction (ETJ) means the unincorporated area that is contiguous to corporate boundaries of the municipality and that is located within one mile of those boundaries, in the case of a municipality with 5,000 to 24,999 inhabitants. 
    Finance director means the finance director of the city. 
    Hotel means any building or buildings in which the public may, for a consideration, obtain sleeping accommodations, including hotels, motels, tourist homes, houses or courts, lodging houses, inns, rooming houses or other buildings where rooms are furnished for a consideration, but not including hospitals, or sanitariums or nursing homes. 
    Occupancy means the use or possession, or the right to the use or possession, of any room or rooms in a hotel if the room is one which is ordinarily used for sleeping and if the occupant is other than the permanent resident as hereinafter defined. 
    Occupant means anyone who, of a consideration, uses, possesses, or has a right to use or possess any room or rooms in a hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license, contract or agreement, other than a permanent resident as hereinafter defined. 
    Permanent resident means any occupant who has or shall have the right to occupancy of any room or rooms in a hotel for at least 30 consecutive days during the calendar year or preceding year. 
    Person means any individual, company, corporation or association owning, operating, managing or controlling any hotel. 
    Quarterly period means the regular calendar quarters of the city's fiscal year, the first quarter being composed of the months of October, November, and December; the second quarter being the months of January, February, and March; the third quarter being the months of April, May, and June; and the fourth quarter being the months of July, August, and September. 
(Ord. No. 1927, § 1, 10-10-2000) 
Sec. 50-63. - Tax levied; exemptions. 
(a)  There is hereby levied a tax of seven percent of the price paid for a room in a hotel on every person who, under a lease, concession, permit, right of access, license, contract or agreement, pays for the use or possession or for the right to the use or possession of a room that is in a hotel, costs $2.00 or more each day, and is ordinarily used for sleeping. The price of a room in a hotel does not include the cost of food served by the hotel and the cost of personal services performed by the hotel for the person except those services related to the cleaning and readying of the room for possession. 
(b)  The following shall be exemptions from subsection (a) of this section: 
(1)  No tax shall be imposed upon a permanent resident. 
(2)  No tax shall be imposed on diplomatic personnel who present a tax exempt card issued by the United States Department of State. 
(3)  No tax shall be imposed on federal or state military personnel traveling on official military business. This exemption does not cover military personnel on leave or between stations. 
(Ord. No. 1927, § 2, 10-10-2000) 
Sec. 50-64. - Collection of tax. 
    Every person owning, operating, managing or controlling any hotel within the city limits and those within the ETJ of the city shall collect the tax levied by this article. The hotel-motel operator shall be entitled to one percent of the occupancy tax revenues collected as reimbursement for the operator's administrative costs for collecting the tax. However, as here in below provided, this reimbursement may be forfeited at the discretion of the city if the hotel-motel operator fails to timely pay over the tax or timely file a report as required by the city or file a false report with the city. 
(Ord. No. 1927, § 3, 10-10-2000) 
Sec. 50-65. - Quarterly reports to the finance director. 
    On the last day of the month following each quarterly period, every person required to collect the tax imposed hereby shall file a report with the finance director showing the price paid for all room occupancies and any other information the finance director may reasonably require. Such person shall pay the tax due on such occupancies at the time of filing such report. The report shall be in a form prescribed by the finance director. The finance director is hereby authorized and directed to do all such things necessary or convenient to carry out the terms of this article. The finance director shall have the authority to request and receive within a reasonably time documentation or information contained in the report to the city by the hotel. 
(Ord. No. 1927, § 4, 10-10-2000) 
Sec. 50-66. - Rules and regulations of the finance director pertaining to access to books and records. 
    The finance director shall have the power to make such rules and regulations as are reasonable and necessary to effectively collect the tax levied hereby, and shall, upon reasonable notice, have access to books and records necessary to enable him to determine the correctness of any report filed as required by this article, and the amount of taxes due under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1927, § 5, 10-10-2000) 
Sec. 50-67. - Penalties. 
(a)  If any person shall fail to file a report as required herein or shall file a false report or shall fail to pay to the finance director the tax as imposed herein when the report or payment is due, he shall forfeit five percent of the amount due as penalty and after the first 30 days, he shall forfeit an additional five percent of such tax. However, such penalty shall never be less than $1.00. Delinquent taxes shall draw interest at the rate of ten percent per annum beginning 60 days from due date. 
(b)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this article, including hotel operators who fail to collect the tax, fail to file a return, file a false return or who are delinquent in their tax payment, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction, be fined in any sum not to exceed $500.00 and each 24 hours of any such conviction shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1927, § 6, 10-10-2000) 
Sec. 50-68. - Additional penalties. 
    The city is hereby authorized to take the following actions against any person required to collect the tax imposed hereby and pay the collection over to the city and who failed to file a report, or filed a false report or failed to pay the tax when due: 
(1)  Bring suit against the hotel for noncompliance; or 
(2)  Bring suit against the hotel seeking any other remedies provided under Texas law. 
(Ord. No. 1927, § 7, 10-10-2000) 
Sec. 50-69. - Authorization to bring suit. 
    The city attorney is hereby authorized to bring suit against any person required to collect the tax imposed hereby and required to pay the collection over to the city and who has failed to file a report, or filed a false report or failed to pay the tax when due. Such suit may seek to collect such tax not paid or to enjoin such person from operating a hotel in the city until the tax is paid or the report is filed or both, as applicable and as provided in the injunction. 
(Ord. No. 1927, § 8, 10-10-2000) 
Sec. 50-70. - Use of revenue. 
    The revenue derived from any hotel occupancy tax imposed and levied by this article may be used in accordance with the Tax Code, section 351 or amended thereof to promote tourism and the convention and hotel industry, and that use is limited to the following: 
(1)  The acquisition of sites for and the construction, improvement, enlarging, equipping, repairing, operation and maintenance of convention center facilities; 
(2)  The furnishing of facilities, personnel and materials for the registration of convention delegates or registrants; 
(3)  Advertising and conducting solicitations and promotional programs to attract tourists and convention delegates or registrants to the municipality or its vicinity; 
(4)  The encouragement, promotion, improvement and application of the arts, including instrument and vocal music, dance, drama, folk art, creative writing, architecture, design and allied fields, painting, sculpture, photography, graphic and craft arts, motion pictures, radio, television, tape and sound recording, and other arts related to the presentation, performance, execution and exhibition of these major art forms; and 
(5)  Historical restoration and preservation projects or activities or advertising and conducting solicitations and promotional programs to encourage tourists and convention delegates to visit preserved historic sites or museums: 
a.  Which are at or in the immediate vicinity of convention center facilities; or 
b.  Which are located elsewhere in the municipality or its vicinity that would be frequented by tourists, convention delegates or other visitors to the municipality. 
(6)  Revenue derived from the hotel-motel occupancy tax shall be expended only in a manner, which directly enhances and promotes tourism and the convention and hotel industry as here in before delineated. Such revenue shall not be used of the general revenue purposes or general governmental operations of the municipality, which are not directly related to promoting the hotel and convention industry or tourism in the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 1927, § 9, 10-10-2000) 
Sec. 50-71. - Administrative requirements; accountability, keeping of records. 
(a)  The city council may, by contract, delegate to a person, including another governmental entity or a private organization, the management or supervision of programs and activities funded with revenue from the hotel occupancy tax. The city council shall approve in writing in advance the annual budget of the entity to which it delegates those functions, and shall require the entity to make periodic reports to the city council at least annually listing the expenditures made by the entity of revenues from the tax provided by the municipality. 
(b)  The entity must maintain the revenue provided by the municipality from the tax in a separate account established for the purpose and may not commingle that revenue with any other money or maintain it in any other account. 
(c)  The municipality may not delegate to any person or entity the management or supervision of its convention and visitors programs and activities funded with revenue from the hotel occupancy tax other than by contract as provided herein. 
(d)  City council's approval of the entity's annual budget to which these functions are delegated creates a fiduciary duty in the person or entity with respect to the revenue provided by the municipality to the person or entity under the contract. 
(e)  A person or entity with whom the municipality contracts to conduct authorized activities shall maintain complete and accurate financial records of each expenditure of hotel occupancy tax revenue made by the person or entity, and on request of the city council or other person, shall make the records available for inspection and review. 
(f)  Hotel occupancy tax revenue may be spent for day-to-day operations, supplies, salaries, office rental, travel expenses and other administrative costs only if those administrative costs are incurred directly in the promotion and servicing of expenditures here in before authorized. The portion of the total administrative costs for activities for which hotel occupancy tax revenue may be used may not exceed the administrative costs actually incurred in conducting the authorized activities. 
(g)  Hotel occupancy tax revenue may not be spent for travel for a person to attend an event or conduct an activity in which the primary purpose of not directly related to the promotion of the hotel and convention facilities of the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 1927, § 10, 10-10-2000) 
Secs. 50-72-50-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - HOUSING TAX ABATEMENT 

Sec. 50-100. - Findings and determinations. 
    The city, after conducting such hearings and having heard such evidence and testimony, has made the following findings and determinations based on the testimony and evidence presented to it: 
(1)  That the public hearing on the designation of the area within the city limits, as a residential tax abatement reinvestment zone has been properly called, held and conducted and that notices of such hearings have been published as required by law and delivered to all taxing units overlapping the territory inside the proposed reinvestment zone; 
(2)  That the boundaries of the reinvestment zone shall be the boundaries of the city limits as they exist upon adoption of this article; 
(3)  That the creation of the reinvestment zone for multifamily residential housing tax abatement in Beeville, and the improvements sought are feasible and practical and, will be a benefit to the reinvestment zone and to the city after the expiration of any tax abatement agreement entered into under V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 312.204; and 
(4)  That the reinvestment zone meets the criteria for the creation of a reinvestment zone as set forth in V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 312.202, as amended, in that it is reasonably likely as a result of the designation to contribute to the retention or expansion of primary employment or to attract major investment in the zone that would be a benefit to the property and that would contribute to the economic development of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2094, § 1, 3-27-2007) 
Sec. 50-101. - Property redevelopment. 
    Pursuant to the Property Redevelopment and Tax Abatement Act, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 312.001 et seq., the city hereby creates a Reinvestment Zone for multifamily residential housing tax abatement. The zone's boundaries shall be coterminous with the city limits upon adoption of this article, and such reinvestment zone is hereby designated as Beeville Residential Tax Abatement Reinvestment Zone Number Two. The designation of this zone expires five years after the effective date of this article and may be renewed for periods not to exceed five years. 
(Ord. No. 2094, § 2, 3-27-2007) 
Secs. 50-102-50-130. - Reserved.

(Ord. No. 1695, § 1, 6-11-1991)

(Ord. No. 1695, § 3, 6-11-1991; Ord. No. 1702, 8-13-1991) 
Sec. 50-134. - No designation as reinvestment zone. 
    The area described in this article is designated as an enterprise zone only and not a reinvestment zone, subject to the approval of the state department of commerce. 
(Ord. No. 1695, § 4, 6-11-1991) 
Sec. 50-135. - Gas and electricity for residential use. 
    As permitted by V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 321.105(c), the city council has voted to retain its local sales and use tax on the use, storage, or other consumption of gas and electricity for residential use. 
(Ord. No. 1307, 2-27-1979)

(Ord. No. 2223, § 1, 9-27-2013)
