(Ord. No. 2223, § 3, 9-27-2013) 
Chapter 52 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Rules of the Road, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 541.001 et seq.; powers of local authorities regarding regulation of traffic, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 542.202; limitations on local authorities, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 42.203; municipalities may not operate automated traffic control system for speed limit enforcement, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 542.2035; municipal authority to regulate parking, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 601.001; municipal streets generally, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 312.001 et seq.; railroad and roadway crossings, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 471.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 52-1. - Traffic safety commission. 
(a)  Established; membership. The city has created a traffic safety commission, consisting of five members appointed by the city council. Members shall serve terms of two years staggered such that the term of two members expire in one year and the terms of the remaining three members expire in the following year. The chairman and vice-chairman shall be elected annually by the members of the commission at their first meeting of each calendar year. 
(b)  Function. The commission shall be an advisory body. It may establish rules and regulations for its meetings and proceedings. It shall make studies of traffic conditions in the city and recommendations to the city council or administrative staff designed to reduce and eliminate traffic accidents, injuries and deaths resulting therefrom, and the best methods, which, in its judgment, should be adopted to accomplish such results. It shall seek the cooperation and coordination of any and all other civic groups created and working for the same common purpose of improving traffic conditions in the city. It shall make reports to the city council of its work from time to time. 
(c)  Incurring debts and other liabilities. The commission shall not be authorized to create any debts or incur any other liability on behalf of the city unless first authorized to do so by the city council. 
(Code 1973, §§ 17-7-17-9; Ord. No. 608, §§ 1-3, 2-27-1962; Ord. No. 700, § 1, 4-14-1964; Ord. No. 2144, §§ 1-3, 1-13-2009) 
Sec. 52-2. - [Handheld mobile communication devices.] 
(a)  Definitions. In this article: 
    Bicycle means a device that a person may ride and that is propelled by human power and has two tandem wheels at least one of which is more than 14 inches in diameter. 
    Engaging in a call means talking to, dialing, or listening on a handheld mobile communication device, but does not include holding a mobile communication device to activate or deactivate the device. 
    Handheld mobile communication device means a text-messaging device or other electronic, two-way communication device that uses a commercial mobile service, as defined by 47 U.S.C. section 332, that is designed to receive and transmit voice communication, text message or pictorial communication, or both, whether by internet or other electronic means. The term includes a mobile telephone, and a personal digital assistant (PDA). 
    Hands-free mobile telephone means a mobile telephone that has an internal feature or function or that is equipped with an attachment or addition, whether or not permanently part of the mobile telephone, by which a user engages in a call without the use of either hand (or prosthetic device or aid in the case of a physically disabled person) whether or not the use of either hand (or prosthetic device) is necessary to activate or deactivate the mobile telephone. 
    Operating a bicycle means sitting astride a permanent seat attached to the bicycle while the bicycle is in motion. 
    Park or parked shall mean for the operator to completely cease movement of a motor vehicle in a lawful manner and location. For purposes of this section, "parked" does not include or mean a vehicle stopped in a lane of traffic due to either a lawful traffic-control device, or the conditions on the roadway, or traffic congestion patterns then existing. 
    Text message means a two-way communication (whether real-time or asynchronous) in which data (composed in whole or in part of text, numbers, images, or symbols) is sent, entered, or received by a method other than by voice and transmitted through either a short message service (SMS) or a computer network. The term does not include a communication transmitted through a global positioning or navigation system. 
(b)  Use of handheld mobile communication devices prohibited. 
(1)  A person commits an offense if, while operating a motor vehicle or a bicycle on a public roadway or any area described under subsection (a) of this section, the person uses a handheld mobile communication device to: 
a.  Engage in a call; 
b.  Send, read, or write a text message; 
c.  View pictures or written text whether transmitted by internet or other electronic means; 
d.  Engage in gaming; or 
e.  Engage in any other use of the device while operating a moving motor vehicle. 
(2)  This section does not apply to an operator of a motor vehicle or bicycle who is using a handheld mobile communication device: 
a.  While the vehicle or bicycle is legally parked or is being operated on private property; 
b.  If the device is affixed to the vehicle, whether permanently or temporarily, and being actively utilized as a global positioning or navigation system; 
c.  If the device is being used in conjunction with a hands-free mobile communication telephone or other such device through Bluetooth or other comparable technology; 
d.  While operating an authorized emergency vehicle in an official capacity; or 
e.  Who is licensed by the Federal Communications Commission while operating a radio frequency device other than a hand held mobile communication device. 
(3)  It is an affirmative defense to prosecution under this section if the person was using a handheld mobile communication device for the purpose of: 
a.  Communicating with an emergency response operator, a fire department, a law enforcement agency, a hospital, a physician's office, or a health clinic regarding a medical or other emergency situation; or 
b.  Preventing injury to a person or property. 
(c)  Penalty. 
(1)  A person convicted of an offense under this section shall be punished by a fine of not more [than] $150.00 for a first offense and not more than $500.00 for any additional offenses. 
(2)  An offense under this section is not a moving violation and may not be made a part of a person's driving record or insurance record. 
(Ord. No. 2313, §§ 1-3, 11-21-2016) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2313, §§ 1-3, adopted Nov. 21, 2016, enacted provisions but did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, codification as § 52-2 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 52-3-52-20. - Reserved.

Sec. 52-23. - Yield intersections. 
    All vehicles proceeding along the following streets, in the directions respectively stated, shall yield the right-of-way to vehicles on the other street or streets as set forth in this article: 
(1)  While proceeding north on Adams, shall yield right-of-way at the intersection of St. Mary's Street.

Sec. 52-24. - Pedestrian crossings. 
(a)  All vehicles shall come to a stop at an established pedestrian crossing in the city when pedestrians are present in such crosswalk and remain stopped until the crosswalk is free and clear of pedestrians. It is the duty of vehicle drivers to keep a proper look out for pedestrians in the vicinity of the crosswalk. 
(b)  The city has established the following ten-foot-wide pedestrian crossings: 
(1)  In the 1100 block of West Stamper Street at 400 South Minnesota Street. 
(2)  In the 600 Block of North St. Mary's Street between the present First Baptist Church Auditorium and its parking lot. 
(Ord. No. 1647-A, 12-12-1989; Ord. No. 1647-B, 2-25-2014) 
Sec. 52-25. - One-way streets and roadways. 
    The following streets and roadways are designated one-way, on which vehicular traffic shall travel only in the direction specified: 
(1)  North Avenue E southbound from the intersection of West Carter Street to its intersection with West Ireland Street. 
(2)  Alley running north and south across block two, Jones Addition, northbound between West Hefferman Street and West Cleveland Street. 
(3)  Alley running north and south across block 36, Original Townsite, northbound between West Bowie Street and West Hefferman Street. 
(4)  Doc Street, from its intersection with Buchanan Street to its intersection with Adams Street. 
(5)  Doc Street eastbound from its intersection with Adams Street to its intersection with Buchanan Street. 
(6)  East Flournoy Street westbound from its intersection with North Harrison Street to its intersection with North Tyler Street. 
(7)  North Harrison Street northbound from its intersection with Kennedy Street to its intersection with Flournoy Street. 
(8)  North Harrison from East Lott Street to East Flournoy Street northbound between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. on days when school is in session. 
(9)  East Kennedy Street westbound from its intersection with North Tyler Street to its intersection with North Harrison Street. 
(10)  Mussett Street southbound from South Washington Street to Fadden Street. 
(11)  All of South Mussett Street southbound only from Highway 202 to FM 351 on school days from 7:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. 
(12)  North Tyler Street southbound from its intersection with Flournoy Street to its intersection with Lott Street. 
(13)  The 800 and 900 blocks of North Polk Street from East Jones Street to East Hayes Street is hereby designated a one-way southbound street for all vehicular traffic between the hours of 7:30 a.m. to 8:30 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. to 4:00 p.m. on days when school is in session. 
(14)  The 700 block of North Filmore Street is hereby designated a one-way allowing only southward bound vehicular traffic on all school days between the hours of 7:30 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. 
(15)  That portion of Mussett Street adjacent to the F.M.C. school campus is hereby designated a one-way allowing only southward bound vehicular traffic toward FM 351 on all school days between the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. 
(16)  The 200 block of East Stamper Street allowing only eastward bound vehicular traffic at all times. 
(17)  The 400 block of South Jefferson Street allowing only southward bound vehicular traffic at all times. 
(18)  Establishing one-way traffic between the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 4:00 pm during school days limiting traffic to a southward direction of travel on the 300 block of North Jackson Street and eastward on 500 and 600 blocks of West First Street in efforts to alleviate the acknowledged heavy traffic congestion around the Jackson Elementary School during the time when the students are left in the morning and picked up in the afternoon. 
(Code 1973, § 17-17; Ord. No. 498, 8-11-1959; Ord. No. 531, 4-26-1960; Ord. No. 662, 8-13-1963; Ord. No. 699, 3-24-1964; Ord. No. 772, 10-28-1965; Ord. No. 793, 3-8-1966; Ord. No. 906, 6-11-1968; Ord. No. 916, § 1, 7-23-1968; Ord. No. 1060, 11-23-1971; Ord. No. 1431, 10-12-1982; Ord. No. 1476, 10-11-1983; Ord. No. 1593, 10-13-1987; Ord. No. 1847, 2-11-1997; Ord. No. 1880, 10-27-1998; Ord. No. 2020, 12-9-2003; Ord. No. 2035, 8-10-2004) 
Sec. 52-26. - Restricted or assisted turn designations. 
(a)  A designated right-turn lane only is hereby established on the most northern 200 feet of the 2300 block of North Adams Street where it comes perpendicular to FM 351 so as to facilitate eastbound traffic unto FM 351 from North Adams Street. 
(b)  Tractor trailer vehicles proceeding westward on the 100 block of West Corpus Christi Street are hereby prohibited from making right-hand turns onto the 100 block of North Washington Street. 
(Ord. No. 1847, 2-11-1997; Ord. No. 1947, 11-13-2001) 
Sec. 52-27. - Traffic control lights. 
(a)  Flashing lights for school zones. The city has established the following school zones controlled by mechanically flashing lights, which shall be utilized between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 4:30 p.m. on each day that school is in session: 
(1)  On the 700-900 blocks of North Adams Street. 
(2)  On the 400-500 blocks of W. Corpus Christi Street. 
(3)  On the 800-1100 blocks of West Fannin Street. 
(4)  On FM-673 between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. 
(5)  On the 400-600 blocks of East Houston Street. 
(6)  On the 1500-1600 blocks of South Washington Street. 
(7)  On the 1900 block of South Washington Street. 
(b)  Blinker-type lights. At the intersection of Minnesota Street and West Corpus Christi Street, there shall be installed a blinker-type traffic control light, the ember lamp to be facing West Corpus Christi Street and the red lamp to be facing Minnesota Street. All vehicular traffic on Minnesota Street shall stop at such intersections before entering West Corpus Christi Street, the traffic on West Corpus Christi Street shall therefore have the right-of-way over traffic entering from Minnesota Street. 
(Ord. No. 1298, 10-10-1978; Ord. No. 1594, 10-27-1987; Ord. No. 1755, 10-12-1993) 
Secs. 52-28-52-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing and parking generally, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.301; parking, towing and storage of vehicles, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 681.001 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 52-50. - Laying out spaces. 
(a)  In the parking meter zones and parking lots operated by the city, the city manager is authorized to cause parking spaces and loading zones to be designated and maintained in and on such parts of such parking meter zones and parking lots operated by the city which may be authorized by the city council from time to time, in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  All spaces for parking vehicles shall be laid out parallel to the curb, with the exception of the west half of St. Mary's Street which lies between Corpus Christi Street and Bowie Street, in which area parking spaces shall be laid out at a 45-degree angle to the curb, and shall be designated by the yellow lines or marks painted on the surface of the streets and curb, and shall be laid out so there shall be one parking space for and at or near each installed parking meter. 
(c)  Loading zones for handling of passengers and heavy or bulky merchandise, supplies and materials shall be laid out and designated by red colored lines or marks on the surface of street or curb, with the words "Loading Zone" painted thereon. No parking meter shall be installed in or adjacent to a loading zone. 
(Code 1973, § 17-41; Ord. No. 252, § 4, 5-29-1946; Ord. No. 509, § IV, 10-13-1959) 
Secs. 52-51-52-73. - Reserved.

Sec. 52-75. - Limited parking areas.

Sec. 52-77. - [Commercial delivery trucks.] 
(a)  There is hereby established a "no parking for commercial delivery trucks" on the north and south end of the Rialto Theater. 
(b)  It shall hereafter be unlawful for any persons, firm or corporation to park or cause to park a commercial delivery truck in said area. 
(c)  Any violation of this section shall be deemed a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be assessed a fine not to exceed the maximum limit established by the most current state statutes. 
(Ord. No. 2331, §§ 1-3, 12-12-2017) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2331, §§ 1-3, adopted Dec. 12, 2017, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, codification as § 52-77 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 52-78-52-93. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - METERED PARKING AND PARKING LOT 

Sec. 52-94. - Use of parking space for loading and unloading. 
    It shall be unlawful for any operator of a vehicle to stop or park the same in a parking space for the purpose of loading or unloading of merchandise, supplies or materials, except where the place of business, where such merchandise, etc., is to be loaded or unloaded, does not have either a usable entrance from an adjoining alley or an officially designated loading zone on that part of the street adjacent to such place of business; and where there is neither a usable entrance to a place of business from an alley, nor an officially designated loading zone on that part of the street adjacent to such place of business, for the length of time necessary to expeditiously load or unload such merchandise, etc., and give or secure delivery receipt therefor; but it shall be unlawful for any operator to use more than two parking spaces for such loading or unloading for a longer time than necessary to expeditiously load or unload such merchandise, etc., and give or secure a delivery receipt therefor. 
(Code 1973, § 17-51; Ord. No. 252, § 16, 5-29-1946; Ord. No. 509, § XVI, 10-13-1959) 
Sec. 52-95. - Parking by United States post office. 
    It shall be unlawful for any operator to stop or park any vehicle in his possession or under his control on that half of St. Mary's Street adjacent to the lot on which the United States post office is located, same being lot 150 by 150 feet of block 37 of the Original Townsite, for a longer period of time than that established therefor between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. of any day. 
(Code 1973, § 17-53; Ord. No. 252, § 22, 5-29-1946) 
Sec. 52-96. - Impounding vehicles. 
    In the event any vehicle shall be found standing or parked in violation of and contrary to any of the provisions of this division, the same shall be a nuisance per se, and shall be removed by any police officer and taken to some place designated by the chief of police for such purpose, and there kept by such officer until application for its redemption shall be made by the owner or his duly authorized agent, who shall be entitled to the possession thereof upon payment to the city of a sum as provided on the city fee schedule , together with all other reasonable costs of removal and storage that may have accrued thereon. In the event the vehicle impounded shall not be redeemed by its owner or his agent, within 30 days, such vehicle shall be disposed of in accordance with state law and this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 17-55; Ord. No. 252, § 17, 5-29-1946; Ord. No. 509, § XVII, 10-13-1959; Ord. No. 558, § 1, 1-10-1961) 
Secs. 52-97-52-135. - Reserved.

Sec. 52-137. - Regulations of use. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any operator to stand or park a vehicle in a loading zone for the purpose of loading passengers for a period in excess of two minutes, except, however, motor buses or motor coaches operated by bus lines over designated roads in and through the city may remain for a period of time necessary to expeditiously load or unload passengers. 
(b)  In loading zones for the loading and unloading of merchandise, supplies or materials, all such loading and unloading must be performed in an expeditious manner and no vehicle may remain in a loading zone for a period of time longer than necessary to expeditiously load or unload the same, or while the operator thereof is soliciting or engaged otherwise than the loading or unloading of the vehicle, except that a reasonable time shall be allowed for giving or securing a delivery receipt. 
(c)  The provisions of this section apply on all days and hours, except as otherwise provided. 
(Code 1973, § 17-65; Ord. No. 252, § 15, 5-29-1946; Ord. No. 509, § XV, 10-13-1959) 
Secs. 52-138-52-157. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SPEED LIMITATIONS 

Sec. 52-158. - Speed limits; general. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate a motor vehicle upon the streets, alleys and ways in the city in excess of the following speeds: 
(1)  30 miles per hour within the city limits, except when a lower rate of speed is required or when a greater speed is permitted as set out and prescribed in this chapter. 
(2)  15 miles per hour in all alleys. For the purposes of this section, an alley shall be defined as the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel having no legal or official name and of 20 feet or less in width. 
(3)  20 miles per hour on South Tyler Street north and south 600 feet from where Everett Circle meets said South Tyler Street. 
(Code 1973, § 17-15; Ord. No. 999, 3-10-1970; Ord. No. 1630, 7-11-1989; Ord. No. 1772, 6-14-1994)

    It shall be unlawful to operate a motor vehicle upon the following streets, alleys and ways in the city in excess of the following speeds: 
(1)  U.S. Highway 59. 
a.  From a point 42 feet east of Burke Street to a point 88 feet west of FM 673 (Minnesota Street), 40 miles per hour, except when signed as a school zone at 20 miles per hour.

Sec. 52-160. - Church zones. 
(a)  Vehicles proceeding through marked church zones within the city shall travel at a speed not to exceed 20 miles per hour between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 12:30 p.m. and 6:00 p.m. to 8:30 p.m. on Sundays. It is the duty of vehicle drivers to keep a proper lookout for pedestrians in the vicinity of the crosswalk. 
(b)  The city has established the following church zones: 
(1)  North St. Mary's Street commencing from the 400 block through and including the 1100 block between Cleveland Street and Fanning Street. 
(2)  In the 400 block of South Alta Vista Boulevard; in the 600 block of South Alta Vista Boulevard. All motor vehicles and other conveyances proceeding north and south on South Alta Vista Boulevard at such church zones shall reduce the speed of their vehicle to 20 miles per hour on the 400 block and 500 block of South Alta Vista Boulevard from 9:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. and from 6:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. on Sundays in the 400 block of South Alta Vista Boulevard and all Sunday mornings in the 600 block of South Alta Vista Boulevard. It shall be the duty of all drivers of such vehicles to keep a proper look out for pedestrians within the vicinity of said church zones. 
(3)  On the 100 block of North Burke Street in front of the Bethlehem Missionary Baptist Church. All motor vehicles and other conveyances proceeding north and south on the 100 block of North Burke Street shall reduce the speed of their vehicles to 20 miles per hour between the hours of 9:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. and from 6:00 p.m. to 8:00 p.m. on all Sundays. It shall be the duty of all drivers of such vehicles to keep a proper look out for pedestrians within the vicinity of said church zone. 
(4)  On the 1100 block and the north half of the 1000 block of North Madison Street in front of the Full Gospel Church. All motor vehicles and other conveyances proceeding north and south on the 1100 block and the north half of the 1000 block of North Madison Street shall reduce the speed of their vehicles to 20 miles per hour between the hours of 9:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. and 6:30 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. on Sundays and between 6:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. on Wednesdays. It shall be the duty of all drivers to such vehicles to keep a proper look out for pedestrians within the vicinity of said church zone. 
(5)  On the 400 block of South Jackson Street from 6:00 p.m. to 9:30 p.m. on all Wednesdays and from 9:30 a.m. through 12:30 p.m. and from 5:30 p.m. through 8:30 p.m. on all Sundays. 
(6)  On the 300 block of South Tyler Street from 6:30 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. on all Wednesdays and from 9:00 a.m. through 12:30 p.m. and from 6:30 p.m. through 9:00 p.m. on all Sundays. It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a motor vehicle in said zone in excess of 20 miles per hour during the applicable days and time zones. 
(7)  On all of the 700 block and the southern half of the 800 block of North Avenue D: 
a.  On Wednesdays from 6:00 p.m. to 8:00 p.m. 
b.  On all Saturdays from 5:30 p.m. to 7:30 p.m. 
c.  On all Sundays from 7:30 am. to 9:30 a.m. and from 10:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. 
(c)  There is hereby established a church crosswalk on the 700 block of North Avenue D commencing at its intersection with the most southern boundary of West Carter Street southward along North Avenue D a distance of 30 feet, with signs designating the crosswalk.

ARTICLE V. - SCHOOL ZONES 

Sec. 52-190. - Operation of vehicles when approaching. 
    All motor vehicles, wagons and other conveyances proceeding at school crosswalks shall, whenever children are in, or are about to enter, a crosswalk, come to and immediately halt and shall remain stopped until the crosswalk is free and clear of all children. It shall be the duty of all drivers of such vehicles to keep a proper lookout for children within the vicinity of and in school crosswalks. 
(Code 1973, § 17-74; Ord. No. 994, 2-24-1970) 
Sec. 52-191. - Parking prohibited in school bus loading and unloading areas. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle in a school bus loading and unloading zone, except that it shall be lawful to park school buses therein temporarily for the purpose of loading or unloading schoolchildren. 
(Code 1973, § 17-77; Ord. No. 515, 10-10-1959) 
Sec. 52-192. - Restricted zones and hours enumerated. 
(a)  Street closure. The following streets shall be closed to traffic during the hours indicated: 
(1)  That portion of the 500 block of East Lott Street lying between a line 36 feet east of its intersection with North Harrison Street and 36 feet west of its intersection with North Tyler Street is closed to motor vehicle traffic between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. on all days when school classes and other school activities are in session and taking place at the adjacent school. 
(2)  The entire 600 Block of East Hayes Street shall be closed to all through traffic on all school days between the hours of 7:30 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. by the physical placement of traffic barricades where it comes perpendicular to North Tyler Street. 
(3)  School zone effectiveness for the St. Philip's Episcopal School is in effect between the hours of 11:30 a.m. and 12:30 p.m. 
(b)  Directional use restrictions. Directional traffic control shall be applicable on the following streets as indicated during the times indicated: 
(1)  The 700 Block of East Hayes Street is hereby designated a one-way allowing only westward bound vehicular traffic on all school days between the hours of 7:30 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. 
(2)  The 700 Block of North Filmore Street is hereby designated a one-way allowing only southward bound vehicular traffic on all school days between the hours of 7:30 a.m. to 4:00 p.m.

Sec. 52-194. - Loading and unloading zones established. 
(a)  There is established a school bus loading and unloading zone on the west curbline of North Tyler Street, commencing at the intersection of the western curbline of North Tyler Street and the southern curbline of Flournoy Street, and proceeding a distance of 660 feet to the intersection of the western curbline of North Tyler Street and the northern curbline of Lott Street. 
(b)  There is hereby established a loading and unloading zone on the east side of North Adams Street beginning at the southern boundary of East Orange Street at its intersection with North Adams Street and extending southward a distance of 723 feet. So much of the loading and unloading zone wherein there lies a raised curb shall be appropriately painted and there shall be erected appropriate signs as required. It shall hereafter be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked any vehicle of any kind or character in the loading and unloading zone referred to herein on Mondays through Fridays when school is in session, between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 4:30 p.m., except for the express purpose of loading and unloading children. 
(c)  There is hereby established a school bus loading zone on the west side of the 300 block of North Jackson Street beginning at the northwest intersection of First Street and extending southward to the southwest intersection of West Hefferman Street, a distance of 231 feet. It shall hereafter be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked any vehicle of any kind or character except a school bus in the loading and unloading zone referred to herein between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. on days when school is in session. 
(d)  There is hereby established a loading and unloading zone on the 100 block of the west side of North Jefferson Street beginning 20 feet from the southern boundary of East Bowie Street at its intersection with North Jefferson Street and extending southward a distance of 42.5 feet. It shall hereafter be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to park or cause to be parked any vehicle of any kind or character in said loading and unloading zone referred to herein, except for the express purpose of loading and unloading passengers and freight from commercial bus lines. 
(Code 1973, § 17-76; Ord. No. 515, 10-10-1959; Ord. No. 1070, 1-25-1972; Ord. No. 1149, § 2, 2-12-1974; Ord. No. 1186, §§ 1, 2, 9-24-1974; Ord. No. 1221, 11-25-1975; Ord. No. 1607, 8-9-1988)

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 52-206. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Extremely hazardous materials means acrolein, acrylonitrile, ammonia solution of not less than 44 percent, boron trifluoride, bromine, carbon bisulfide, chlorine, dimethyl surfate, dimethylamine, anhydrous, epichlorohydrin, ethylene imine, ethylene oxide, Fluorine, liquid, hydrochloric acid, anhydrous, hydrochloric acid, hydrogen cyanide, anhydrous, hydrogen fluoride, anhydrous, hydrogen sulfide, methylamine, anhydrous, methyl bromide (bromomethane), methyl chloride, methyl mercaptan, methyl sulfate, nitric acid, nitric oxide, nitrogen tetroxide mixture, nitrogen tetroxide, and dioxide, oleum (sulfuric acid, fuming), perchloromethyl-mercaptan, phosphorus trichloride, sulfur dioxide, sulfuric anhydride, titanium tetrachloride and trimethylamine, anhydrous. 
    Hazardous materials means those materials and substances listed and identified in the federal Department of Transportation's publication DOT-5800.2, as amended from time to time. 
    Heavy vehicle or large vehicle means vehicles not designed or used primarily for transportation of property and only incidentally operated or moved over a street. 
    Light truck means any truck with a manufacturer's rated carrying capacity of 2,000 or less including pickup trucks, panel delivery trucks and carry-all trucks. Light trucks are not "trucks" as defined in this section. 
    Through truck means a truck, as defined in this section, traveling through the city only to reach another ultimate destination and having no related business to be conducted in the city. 
    Through truck route means a way over certain streets, highways, and inter-connecting loops, as designated in this division, over and along which through trucks traveling through the city must operate. 
    Trailer means any vehicle drawn by a truck and designed for the transportation of property, including semi-trailers. 
    Truck means any motor vehicle with a manufacturer's rated carrying capacity that exceeds 2,000 pounds and is designed, use or maintained primarily for the transportation of property, specifically excluding "light trucks" as defined in this section. 
(Ord. No. 1533, § I, 8-13-1985; Ord. No. 1533-A, § I, 6-26-2012; Ord. No. 1533-B, § I, 1-12-2016) 
Sec. 52-207. - Determining gross vehicle weight. 
    For purposes of this article, gross vehicle weight may be determined by any city police officer by visual inspection of the manufacturer's rating or by the vehicle registration receipt that is required by state law to be carried at all times on any such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 1533, § I, 8-13-1985; Ord. No. 1533-A, § I, 6-26-2012; Ord. No. 1533-B, § I, 1-12-2016) 
Sec. 52-208. - Parking, weight and time limits. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park, or cause to be parked, or allow to remain any motor truck, motor vehicle, trailer or any other vehicle having a gross vehicle weight in excess of 18,000 pounds on any street or alley in the city. 
(b)  No truck, as defined in this article, shall park on a residential street for a continuous period exceeding eight hours or on any street in the city during the hours of 6:30 p.m. and 6:30 a.m. 
(c)  There shall be erected "No Thru Trucks" signs on East Inez Street at its intersection with North Adams Street and at its intersection with Wofford Lane. 
(Code 1973, § 17-89; Ord. No. 549, § III, 9-24-1960; Ord. No. 619, § I, 8-7-1962; Ord. No. 1213, 8-26-1975; Ord. No. 1533, § II, 8-13-1985; Ord. No. 1533-A, § II, 6-26-2012; Ord. No. 1533-B, § II, 1-12-2016) 
Sec. 52-209. - Petroleum carriers. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked on any street or alley within the city any motor vehicle, motor truck, trailer or other vehicle having thereon, or attached thereto, a tank or other receptacle used for the carrying of petroleum products as are described in this article, whether loaded, partially loaded or empty, except for the purpose of making domestic delivery of such products, and in such case, such truck, vehicle, trailer or other conveyance shall proceed from the highway by the most direct route to the point of delivery and from such point of delivery by the most direct return route to the highway. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to any vehicles stopping on any such street in the city due to breakdown of such vehicle, or due to causes beyond the actual control of the driver thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 17-90; Ord. No. 549, § II, 9-24-1960) 
Sec. 52-210. - Explosive-carrying vehicles prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked at any place within the city any automobile, truck, trailer or other vehicle or conveyance, which at the time of such parking is fully loaded or partially loaded with dynamite, TNT or any other form of explosive. 
(Code 1973, § 17-91; Ord. No. 549, § IV, 9-24-1960) 
Sec. 52-211. - Exceptions. 
(a)  The provisions of this article shall not apply under the following conditions and circumstances: 
(1)  When any truck, motor vehicle or trailer is carrying gasoline to filling stations, commercial customers or bulk stations located within the city. 
(2)  When any truck, motor vehicle or trailer is carrying such products to be used exclusively for its own propulsion. 
(3)  When any truck, motor vehicle or trailer, loaded or partially loaded, has stopped on any street or alley in the city for the purpose of discharging its products, cargo and contents, or when it is stopped for the purpose of making necessary repairs, or when caused to be stopped under circumstances beyond the control of the driver. 
(4)  When any truck, motor vehicle or trailer needs immediate repairs and is not loaded or partially loaded with such petroleum products and is on a direct route to a garage, or to the private property or place of business of the owner of the truck, motor vehicle or trailer; provided, however, this subsection shall not authorize the repair, nor the parking thereof for the purpose of repair, in any zone designated by the zoning ordinance as a residential zone. 
(5)  When any truck, motor vehicle or trailer, whether loaded, partially loaded or empty, has broken down and is out of repair to the extent that same cannot be repaired within two hours, and the police authorities have been notified, and the same is being removed from such place of storage or breakdown to a garage or to some other place within the city under the direction of the police department. 
(b)  In all cases where a truck, motor vehicle or trailer shall be broken down and unable to proceed under its own propulsion, or shall have a flat tire, the driver thereof shall immediately give notice of the location and condition of the vehicle to the police department; and the chief of police is directed, upon receipt of such notice, to cause a member of the police department to proceed to the location of such vehicle, and there assist the driver in making arrangements to have such vehicle removed to a suitable place for repair; and providing further, in the event such repairs can reasonably be made at the point where such vehicle has stopped, and within a reasonable time, the driver shall be authorized to do so under instructions from the chief of police, and the police officer so designated to proceed to such point shall either remain thereat, or shall designate some other person to remain thereat to warn other persons using the street of the location of such vehicle. 
(c)  When any person is engaged in the use of his trucks, motor vehicles and trailers in the city in hauling liquefied petroleum products, merchandise and contents, and has his place of business within the city, such person shall have a right to convey such truck, motor vehicle or trailer to such place of business without police protection, provided such vehicle, if it is one used for the purpose of hauling such petroleum products, is empty and free of all such petroleum products. 
(Code 1973, § 17-92; Ord. No. 549, § V, 9-24-1960) 
Sec. 52-212. - Major thoroughfares designated. 
    The following streets are designated as major thoroughfares within the city: 
(1)  North and South Washington Street. 
(2)  North and South St. Mary's Street. 
(3)  North and South Archer Street. 
(4)  North and South Minnesota Street. 
(5)  West Corpus Christi Street. 
(6)  West Fannin Street. 
(7)  East Houston Street. 
(8)  Reagan Road. 
(9)  Charco Road. 
(10)  Cook Road. 
(Ord. No. 1533, § IV, 8-13-1985; Ord. No. 1575, 2-10-1987; Ord. No. 1533-A, § IV, 6-26-2012; Ord. No. 1533-B, § IV, 1-12-2016) 
Secs. 52-213-52-222. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TRUCK ROUTES 

Sec. 52-223. - Certain truck traffic restricted; exceptions. 
    The operator of any through truck or trailer shall drive or operate such vehicle only over and along the through truck routes established in this division; provided, however, that the truck route restriction shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Pickups and deliveries. The operation of a truck upon any street where necessary to make a pickup or delivery at a destination point on a residential street so long as main city thoroughfares are used until reaching the intersection nearest the destination point. 
(2)  Emergency vehicles. The operation of emergency vehicles upon any street in the city. 
(3)  Public utilities. The operation of trucks owned or operated by the city, public utilities, and any contractor or materialman while engaged in the repair, maintenance or construction of streets, street improvements, or street utilities within the city. 
(4)  Detoured trucks. The operation of trucks upon any officially established detour if the truck could lawfully be operated upon the street for which such detour is established. 
(Ord. No. 1533, § II, 8-13-1985; Ord. No. 1533-A, § II, 6-26-2012; Ord. No. 1533-B, § II, 1-12-2016) 
Sec. 52-224. - Through truck routes established. 
(a)  Generally. The following truck routes are designated for through truck traffic, except truck transporting hazardous and extremely hazardous materials, within the city: 
(1)  U.S. Highway 59 . FM 351 on the city's most northern and northwest perimeter to its intersection with U.S. Highway 59 on the city's most western city limits and that portion of U.S. Highway 181 by-pass between its intersection with FM 351, on the city's most northeastern corner, to its intersection with U.S. Highway 59 on the city's most eastern city limits. 
(2)  U.S. Highway 181 . U.S. Highway 181 by-pass on the city's eastern perimeter. 
(3)  Business U.S. Highway 181, southbound . FM 351 on the city's most northern and western perimeter to its intersection with Business U.S. Highway 181. 
(4)  Business U.S. Highway 181, northbound . FM 351 on the city's most southern and western perimeter to its intersection with Business U.S. Highway 181. 
(5)  State Highway 202, northbound to east U.S. Highway 59 . U.S. Highway 181 by-pass. 
(6)  State Highway 202, northbound to west U.S. Highway 59 . U.S. Highway 181 by-pass on the city's southeastern and southern perimeter to the exit for Business U.S. Highway 181, continue north on Business 181 to its intersection with FM 351 on the city's southwestern and western perimeter. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(Code 1973, § 17-88; Ord. No. 549, § I, 9-24-1960; Ord. No. 1533, § III, 8-13-1985; Ord. No. 1533-A, § III, 6-26-2012; Ord. No. 1533-B, § III, 1-12-2016; Ord. No. 2322, 2-14-2017) 
Sec. 52-225. - Maps and signs identifying truck routes. 
    The police chief shall keep and maintain accurate maps setting out through truck routes upon which through truck traffic is permitted copies of which shall be kept on file in the city secretary's office and the police department and shall be available to the public. The police chief shall also cause signs to be posted within the city clearly designated the truck routes established in this division. 
(Ord. No. 1533, § V, 8-13-1985; Ord. No. 1533-A, § V, 6-26-2012; Ord. No. 1533-B, § V, 1-12-2016) 
Sec. 52-226. - Penalties. 
    Persons violating this division shall be subject to a fine of up to $200.00. 
(Ord. No. 1533, § V, 8-13-1985; Ord. No. 1533-A, § V, 6-26-2012; Ord. No. 1533-B, § V, 1-12-2016) 
Secs. 52-227-52-240. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - TOWING AND STORAGE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 52-241. - Vehicle storage facilities. 
    The city adopts as though fully set forth in this section the Vehicle Storage Facility Act, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 2303.001 et seq., which shall be applicable within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 1547, § 1, 2-25-1986) 
Secs. 52-242-52-260. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ABANDONED AND JUNK VEHICLES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Abandoned vehicles, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.001 et seq.; removal of unlawfully stopped vehicle, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.305; removal of personal property from roadway or right-of-way, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.3051. 

Sec. 52-261. - State law adopted. 
    The provisions of V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.001 et seq. regarding abandoned vehicles are hereby adopted by reference as though completely set out herein. A copy of the adopted statutes is on file in the office of the city secretary and may be examined there during normal business hours. 
Sec. 52-262. - Impoundment authorized. 
    Any vehicle that remains standing or parked upon any public street, avenue, way, alley or other public place, may be removed by or upon order of the chief of police, and placed in storage in a privately operated garage or other place designated by or maintained by the city, under the following circumstances: 
(1)  When any vehicle is found upon a street, avenue, alleyway or public place and a report has been previously made that such vehicle has been stolen or complaint has been filed and a warrant issued thereon, charging that such vehicle has been stolen or converted in violation of law. 
(2)  When any police officer of the city has reasonable grounds to believe that any vehicle has been abandoned. 
(3)  When a police officer arrests any person driving or in control of a vehicle for an alleged offense and such officer is or may be required by law to take the one arrested immediately before a magistrate, or if the arrested one is the sole occupant or the owner of the vehicle and is immediately placed in custody. 
(4)  When a vehicle is so disabled that its normal operation is impossible or impractical and the persons in charge of the vehicle are incapacitated by reason of physical injury or other causes to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its removal or custody, or cannot be found or are not in the immediate vicinity of such vehicle. 
(5)  When any vehicle is left standing or parked unattended for more than 48 hours in violation of this article; provided however, that in the event such vehicle is parked or standing immediately in front of or immediately adjacent to property owned by the owner of such vehicle, or property rented by such owner, before such vehicle shall be removed, the owner thereof shall be given written notice after the expiration of 48 hours and shall be given an additional 24 hours to remove or cause to be removed such vehicle. Such written notice may be given by placing same in the mail box of the owner or by depositing same in the United States mail, addressed to the owner at the address given on the registration receipt of the vehicle, or his last known address. 
(Code 1973, § 17-3; Ord. No. 883, § I, 2-27-1968) 
State Law reference- Junked vehicles declared public nuisance, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.071; authority to take abandoned motor vehicles into custody, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.011. 
Sec. 52-263. - Notice of sale of motor vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the chief of police to submit to the state highway department and similar agency of the proper state when the vehicle is from another state all information in his possession concerning the vehicle and to request that the department supply to him all information the records of the department contain on the vehicle. 
(b)  Except as otherwise specifically provided by statute, immediately on receipt of such information, and not more than ten days from the date of impoundment, the chief of police shall notify the owner and lienholders as shown by the records of the department by registered mail with return receipt requested that the vehicle has been impounded and the provisions of this division in regard to redemption and sale of impounded property. The notice under this section shall include all information required by V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.012. 
(c)  If the identity of the last registered owner cannot be determined, if the registration has no address for the owner, or the determination with reasonable certainty of the identity and address of all lienholders is impossible, notice shall be published, not more than ten days from the date of impoundment, in a newspaper of general circulation within the city. The notice under this section shall include all information required by V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.012. 
(d)  In the event a motor vehicle has not been redeemed within 20 days from receipt of the return receipt of notice of non-delivery of the registered mail or 20 days from the date of publication of the notice, the chief of police shall prepare a notice of sale of such vehicle, in the manner prescribed in this division for other personal property, shall send a copy of the notice to owner and lienholders, as shown by the records of the highway department, by registered mail, and shall post and advertise the notices in the manner required in the preceding section. Notice by registered mail to the address shown on the records of the highway department shall constitute notice of the pending sale to such owner and lienholders. 
(Code 1973, § 17-4; Ord. No. 883, § II, 2-27-1968) 
State Law reference- Seizure and auction of motor vehicles, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.014 et seq. 
Sec. 52-264. - Redemption. 
    The owner or any person legally entitled to possession of personal property impounded pursuant to this article may redeem the same as follows: 
(1)  Before sale. By paying to the chief of police the impounding fee and any other actual expenses incurred by the city in impounding and keeping the impounded property, as determined by the chief of police. 
(2)  After sale. By paying to the buyer at the auction sale double the amount paid by him for such personal property and any reasonable expenses incurred by him for keeping same; providing that the property must be redeemed from the auction buyer within 30 days after the date of the auction sale, excluding the date of sale; otherwise, title to the property shall become absolute in the auction buyer. 
(Code 1973, § 17-5; Ord. No. 883, § III, 2-27-1968) 
Sec. 52-265. - Scope of provisions. 
    The provisions of this division shall apply to parts of such vehicles, as for example, auto frames, doors, wheels, body hulks, engines, seats and cushions and any and all other parts, however great or minute in size; provided, however, when in the opinion of any such officer a vehicle or vehicle parts are by reasons of their location in the public street, road or alley a hazard to the public or are so scattered, dismembered or otherwise separated as to make it doubtful whether they are from one or more vehicles or in such condition that in such officer's opinion the cost of their reassembly would reasonably exceed their market value, such vehicle or parts may be removed from the public right-of-way without any prior notice to the owner thereof. In such cases, the notice required by this division shall be given after such vehicle or parts are stored. 
(Code 1973, § 17-6; Ord. No. 883, § IV, 2-27-1968) 
Chapter 54 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal water and utilities generally, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 552.001 et seq.; municipal utility systems, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 552.001 et seq.; agreement with conservation and reclamation districts, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 552.903; Texas Water Quality Act, V.T.C.A., Water Code § 21.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 54-1. - Extension of water and sewer mains. 
(a)  The city will extend its water and sewer mains without charge to the inside city limits customer, a maximum of 50 feet in order to serve individual lots. Where an extension of water or sewer mains is required in excess of 50 feet, in order to serve an individual lot, the owner will pay the entire cost of the extension beyond 50 feet. Outside city limits customers will be required to pay the total cost of extensions. 
(b)  Subdividers shall also be required to pay the entire cost of water and sewer mains required to serve a subdivision, provided that the city may participate in the cost of lines over and above the size required by a developer when the council determines such participation to be in the best interest of the city. 
(c)  If the city council determines that it is in the best interests of the community and improves the health and welfare of its citizens and thereby causes water or sewer lines to be extended, the property owners served by the line extension, having their property thereby improved, will be charged pro rata costs of the line extension. The charge will be based on the size of the line, not to exceed six inches, per foot of property served, plus cost of installation. If bond funds are used, pro rata will not be charged. 
(d)  All charges for water and sewer main extensions must be paid prior to installation of the line. 
(e)  All water and sewer mains extended become the property of the city, after acceptance of the installation by the city council, whose rules and regulations shall govern the use and maintenance thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 18-10; Ord. No. 983, §§ I-IV, 9-23-1969; Ord. No. 1101, § 7, 1-23-1973) 
Secs. 54-2-54-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - UTILITY CHARGES, BILLING AND COLLECTION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 54-21. - Fees and other charges provided in separate fee schedule. 
    All water and sewer deposits, installation, connection, and reconnection fees, and monthly service charges, as well as solid waste collection charges, shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
Sec. 54-22. - Utility deposits and deposit refunds; no interest accrues on deposits. 
    Utility deposits in the amount provided in the city fee schedule shall be required upon application for service. Deposits will be credited to a deposit fund and used to defray the costs of unpaid charges to each account. When the customer terminates the service, any amount remaining after final billing is satisfied will be returned to the customer. No interest will accrue to such deposit charges as any such interest will be used to defray the administration of the accounts. 
(Code 1973, § 18-6; Ord. No. 1101, § 5, 1-23-1973) 
Sec. 54-23. - Grounds for disconnection of services. 
    Failure to pay monthly bills for water, garbage or sanitary sewer services when due, or failure to pay the established sewer charge for industrial wastes when due, or repeated discharge of prohibited waste to the sanitary sewer, shall be sufficient cause to disconnect all services to the water or sanitary sewer mains of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 18-9; Ord. No. 1077, § 8(a), 2-14-1972; Ord. No. 1196, § 8, 1-14-1975) 
Sec. 54-24. - Nonpayment; disconnection of services; reconnection charge. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Day means a calendar day unless otherwise specified. 
    Utility services means city water, wastewater (sewer) or solid waste collection service or any combination thereof. 
(b)  Billing procedure; when delinquent. Utility bills hall be rendered to customers on a 30 day billing cycle. The total balance due as shown on the bill shall be due 25 days after the billing date. If the due date should fall on a weekend or holiday, then the charges will be due on the next working day. Any portion of the balance due on an account not paid on or before the due date is considered delinquent. 
(c)  Payment. Payments as accepted by mail and in person at the city's utility administration office in city hall. City personnel working outside of that office in the field are not authorized to accept payments under any circumstances. 
(d)  Notice of intent to disconnect for delinquency; disconnection. Accounts that remain in a delinquent status for ten days will be mailed a disconnect notice that allows customers an additional ten days to make payment arrangements or resolve disputed charges, before service is disconnected. The notice will indicate the delinquent amount due and the scheduled disconnect date. If the account remains delinquent on the disconnect date, service shall be disconnected; provided, however, that disconnection work orders will not be done on a day immediately preceding a weekend or policy when city hall offices will be closed for business. 
(e)  Deferred payment plans. 
(1)  Generally. Customers will be given the opportunity for a face-to-face meeting with a city representative during regular business hours prior to the pending disconnection to discuss the status of their account, and work out a mutually acceptable agreement to resolve the problem. The city will take into consideration personal problems which may have contributed to the customer's account delinquency. Provided that the customer makes a good faith effort to pay the delinquent charges within a reasonable amount of time, disconnection of services will be postponed. 
(2)  Medically related. The city will not disconnect service to delinquent residential accounts if the customer permanently residing at the address can establish that disconnection services will cause, or worsen, a medical problem or illness of a person residing at the residence. Any customer who seeks to avoid disconnection of service under this policy must have physician contact the city and confirm in writing the potentially affect of the pending service disconnection. This written statement must be submitted prior to the scheduled disconnection. The customer and city will negotiate a "deferred payment schedule" for the account which will allow service to continue uninterrupted so long as the customer satisfies the conditions and obligation of the agreement. 
(f)  Reconnection. If a customer whose utility services have been disconnected, requests reconnection of services, all delinquent charges must be paid, and the amount deposit fee brought up to the full deposit amount if any portion of the deposit was applied to the customer's outstanding delinquent charges. Reconnection fees in the amount provided in the city fee schedule shall be charged to the customer's account. 
(g)  Water service delinquency penalties applicable to all utility charges. The same penalties and charges now or hereafter imposed by ordinance for failure to pay the bill for water service when due shall be applicable in like manner in the case of failure to pay charges for all other city services including, without limitation, the established surcharge for industrial waste discharged to the sanitary sewer mains. 
(Code 1973, § 18-8; Ord. No. 250, § III, 4-9-1946; Ord. No. 1101, § 8, 1-23-1973; Ord. No. 1690, §§ I-IX, 4-23-1991) 
Secs. 54-25-54-51. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BUSINESS MASTER METER ACCOUNTS 

Sec. 54-52. - Purpose, intent and applicability. 
(a)  It is the intent and purpose of this article to establish the method of calculating water and sewage utility charges for business customers whose accounts are considered multiple connection or master meter type utility accounts, i.e., the account served by the master meter is charged more than one minimum charge for either water, sewage, or both services depending on the number of service connections or outlets on the premises served by the meter. 
(b)  This division applies to utility accounts serving business customers only, and addresses the method of calculating total charges for water or sewage service based on rates in effect at the time the charge is calculated. This division does not alter or change the utility rates presently in effect, or the methods of calculating utility service charges for any other type of city utility customer. 
(Ord. No. 1627, §§ II, IV, 5-9-1989) 
Sec. 54-53. - Business customer defined; exceptions. 
    For purposes of this division, the term "business customer" means a commercial enterprise selling or providing goods or services, offering space for rent or lease for commercial purposes, storage or warehouse space, governmental offices, veterinary hospitals, schools and churches. The term "business customer" specifically does not include any customer location where the primary function of the premises is for dwelling or living purposes, either on a permanent or temporary basis, such as single or multifamily dwellings, apartments, duplexes, rent subsidized housing, motels, convalescent homes, hospitals for overnight and longer patient care, mobile home parks, and businesses conducted out of a person's dwelling (home occupation businesses). 
(Ord. No. 1627, § III, 5-9-1989) 
Sec. 54-54. - Method of calculating utility service charge. 
(a)  Component charges. A customer's utility bill usually consists of several itemized charges, among which are charges for water or sewage service. The total utility charge for either water or sewage service to a business customer under this division shall be the sum total of two component charges: 
(1)  Basic (minimum) charge. The basic charge shall be the current basic charge for the size of water meter serving the account, or in the case of sewage service, the current basic sewage charge. There shall be one basic charge only for each type of service, and no multiplication factor will be applied to the basic charge as a result of multiple connections. The present basic charge is $11.31 for water service, and $7.89 for sewage service. 
(2)  Consumption (volume) charge. The consumption charge shall be calculated as follows: 
Total Metered Consumption - Consumption Allowance Included in Basic Charge Consumption Net of Minimum Allowance x Consumption Charge per 1,000 gallons 
Consumption Charge  
(b)  Calculation of consumption factor. The total metered consumption factor upon which sewage charges are based is presently calculated for each account once a year based on average monthly water consumption during January and February. The consumption factor for an account then remains constant from month to month until a new consumption factor is calculated. 
(Ord. No. 1627, § V, 5-9-1989) 
Secs. 54-55-54-81. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WATER SERVICE AND RESOURCES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 54-82. - Water conservation policy and emergency plan adopted. 
    The city has adopted a water conservation policy and emergency plan, made a part of this article as though set forth in full herein, as an official policy of the city. A copy of the plan is available in the office of the city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 2155, § 1, 6-23-2009; Ord. No. 2237, 9-23-2014) 
Secs. 54-83-54-107. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PRIVATE WATER WELLS AND WATER SYSTEMS 

Sec. 54-108. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abandoned means a water well that is not a producing well. A well is considered abandoned it has not actually produced water in substantial quantity for a period of 90 days or more. 
    Backflow preventers mean a device or means to prevent backflow into the city's potable water system. 
    Commercial means engaging in or pertaining to commerce or mercantile; as a commercial business of selling a product for profit; having a financial profit as an aim in the distribution or sale of water; to produce or to make producible in quantities sufficient to supply quantities of water for use in businesses, factories, industrial plants, warehouses, recreational areas, apartment houses, hotels, motels, multiple family rental dwellings; condominiums, hospitals, nursing homes, rest homes and all other accommodations for housing having more than one single family dwelling space as such space is defined in city zoning regulations. 
    Cross connection means a physical connection between city's potable water supply system and any other water system, including water from wells other than the city's wells. 
    Domestic means production of water from real property on which there is situated a single family dwelling as that term is defined city zoning regulations. 
    Existing work means a water well or water system installed prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived. 
    Industrial means engaging in or pertaining to commerce or mercantile; as an industrial business selling a product for profit, having a financial profit as an aim in the distribution or sale of water; to produce or to make producible in quantities sufficient to supply water for use in connection with any form of machinery, device or devices, mechanical installations or other units of machines such as, for instance, in a factory, manufacturing plant, machine shop, warehouse, industrial development, refinery, and any and all other installations where water is employed for all purposes and uses having a financial profit as a motive and where water may be produced or is producible in substantial quantities for commerce or for an industrial or commercial venture of whatever character. 
    Plumbing inspector means any person licensed by the state board if plumbing examiners and employed by the city for the purpose of inspecting work and installations in connection with this division. 
    Public sewer means a common sewer directly controlled by a public authority. 
    Sanitary sewer means a pipe which carries wastewater and excludes stormwater, surface water and groundwater. 
    Septic tank means a watertight receptacle which receives the discharge of a drainage system or part thereof, which is designed and constructed so as to separate solids from the liquid, digest organic matter through a period of detention, and allow the liquids to discharge into the soil outside of the tank through a drainfield or disposal or perforated piping. 
    Water main means a water-distribution pipe for public or community use. 
    Water well means a bored well and specifically excludes dug and driver wells which are prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 1449, § IV, 2-22-1983; Ord. No. 1551, § 1, 4-29-1986) 
Sec. 54-109. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this division apply to the construction of water wells and water systems in the city and outside the city that are intended to be or are connected to either the city water or sewerage system. 
(Ord. No. 1449, § III, 2-22-1983) 
Sec. 54-110. - Penalties. 
    Any person that violates any provision of this division shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, subject to penalties as provided in section 1-14 unless a different penalty is required by state law or a higher penalty is permitted by state law in which event state law shall apply. If the violation is by a corporation, the officers and agents actively in charge of the business of the corporation shall be subject to the penalty herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 1449, § IX, 2-22-1983) 
Sec. 54-111. - Permits and licenses required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to construct a water well or water system in the city without having first procured the licenses and required in this division and complying with this division such that all workmanship and materials used in construction meet the requirements of this division in regard to the drilling construction, location and operation of such wells and systems. 
Sec. 54-112. - Water well driller license required; display of license. 
    Construction of water wells shall be performed only by those holding a valid water well drillers license issued by the state. The license number shall be displayed during construction at the site of the work. The number shall be clearly readable from the nearest traveled public roadway. 
(Ord. No. 1449, §§ II, V, 2-22-1983) 
Sec. 54-113. - Construction permits. 
(a)  Required; exceptions. It is unlawful to construct a water well or major overhaul of a water well without first securing a water well construction permit. Permits are not required for producing wells existing on the date of adoption of the ordinance from which this division is derived, provided that this exception is terminated upon abandonment of the well. Permits are not required for routine well maintenance. 
(b)  Application. All applications for permits shall give include: 
(1)  The name, address, telephone number, and state license number of the well driller; 
(2)  The name, address and telephone number of property owner; 
(3)  A sketch of property that shows location of the water well, all buildings, septic tanks, drain fields and other significant structures. The sketch shall also show the location of structures on adjacent property if within ten feet of the property line. 
(c)  City to be indemnified against all liability. The water well driller who is to conduct the work specified in an application for permit under this division must provide to the city, prior to issuance of the permit, assigned indemnity of all liability upon the city, in a form provided or approved by the city, for any damages caused by the driller while engaged in any service connected with the drilling of the well. 
(d)  Effect of false statements in permit application. Any person who in making application for permit shall willfully make any false statement in order to obtain the permit shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to the penalty provided herein. 
(e)  Limitation on issuance for wells to be used for commercial or industrial purposes. No permit for the drilling of any commercial or industrial water well shall be issued unless it is determined by the city council that the city cannot supply the required quantity of water within 18 months after the date of filing the application for such permit. If it is determined by the city council that the city cannot supply the water within the stated time period, the city council may issue a permit for the drilling of such commercial or industrial water well upon compliance with all applicable provisions of this division. 
(f)  Issuance by plumbing inspector. The plumbing inspector or his designated representative shall issue all plumbing permits in accordance with the provisions and requirements of this division. 
(g)  Permits personal to permittee and non-transferrable. Permits issued under this division are personal to the permittee and shall not be assigned or transferred to another person. No person shall permit another person to obtain a permit in his name or permit any new well construction or major overhaul work to be performed under his permit by any person other than a person authorized to do the same. 
(h)  Suspension of permit for bad faith or unreasonable delay. Bad faith or unreasonable delay in the performance of work under this Code shall be deemed a sufficient reason for suspension of the permit of the well driller so offending, and no further permit shall be issued until such act of bad faith or unreasonable delay has been corrected. 
(i)  Duration; lapse from failure to timely being and complete construction. Every permit issued under this division shall expire 90 days from the date thereof unless the work authorized by such permit shall have been commenced within such time; and every permit shall expire if the work authorized by such permit is suspended or abandoned for as long as 90 days after it has been commenced. In every case where a permit is permitted to expire, a new permit shall be obtained before any work is resumed. 
(j)  Fees. The permit and inspection fees applicable to permits and construction pursuant to this division shall be as set forth in the city fee schedule. 
(k)  Right of entry for inspection and testing. The plumbing inspector shall have the right to enter the property for the purpose of inspections to ensure compliance with this division and to ensure that there are no cross connections. 
(l)  Driller's log and water analysis to be provided by driller upon completion of construction. Upon completion of the well the well driller shall furnish the plumbing inspector a copy of the drillers log and a copy of the water analysis. 
(m)  Use of well must comply with permit purpose. Where a permit is granted by the city, for the commencement or drilling, working or reworking, and producing of water from a well for an express permitted purpose, the uses to which such water is employed shall be confined solely to the institution, installation or other application of the well not in contravention of this article, provided however, no such well or wells drilled and producing under a permit granted by the city shall be in any manner connected to the city's water distribution system which provides potable water to the inhabitants of the city and to other persons and places outside of the territorial limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1449, § VI, 2-22-1983; Ord. No. 1498, § I, 7-24-1984; Ord. No. 1551, §§ 3, 4, 4-29-1986) 
Sec. 54-114. - Construction and use standards and specifications. 
(a)  Casing. A casing of steel or other approved material shall be provided to prevent caving of the formations penetrated and also to ensure protection of water supply from contamination by water from shallow strata. The well shall be cased from the bottom of the drilled hole to 18 inches above the finish grade or more if required to keep surface water from entering casing. 
(b)  Seal. The annular space between the drilled hole and the well casing shall be sealed with concrete or grout for a depth of at least ten feet below finished grade. the casing shall be covered at the ground with a concrete slab no less than 24 inches by 24 inches by 12 inches. The top of this slab shall protrude six inches above finished grade and shall be sloped away from the casing. The top of the casing shall be provided with a suitable well seal to prevent contamination of the well. If a vent is provided on the casing it shall be equipped with an elbow turned downward and screened with a 16-mesh screen. 
(c)  Disinfection of well and equipment. Upon completion of the well but before it is placed into service the well and equipment shall be disinfected by the use of chlorine (powdered, tablet or solution). 
(d)  Water samples. After the chlorine has been flushed a sample of water shall be analyzed for purity. The well shall not be placed into service until the water has been tested and found to be suitable for human consumption. 
(e)  Closing abandoned wells. Permanently abandoned wells shall be filled with cement grout or concrete. Abandoned wells shall not be used for the disposal of wastewater, septic tank effluent or other wastes. 
(f)  State regulations applicable. State law and regulations as they pertain to the construction of water wells are incorporated by reference in this section and shall apply to water well construction in the city. 
(g)  Domestic use well may serve only one household. No more than one household may be served by a single water well if the water is for use inside the house. 
(h)  Commercial well may not be used for domestic purposes. It is unlawful for a commercial water well to be used for domestic (household) use or for consumption by the public. 
(i)  Location restrictions. Permanent derricks and towers associated with water wells shall be located no closer than 40 feet to any property line. Water wells shall not be constructed and drilled: 
(1)  Within 25 feet of a front property line; 
(2)  Within four feet of a side property line; 
(3)  Within 25 feet of, or a distance of less than 25 percent of the property depth from, a rear property line; 
(4)  Within five feet of any structure; 
(5)  Within 20 feet of any power line; 
(6)  Within 150 feet of any septic tank or drain field; or 
(7)  Within 150 feet of any barn or animal pen. 
(j)  Cross connections prohibited. There shall be no physical connection between water from water wells and the city's water mains. The use of valves, check valves backflow preventers, etc., as a means of connecting the water systems is prohibited. There shall be a physical separation (air gap) of at least nine inches between systems. 
(k)  Debris and dirty water. There shall be no debris, dirty water, mud or other refuse dumped or discharged onto public rights-of-way. 
(l)  Domestic wells not to be used for commercial or industrial purposes. The connection of a well formerly used for domestic purposes to a commercial or industrial business or enterprise is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 1449, §§ VII, VIII, 2-22-1983; Ord. No. 1498, § II, 7-24-1984; Ord. No. 1551, § 2, 4-29-1986) 
Sec. 54-115. - Sewer use charges. 
    The city is required to charge for water discharged into the public sewer on the basis of actual quantity of water discharge into the sanitary sewer. The method of determining this quantity is based on estimates made from the water meter readings therefore; when a water well is being used a wastewater meter must be installed and maintained by the city (at the expense of the user) or: 
(1)  If the well is used only for yard watering and other uses not connected with the sanitary sewer, then no change in sewer charges is required; 
(2)  If the well is used in such a manner that all or a portion of the well water enters the public sewer, then sewer charges shall be based on a minimum of 10,000 gallons per month discharged and entering the sanitary sewer; 
(3)  If the well is used for purposes other than residential use where all or a portion of the well water enters the public sewer, the water being discharged into the sanitary sewer will be estimated by the city based on each individual case. 
(Ord. No. 1449, § VIII, 2-22-1983; Ord. No. 1498, § II, 7-24-1984) 
Secs. 54-116-54-126. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - VETERANS MEMORIAL PARK WELL 

Sec. 54-127. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Improperly constructed water well means a well that does not meet the surface and subsurface construction standards for a public water supply well. 
    Well means the groundwater well owned and operated by the city near the Beasley Golf Course in the Veterans Memorial Park. 
(Ord. No. 2273, § 2, 10-13-2015) 
Sec. 54-128. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this division is to prevent certain uses and the construction of facilities in or on land surrounding the well that might create a danger of pollution to the water produced from such well. 
(Ord. No. 2273, § 1, 10-13-2015) 
Sec. 54-129. - Prohibited activities. 
(a)  Within 500 feet of well. Application of sewage plant or septic tank sludge, irrigation by sewage plant effluent, and construction or operation of any sewage treatment plant, animal feed lot, or solid waste disposal site are prohibited upon or across any area of land within a 500 foot radius of the well. 
(b)  Within 300 feet of well. Construction or operation of any sewage wet well, sewage pumping station, and drainage ditch that contains industrial waste discharges or the wastes from sewage treatment systems is specifically prohibited within, upon or across any area of land within a 300-foot radius of the well. 
(c)  Within 150 feet of well. The construction and operation of any of the following are prohibited within, upon, or across all areas of land within a 150-foot radius of the wells: 
(1)  New privy, cesspool, septic tank, or septic tank perforated drain field; 
(2)  Area irrigated by low dosage, low angle spray on-site sewage facility; 
(3)  Absorption or evapotranspiration bed; 
(4)  Underground petroleum or chemical storage tank; 
(5)  Liquid transmission pipeline; 
(6)  Landfills or dump grounds; 
(7)  Stock pens; 
(8)  Military, industrial, wood treatment or pesticide storage or mixing facility; 
(9)  Liquid petroleum and petrochemical production, storage, or transmission facility; 
(10)  Class 1, 2, 3, or 4 injection well; 
(11)  Improperly constructed water well of any depth; 
(12)  Abandoned well, inoperative well; and 
(13)  All other construction or operation that could create an unsanitary condition. 
(d)  Within 50 feet of well. Construction or operation of tile or concrete sanitary sewers, sewer appurtenances, septic tanks, storm sewers, and cemeteries and presence of livestock is specifically prohibited within, upon, or across any area of land within a 50-foot radius of the wells. 
(e)  Permissible construction. Construction of homes or other structures within a 150-foot radius of the well is permitted provided that such construction complies with all other restrictions of this division. 
(f)  Farming and ranching operations permitted. Normal farming and ranching operations are not prohibited by this division; provided, however, livestock shall not be allowed within a 50-foot radius of the wells. 
(Ord. No. 2273, § 3, 10-13-2015) 
Sec. 54-130. - Right of entry. 
    City employees and other authorized city representatives bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to immediately enter upon any premises located within a 150-foot radius of any well to conduct any inspection or observation necessary to enforce this division. 
(Ord. No. 2273, § 4, 10-13-2015) 
Sec. 54-131. - Removal of violating structures or activities required; penalties. 
    Any person who shall violate any provision of this division shall be required to remove the prohibited construction or potential source of contamination within 30 days after notification of violation.
